description:
I came here for dinner on a Tuesday night and there were multiple tables empty. We decided to give it a shot because the food on yelp looked great and because they closed later than most Chinese restaurant. They had many servers who always attended us and gave us the greatest service. They were super nice and did not rush us when we were ordering.

We tried the Beef/Vegetable Chow Mein, Dried String Beans, and a small bowl of Hot and Sour soup (serves two) and everything was great and up to my expectation! The string beans were soooo bomb because of the sauce. The price is a bit high for a traditional Chinese restaurant but I respect the hustle and don't mind when the service is great.

I would definitely come back here again. TRY THE STRING BEANS!
author: Quynh L.

description:
I had fond memories of this place from six or seven years ago when there were two cool, but very large lions at the front door. This used to be a great little place...emphasis on used to be. On this visit, gone were the lions and gone was the idea of good food with a little nostalgia. 

Every dish I had here was absolutely the worst. This place is a far different dining experience. I ate here with my wife and we had the fried calamari, shrimp dumplings, shrimp and vegetables stir fry and the BBQ pork egg foo yong. For starters the dumplings were chewy (see photo), thick and had no shrimp. The calamari was overly salted and loaded with MSG. The shrimp and vegetables was edible but had no flavor. The egg foo yong used to be my favorite dish, but it was mostly egg with invisible pork. Our waiter was kind enough but for the price I paid, I wish they put more effort into their food. 

If you are in Chinatown, just walk fast past this place. It was a poor meal and I doubt many of the other dishes have any redeeming qualities.
author: Sean C.

description:
I came here for an event and was excited and nervous to hear about us having an 8 course meal! Haha

S E R V I C E:
There was a lot of people so things were kind of hectic. The servers however did their best to get the food out to everyone. It took too much time to ask for water sometimes and there was a lack of communication - everyone was just go go go go!

F O O D:
I'm very picky with Chinese food. I've been to some restaurants or fast food places where MSG is clearly used and I get insane migraines from it. Here, I'm happy to say I didn't have any migraines. I do wish they had more veggie options that night, but the menu was set so there wasn't anything I could do. My favorite dish was the walnut prawns! They had the perfect amount of crisp and the sauce wasn't too sweet. My least favorite would have to be the braised duck. The presentation wasn't the best..it looked slimey. Not a fan of the taste either.

O V E R A L L:
I'm glad I came to the event, but this is probably not the place I would be dying to come back to.
author: Jaclyn M.

description: Stopped here while in Chinatown and so glad we did!! Everything was excellent and the quantity was above and beyond plentiful. The only downfall was the calamari, it was a little on the chewy side but I will not blame them because they are Asian and that is not from their heritage. All the Chinese food we had was perfect!!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Food was incredible.  We got one of the giant group dinners and everything was good and we are all stuffed and there is probably 5 pounds of food left.

The bbq ribs and the duck were the highlight of the meal.  They were both incredible and I really liked the duck coming with baos rather than the normal Asian tortillas.

Just a wonderful meal.
author: Jordan O.

description:
This place is terrible, we two people went there at 2:30pm on Monday. There are some 2-people group waiting there; while there are at least 10 empty tables, reason we have to wait was because those 10 empty tables were for 4+ people group. But think about it, it's 2:30pm, do you really think there will be 10 big groups to take those tables?

I gave the managers some suggestions, the lady was very rude and arrogant, saying I heard what you say, but if you want to sit on those tables, I am going to charge you the service fee for 5+ people group; and then asking me "do you still want it? If not, take a seat." While no seats are available in the waiting area, since two more small groups (less than 4 people) came after me.

Anyways, I still tried the food there since I was super hungry :(

But the experience was not good :(
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Very nice dinner in downtown Chinatown SF. We had fried rice, shrimp, egg rolls, salt and pepper crab, duck and wok tossed vegetables. All fantastic!  

Bathrooms are kinda hard to get to. 

They were filming "Venom" in grant street that night, so the street was blocked off. But we got to see a cool chase scene!
author: Kevin C.

description: My friend and I wandered in here after a long day of tin the sun. We wanted good quality food in a casual setting at a decent price, and that was what we found - a fair price point for big portions and attentive service, and a casual atmosphere in a big restaurant particularly suitable for groups. We found the food to be quite authentic and of good quality, especially given the price. We had done a quick scan of reviews before wandering in, but weren't discouraged by the average star rating, given how hungry we were, and I'm glad we weren't. In my opinion, this restaurant deserves higher ratings. I would recommend this for casual dinners or delivery!
author: Halle H.

description:
I can be a bit picky having been to China more time than I have fingers and toes.  It doesn't help when you also know those that can cook authentic Chinese food for you as well.  This always poses a dilemma for me going to a Chinese restaurant.

After a day of walking around SF we were STARVING LIKE HOSTAGES!  We wanted to get in this last little area before calling it quits for the day so when we saw this place we went in to eat.  They were not busy but there were a few people inside.  We were greeted as we walked in and seated right away.

We perused the menu and they came to take our drink orders.  We both got water since not having any all day.  Gulp gulp, gulp, aweeeee refreshing.!  They kept our glasses filled which was great.  Next they brought over some tea.

Looking at a menu when our starving is quite difficult.  We went back and forth with what to get.  I ended up with the mixed veggies and Bunny got the some beef dish that came over rice.  We also shared some spring rolls.

We chatted and another family from Texas came in.  I wish they would have sat them else where.  All they did was complain about the tea.  This taste different.  Umm yes it's not sweet tea darl'ing.  

Our spring rolls arrived and they were DELISH!  I always love the sauce they come with.  We tried not to eat those all up waiting for our food so we would have room.  Soon our food arrived to the table just as Mary-Sue and Jimmy-Joe and Huck were placing there order.  Wat's fry'd ri-ic-ice?  They have shrimp n-da fry'd ri-ice?  That sound gross. Well leave then Ruth-Ann and go to McDonald's.   Oh Jimmy-Jo dey have da blue crab herr.  Ugh....So annoying.  

We dug in teeth first.  Thank goodness we had the spring rolls before hand.  The food was just ok!  My veggies were cooked perfectly.  I could have used a bit more seasoning in the sauce.  Bunny liked his food and ended up with left overs.  

The service was good but the food was a bit hit and miss for me.  While the spring roll were yummy my veggie sauce didn't quite make a home run.
author: Ryan P.

description: I had the General Chou's Chicken, and white rice. It was absolutely delicious. The portion sizes were generous, and the chicken and vegetables were fresh and had very good flavor.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
Love this place. The vintage 1920 interior, with wonderful huge antique hanging lanterns and chandeliers, dark wood paneling, and the wait staff consisting mostly of grave, dignified, older Chinese gentlemen, reminds me of the old Chop Suey palaces my Mom and Grandma took me to in downtown Chicago as a kid.  Very few places like this exist anymore. 

It's a tourist crowd, but who cares, the food is good. The won ton soup had an ample portion of dense, delicious shrimp and pork won ton dumplings along with crunchy chopped cabbage, and the Hong Kong style seafood pan fried noodle (shrimp, squid, scallop, bok choy, carrot) was fresh and tasty.  And service was perfectly attentive.
author: Steve S.

description:
After a 6 hour road trip, we ended up at our final destination in San Francisco. We just so happen to arrive during the celebration of Chinese New Year. The City was a mad house! After looking through a few restaurants and walking out of one, (lol) we happened upon the Far East Cafe.

We were a little skeptical at first but after a long day, we decided to just take the chance. We went in and were advised of the 45 minute wait. On such a holiday , the wait was expected. We took a seat at the bar which was traditionally designed. We were served drinks within minutes and had a great conversation with the bartender/ owner. The 45 minute wait turned into more of a 20 minute wait, much to our surprise due to the venue being so packed!

We had the chicken chow mein, yang chow fried rice and the barbecue pork fried rice. The service was quick and the food was well prepared. I would recommend the Far East Cafe for a nice causal date night or for Chinese food with friends!
author: Shane O.

description: This place is amazing. Food is great but honestly Kathy (manager) makes this place like home. We will definitely be back 100 times. This is a must go place!!
author: Angelina S.

description:
We are from the East coast & know good Chinese from both Chinatown in D.C., & Chinatown in NYC. Have also traveled to Hong Kong & have had the non-American version of Chinese.

This place is some of the best Chinese we've had in a while! We were visiting family in San Fran & stopped here after spending the day there.

The hot & sour soup is the best you'll have. Spare ribs full of flavor, not dry or greasy. General Tsao's chicken was probably the best we've had, as was the chicken & broccoli. The crispy chicken had a beautiful presentation, and although the skin was crispy, the chicken itself was a little dry.  Had one of the spicy shrimp dishes, had lots of shrimp, could've used a little more spice. Very nice interior & each table had a lazy Susan to make it easier to share dishes. Looking forward to our next visit.
author: Renee K.

description: Terrific food, prices and atmosphere.  You might have to fight for service. Take control early.... insist on being noticed.  Grab the manager...she's very good.
author: Scott W.

description: Quickly seated for party of 9, fast service, delicious food. Fortune cookies. Clean bathrooms. Met our expectations!
author: Marrianne B.

description:
I guess I can't blame some people who came here with expectations that the food would be "as good" as Panda Express or a can of Chun King or, for the far more sophisticated and worldly diners, expectations that they would find "truly gourmet" Chinese food like that bastion of fine taste, P.F.Chang.  Those people would give this 100+ year old building 0-stars for being "old". Sure they would hate the antique hand-made lanterns as being "too dark" compared to proper LED fixtures.  Sure they would say that the staff (many of whom have worked here 30 years) aren't "cute" and "trendy".  I've read the reviews from those same people about ANY restaurant that's not a trendy multi-location chain that serves "American-sized portions" of microwaved frozen food. They obviously don't get out much.

Nope, you won't find any of that at Far East Cafe. Stay away if you're idea of Chinese food is canned chop suey!

Not that I know anything about Chinese restaurants. I've only filmed documentaries in China and eaten in restaurants big and small in large cities and tiny rural villages in China.  First off, historically China has amazing food ... they just don't use the word gourmet, that's an American affectation. In China portions aren't "super-sized". They are generally fresh, healthy, and served family-style.

Far East Cafe reminds me a lot of some if the larger restaurants in China's more metropolitan cities.  It isn't made of plastic designed to look like a movie set, everything is real. The people who work there aren't millennials dressed in fake Chinese-looking costumes.  The food doesn't come in a can from a restaurant supply company.

I had seaweed soup to start. I bet not one person who left a negative review would even try seaweed soup. It tasted like seaweed ...yum!  I did have the obligatory Dim Sum, something San Francisco natives call "pork rolls".  None of it looked or tasted "gourmet", in other words it was served as traditional Chinese food is served.

Bottom line, sure this place exists primarily for tourists. It's one of the first restaurants you come to inside the main Dragon Gate on Grant Street. If wouldn't be a bad idea if they had an instruction manual to help newbies dine there so they wouldn't be looking for trendy Americanized chain restaurant-type "Chinese food".  As far as service, what I saw were hard working people who live locally who hovered over us like a mother hen to make sure we were being served efficiently and properly.

IF YOU GO: Far East Café first opened its doors in this building in 1920 in a historic building that is one of the oldest in San Francisco, built in 1908 soon after the devastating 1906 earthquake. They serve Cantonese and Szechuan style food. The chandeliers are from an ancient China palace and the murals and paintings are hand-made and are over 100 years old. Prices are very low and reasonable, especially when you take into account they are in a high rent extreme tourist area.
author: Todd H.

description:
I love this place!  Again, came up here with my parents and my aunt and cousin.  I began to remember a couple of things as we sat in the main dining room.

She: I have a nut allergy
He: Huh?
She: A nut allergy? I'm allergic to nuts...peanuts, walnuts...
He: Uummm peanuts?
She: Is there cross contamination?
He: Huh?

I wanted to sock this woman.  She wasn't rude, just condescending.  And she had that whiney nasal voice...you know the one.  I wanted to turn and say, you're in an old school Chinese restaurant that doesn't care if you have an allergy or not.  Get the F@(# out!  LOL!  They ended up leaving, which was good since I didn't want to hear her complaining for the rest of the evening.

Great walnut shrimp!  I loved their noodles!  Again, this is an old school establishment, so if you have allergies or are a picky eater, stay the F@(# away and don't ruin it for the rest of us!
author: Mikey H.

description: This place has pretty good, authentic Chinese food but the service is terrible! I went with my boyfriend and mom, and they also enjoyed the food. I didn't realize dim sum hour was over, so I picked up a dim sum menu and proceeded to order, just to have the waiter, Jimmy, yank it out of my hands and yell, "NO MORE DIMSUM." He was so rude and walked away. We had to ask someone else to help us because he never returned! I probably wouldn't go back.
author: Alejandra A.

description: All Capone ate here in one of the vintage carved wooden rooms. This restaurant is located in the oldest parts of Chinatown. And not to far away from the Marina, where you can catch the boat ride to Alcatraz, where Capone was imprisoned. The Dim Sum came out fast, fresh and very tasty. The limitless hot tea leaves fill your small cup with old times from China.
author: Nancy R.

description:
I stopped in with my mom knowing that, as one of the first restaurants past the Chinatown gate, this place is for tourists. The building and decor are very nice - has an old-school feel to it. The service was fine, though when I wanted to ask if the "lychee dessert" was just lychee or something else with it, neither of the two people I asked understood, nor did they look for someone who might. Overall though, the service was good - we were given water and hot tea just a couple minutes after being seated. 

The food itself was just okay, with the appetizer sampler being the best of what we ordered (I would give just that a 4). The spring rolls were fried to perfection and i really enjoyed the dough that the potstickers were wrapped in. As for entrees, the vegetable chow fun had a good amount of bok choy, a bit of carrots, and a few slivers of cabbage. Altogether I found there was a good balance of noodles and veggies, though for some the veggies may have overpowered the noodles. Unfortunately, it seemed to just be seasoned with soy sauce because it was quite salty. Finally, my mom ordered the shrimp & chicken fried rice and again, it was just okay. Not the best fried rice you'll ever have but probably not the worst either. The main dishes came in large portions so we were both able to eat from each dish and still had left overs of both, probably because we were stuffed from the appetizers. 

All in all, if you are famished and can't take another step to find a different restaurant, Far East Cafe will certainly satiate your hunger but by no means will it wow your taste buds.
author: Leslie C.

description:
I took my mom here when she was visiting from out of state and she loved it. This place has such a cool interior with huge antique Chinese chandeliers and vaulted ceilings. The staff is well dressed and attentive, and the food is delicious.

I've been here twice and had the walnut and honey prawns which was $16 and the pressed almond duck which was $15. Loved both the dishes and the free hot tea.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
We stopped by the Far East Cafe, as we were visiting some family that wanted to try this restaurant. Upon reading reviews on Yelp, we were hesitant, but the reservations were already made so we ended up coming anyway. The experience was disappointing, in the sense that the food was mediocre at best, and priced higher than average Chinese food restaurants in the bay area. I don't mind paying a premium for a delicious experience, but this was the opposite of that. After finishing our meal, several waiters kept coming in and giving us looks as if they wanted us to leave as we had already paid the bill. Not sure why they were in such a hurry because it was only 8:30pm, so wasn't closing time, and there were plenty of tables open. We would recommend looking elsewhere for a better dining experience.

Best,
Charlie
author: Charlie K.

description:
What a neat experience! We were exploring San Fransisco, and about the time we wandered into Chinatown, the hunger pains developed into somethin' fierce. A quick Yelp check, and a TripAdvisor cross-reference eluded to the Far East Cafe. We wanted the best Chinese food we could find, quickly, and on a reasonable budget - we had reservations at three sushi restaurants later on, so we needed to travel light. A plate of Lo Mein, some steamed pork buns, and a pile of seared pot stickers should be just the ticket!

Their Lo Mein is in a word: explosive! The flavor is rich, wild, pungent, and clean. Who knew you could taste such magic from a plate of perfectly balanced, al dente noodles? Perhaps the flavor resulted from the MSG the chefs may, or may have not used in the sauce. Who cares, because it was the best, most memorable noodle dish I've ever had. If that plate of lo mein was local, I would live on it. 

Their steamed pork buns had a sweet flavor element I couldn't place, like they had steeped the meat in a thin barbecue sauce; I don't know that I would order them again, but they were very clean. The potstickers were both clean and wonderful; rich with flavor, but they're potstickers - so if you don't mangle them, all potstickers are comparable within their respective derivative cultures. 

The service was abrupt, and hurried - but not in a bad way. It seems part of their traditional culture, with much of the restaurant seemingly projecting such cultural elements. I haven't been to China yet, but I would assume - compared with restaurants in Kansas City - that they've gotten the experience close to culturally authentic. They even bring you a hot pot of free tea! This place is definitely worth a quick in and out. Enjoy!
author: Matthew C.

description: Did a takeaway for the infamous Egg fu young with prawns. It was okay and nothing special. It didn't wow me as a video program of this restaurant pioneer should have.
author: Chan L.

description: The reason we left is because they had these cool little private rooms and it was 3 o'clock in the afternoon and absolutely none of them were used and they wouldn't let us in. The fishtanks looked a little disgusting in the back. And the staff was incredibly rude. At the end of the We left because they only have three stars which I assume set meant that they were something incredibly wrong with the food
author: Jesse P.

description:
It's okay. The service is very abrupt and don't refill water and pretty much ignore you.

I ordered:

walnut prawns - super good

schezwan chicken - super bad

Egg foo yung - fantastic 

When I ordered the egg foo young, he kept asking "how many". I want one order.  "How many?" It went on and on.  So weird. For the record, You get 3 egg foo yung for $10.95

The restaurant was empty and as people arrived they sat them right.next.to.us.

I had an instant flashback when I walked through he door, that I had been here as a kid, in the 1960s in their private booths you enter thru a curtain.  That was very cool

The bill was $50 with tax and tip, this place isn't cheap. I would go back and get the egg foo yung to go.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Came for the decor, and food was pretty good too.

The big, bold, old-style Chinese decorations are fabulous. And when I say old, I don't think anything in this restaurant was made before 1870, except the food, I hope.

This good old Chinese American food done right, every dish was good, especially the fish and glazed prawns.

And it has these super cool little private booths, I don't know how you get them, maybe on a Friday night, when it's crowded, and you can kissy kissy in the booth.
author: John C.

description: Food was pretty bland.. everything tasted the same with little change between them.  Service was great.
author: David G.

description: This is my first time here and I would definitely come back. After a long morning in San Francisco, some friends and I decided to stop some place to eat. Wanting to try Chinese in Chinatown we stopped at the Far East Cafe. The staff was friendly and attentive. Getting the food was a a little slow, but once we got it, the food was great. The vegetables and meet were cooked perfectly. Not overly fast, but for some good Chinese at a reasonable price, this is definitely a place to try
author: Jordan P.

description: The food was good but priced higher than other restaurants in the area and smaller portions. Service was poor--never offered drinks other than the hot tea that comes on the table. With all the options around, I'd pick something else next time.
author: Kim P.

description: Came into town looking for some authentic Chinese food (and I know authentic and fresh). This place was okay nothing special compared to other restaurants I've tried. Ordered some sautéed garlic spinach (good), sweet and sour pork (ok the ratio had too much breading to pork), walnut shrimp ( over priced for what you get), and chicken wings (had five spice seasoning but that's all it was). I probably won't go back.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Their food is very good and the service is very fast. Have been there at least 3 times in the past few years and there has never been a wait more than 15 minutes. For big groups there are private booths with little curtains that house big tables for everyone to sit around- cozy but a cool feature for privacy and easy conversation. The decor of the place is interesting to observe as you eat, their colorful chandeliers are quite pretty. 

This is a favorite of mine in Chinatown.
author: Olivia B.

description:
For all the haters out there, I have been coming here for years. The egg foo young is always awesome and the veggie stir fry we had tonight was fresh and delicious.
The service was fine, fast and friendly.
I LOVE the classic decor and private tables.
Of course it's friggin touristy, this is a town that lives on tourism. Duh...
Needless to say, for anyone who had a bad experience, please come try again. You'll discover the truth that there ARE diamonds in the rough.
author: Andy B.

description: STAY FAR AWAY FROM FAR EAST CAFE !!!!! Horrible service ... I could see the staff eating a huge feast and people sitting down for about a min and then walking out .... keep in mind this happened to several groups who came in ... I should have left too when I knew this place wasn't going to be the best . The waiter was rude and obviously in a rush to eat a feast with his other coworkers .. we ordered fried wontons and received an order of egg rolls instead . We paid 9.00 for something we didn't even order !! I will never go back to this place again .. the only thing good about this place is the ambiance the deco is beautiful. They have private rooms for ...parties or meetings a little sketch but I guess it works ... anyways I warn you first timers not to go here . It's tempting because it's one of the first restaurants you see walking into china town .. very disappointed
author: Melissa L.

description: The food was bland and over cooked. Definitely not a place I would ever recommend or return to. Not good
author: Jim H.

description: Food was good and service was fast! Everyone helped out with each table to make everything run smoothly!
author: Sonya H.

description: I'm giving this place a two star, one because the place is cleans and the other one because the food was good. Although food was good and the place was clean the costumer service is horrible here. The waiter never asked if we needed drink refills and when I asked him, he blew me off like I was his friend or family. It was the rudest thing a server can do a Paying costumer. I was a server for 9 years, I would've never done what he did to me, that was would have me fired on the spot. Not only that but I had asked him to remove all the empty plates. I'm never coming back here again!
author: Crispina G.

description:
Visiting a Historic Chinese Cafe in Chinatown.   Beautiful paintings from 1920.  Reminds you of being in Beijing.

Great for groups.
author: Mandi T.

description:
So I have eaten here three times and I love it. The food is your basic American style Chinese food and has dim sum on the menu. 

So what makes it so special in my book? The old school Chinese restaurant style, the antiques and the private booths (rooms) that you can reserve in advance. 

The restaurant was established in the roaring 20s. If you truly look around you will see items that are a century old from China. Made in China doesn't mean much now but back then it was exotic. 

On our most recent visit, we were with my SIL from the UK. I didn't make a booth reservation, but I asked any ways. The hostess kindly reminded me it was by reservation only but she still allowed us a booth. I still highly suggest you make a booth reservation though. When they pulled back the curtain, my sister in law said "are you kidding? This is great!"

So if stepping back in time and sitting in your on private booth is your thing, make a booth reservation and have fun.
author: Trixie N.

description: Mediocre Chinese food. I came with a big group that was prepaid so I didn't get to order my own dishes. Some dishes such as the shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, fried calamari, sesame ball, were all lukewarm or even cold. The fried rice and stir fried noodles were both really greasy--but then again, that's expected for most Chinese restaurants. They didn't use that much msg because there wasn't a nasty taste in my mouth after so that's a plus. Tea is good though!
author: Donald C.

description:
Without question this restaurant is a novelty which caters mainly to tourists. The first thing I noticed was the lack of customers on a Friday night. We made a reservation for a booth which strikes a shocking resemblance to a public restroom with the walls scratched and dirty with horrid lighting. The food was horrible; meat was bland, noodles soggy, but most importantly, everything was cold. 
 
We arrived hungry and left hungry
author: Alan N.

description: Amazing food that you just can't find anywhere but Chinatown. Stopped in for a quick bowl of won ton soup and potstickers. OH MY! Delicious and perfect for a mid afternoon break along with the tea. The soup was made the way I'd grown up remembering it, with real shrimp and homemade noodles, fresh  Bok Choy  and delicious broth. I decided to try a half order of pot stickers. DELISH! I've never tasted anything like them before. The decor is perfect with oversized lanterns. I'm coming back next time I'm in town.
author: Robin M.

description: First restaurant I saw turning off California onto Grant (side w lanterns). Not bad prices- to me it's a bit $$ but it seems the norm in this area. Went for lunch. A short wait, mainly because a very large group was expected (30+ people) and tables were set aside for them. Food was okay, not great. Did not like the won ton soup. Service was so-so. He wasn't friendly but not rude. Didn't come back to check on us (which again, I'm finding it's the norm for this area).
author: Lisa R.

description:
Excellent service with a really cool ambiance... it's like you're in Shanghai in the 40's.
My meal was delicious and the staff professional and wonderful. I'll be back!
author: Cecilia D.

description: Outstanding architecture and very good food, great service and nice management! Try a booth! I left my phone behind and they kept it safe! Honesty goes a long way!
author: John S.

description:
From Hawaii ... heard we had to try Chinese food in San Francisco Chinatown ( said it's different here).  Walked along the mall here and very particular where I chose to eat Chinese food.  Ordered their noodles & dim sum. Asked for Chinese cake noodles and got a weird look.  In San Francisco its call Shanghai noodles and You have to pay extra. In Hawaii we can customize our dishes how we like (ex. Boneless Minute chicken cake noodle), in San Fran what you see on the menu is exactly how you order it, no substitute at all.   Glad to live in Hawaii. 

Overall best Chinese food restaurant here.
author: Go A.

description: Absolutely awful! Ordered soy sauce chicken and it came out as if it was in the refrigerator all day, told server it was cold (already had no more interest in eating) and he stuck it in the microwave and brought it back. Calamari was awful, not even sure if it was calamari. I wouldn't even recommend this place to my worst enemy!
author: Carly S.

description: Bomb....manager was very friendly and fresh crab we had a great time. Thanks again for having us. Really nice people and great food.
author: Travis M D.

description: I thought the food had some good options including the orange chicken and chow mein....however I believed that my soup need some more seasoning, and the tea was a bit watery....moreover, I was very excited to eat the duck, however my duck was a bit chewy and bony. There were instances where I was biting into bone and chewey ligaments. However, the service was 10/10, but I believe that some of the options here are hit or miss.
author: Connor L.

description: This place is the worse! The food was past nasty!  Actually nasty food would have tasted better. It's a tourist trap design to take your money. The bathroom opens into the main dining area...imagine the smells coming out from there while dining. The food was served cold and half cooked. DON'T GO NEAR THIS PLACE!
author: Eunice G.

description: Oh bad. Came here for a quick late lunch, and really  regretted not checking Yelp first. First, they didn't get my order right ... I like everything so it wasn't the worst thing; but and then the food came...The skin of the short ribs was hot, but the inside was really cold, I only took a bite out of one. When I told the waiter he got upset and said it was already on my bill so he can wrap it up, but I have to pay. I said no problem, I'm just sure they were reheated. Long story short, bad food, poor service, no go.
author: Alexandra L B.

description: We ordered appetizer sampler and it was surprisingly very delicious. Spring roll, pan fried dumpling and calamari was all gone in less than 5 minutes. We also ordered Tsing Tao beer and it paired perfectly with appetizer sampler. Must try sampler if you want variety of food to try. Waiters are not very attentive and service is a bit slow.
author: Diba T.

description: Came here for the first time with my mom, she wanted some good Chinese food... this is definitely not the place to go for that. It was not authentic Chinese food. We tried the shrimp fried rice and the hot and sour soup. Both dishes were very bland. The service here is extremely slow as well. It took 20 minutes before we were served tea and another 10 mins, so 30 mins Total before they even took our order. The servers took payment very quickly though
author: Jennifer P.

description: If you're looking for a restaurant with good service, this one might not be your best choice. The decor is very authentic and the food was not bad, however it was hard to eat while smelling the giant fish tank next to us.
author: Scott L.

description: I would have loved to comment on the food at Far East cafe. Especially since they had a sign in the window boasting about being one of the top restaurants in San Fran (at some point in time) but I never had the opportunity for that since I never got to order. After walking in and being seated right away the experience was awful from that point on. Waited 5 min before having to ask someone for water and teas we then waited another 10 min with no service. That's 15 min with no waiter or waitress identifying themselves, saying that would be with us in a minute. Noting. When I arrived the lady behind me was complaining and I thought she was obnoxious. But after being there for 15 min and watching the train wreck I understood.
author: Joseph S.

description: Yo this place fucking sucks, the waiters are rude, the food is fucking disgusting and pricey, im writing this review so that I will save you from wasting your money and ending up dissapointed
author: Carlos G.

description: Old school 1970's style Chinese food is still alive! Outside of a few similarly nostalgic restaurants in New York City, Far East Cafe joins the Chinese Food Historic Preservation Society I am making up right now, right here. Private rooms behind Chinese decorated curtains open to large happy ending sized tables of a different kind. A massive menu of traditional Americanized Chinese dishes promises to deliver incredibly flavorful dishes. Portions are larger than expected and advertised, and the quality of the food is top shelf. Decorated like an old Chinese casino like room. Wide open, dark, large tables, almost factory. Slightly cold (not in temperature). There is a vintage bar with an amazing chandelier hanging from above. The only thing missing are the smiles from the wait staff and cool merch to let people know I ate at Far East Cafe. The wait staff are all named Peter, Jim, and other names I don't know are real. Who knows really. Anywho, excellent meals. Great timing from order to delivery. Walk ins are welcomed but the room does fill up quickly. Amazing taste experience. Strongly recommend Far East Cafe for corporate parties, family events, and any other event to host your party.
author: Marc B.

description: The worst Dim Sum place we've ever been to! Terrible service and disaster food. They serve Shaomai with frozen inside, and disgusting Shrimp dumpling!
author: Emma F.

description: So mediocre it hurts. Don't waste you're time with this tourist trap. Food was not fresh and overpriced. Avoid if you can!
author: Liz Z.

description: Worst service ever . The staff kept us waiting for 30 minutes with no help, then helped asian people that came in 10 min after us right away . As we sat no one came by to get our drinks whatsoever , keep in mind it wasnt very busy at all. No waiter wanted to help us , no matter how many times we asked. When we finally got a waiter , the waiter was rude to us and said WE had to wait approx 30-40 min for our food to be ready..YET other people that came in after already had their food .  I smell discrimination against hispanics /whites. Just because we are not asian doesnt mean we are paying customers or humans. NO WONDER a white man was yelling at the staff when we came in . He probably went through the same situation with his family. Take your money and tips elsewhere .
author: Jackie M.

description: Had lunch with coworker here. Delicious. Beautiful inside and yummy food. Mongolian beef plate is huge! Pork buns are delicious and have a hint of sweetness, pot stickers were great! Definitely recommend.
author: Cory D.

description: Good Chinese food in china town!  The restaurant is like what you would find in China!  The food was good typical Chinese food.  The menu is big and the portions are big too.  The chicken corn soup was excellent with some soy sauce!  Service is good too!
author: Abbas B.

description: A classic! My main criteria for China town is  easy, the food must be good and this place doesn't disappoint.  We had great steamed fish and pressed duck. Lovely vintage setting. The chandeliers are grand & beautiful & the bar looked like it was from an old movie set. There are murals on the walls and private booths that are no longer in use. Service was accommodating. I would definitely come back. A perfect place for history buffs who like great food! And there was a city meeting going on upstairs complete with police officers! If this place is good enough for the city of San Francisco, it's good enough for me!
author: Shelly S.

description: The food was just a cut above average, and the service didn't fare so well either. However the place is very nostalgic and has a Kung Fu Movie appeal.
author: Israel G.

description: This place was delicious. The service and food was excellent and hardly any waiting. Order food as if your feeding 2 adults. We were a party of 4 and ordered 4 plates and that was plenty.
author: A. S.

description:
Not even sub par. Just convenient. AVOID if you can!

Expensive dim sum ($6/plate) and dinner plates($15-20). The portions are half what I expected them to be- not a true Chinese restaurant. 

But... Their tea is good.
author: Tina N.

description: Horrible service very unfriendly servers , food was mediocre .. I definitely suggest going somewhere else !! Plenty of options here in Chinatown .
author: Amy H.

description:
Please believe the terrible reviews :(

My family took my sister here for her 21st birthday. Mind you she has a disorder which disables her to go out and have fun on her own so tonight was supposed to be fulfilled with great food. We also made a reservation for a private booth, so we thought it would be a delightful treat.

Once we got into our "booth" it's literally a table with a wooden box around it with a curtain as the entryway. The walls are full of graffiti and looks so ghetto. I guess the atmosphere should have been a telltale sign that the food isn't so good either.

We ordered 8 dishes: Barbeque pork wonton soup, fried calamari, honey walnut prawns, clams with black bean sauce, Peking spareribs, sautéed snow peas in garlic sauce, half a roast duck, and beef broccoli pan fried noodles. 

The soup was lukewarm and the bbq pork was hard as a rock. Literally- it hurt my dads teeth. I didn't bother eating it. The fried calamari is also hard and 90% breading. The honey walnut prawns was probably the only edible item here, aside from the snow peas. The clams with black bean sauce was more like celery with black bean sauce. It was also extremely fishy. The Peking spareribs was mostly fat and was super sour. The roast duck isn't your normal roast duck. They claimed it was crispy and it was soggy. It was also served in an overspiced black sauce. Lastly, the pan fried noodles was gloppy and tasted strange. It was DISGUSTING.
Everything here was unappetizing and disappointing.

Now the night my sister is supposed to have fun, is ruined by this ridiculous restaurant. We have to plan another night in order to accommodate what we experienced here. We've had far better Chinese food for a quarter of the price in other places of San Francisco. 

It ruined our night, so please believe me so it doesn't ruin yours.
author: Nina I.

description:
Quite a spacious chinese restaurant. Main level, theres a bar and smaller size eating area. when you go upstairs, of course it provided way more tables than the lower section of the restaurant. 

Since its in chinatown, parking can be quite difficult

I got invited for a big event at this place. It was like 9 or 10 course meal was included for this annual event. Before they brought the food, didnt like that the plates the restaurant provided look greasy in some way. And the chopsticks felt kinda greasy/sticky.

Roasted pork....first thing that came before they gave out the all the main courses. It was cold when they gave this dish to each table. The rest of the food came out warm. each table had were fish, soup, some cold appetizer, chicken and cracker, walnut & shrimp...just to name a few. Most of the food that i had were what i was familiar with at wedding reception. I though the foods were tasty and had flavor. Its your typical average chinese food
author: Julie N.

description:
Pros: The restaurant is very big so there is plenty of seating! The service is pretty decent and there are two restrooms. The food is pretty average, nothing too mind blowing. Though I am guilty of ordering their pre-set menu meal because I was lazy to pick something. The food is pretty Americanize Chinese food about a half step higher than Panda Express. The quantity of food was pretty good so at least I was full!

Cons: For the quality of food, the price is a bit too high. The shrimp in the fried rice was literally tasteless as if recently defrosted from the frozen section. 

Overall: For a restaurant in Chinatown, I expected something more authentic and better. Would most likely not come back.
author: Timothy Y.

description: Staff was rude and tried to rush me out when I had barely begun eating. Lo Mein was nasty. Definitely find something else.
author: Rachel P.

description:
DISGUSTING. Avoid at all cost!!!!
This was my first time in San Francisco! I wanted to go to china town so bad. This was the first restaurant we tried I was so excited.

But the food was mediocre and nasty.

The appetizers were cold and tasteless. The sauce was gross, the only good thing was the tea.

They gave us paper on our dim sum. Check my photos posted. The food was gross and the server was sketchy. 

After taking an eternity he finally brought it. He brought half of the order out at a time..we couldn't even finish it. He literally dropped the plates off and was on his way.

The place was nice but service was awful!

When he dropped off the check he didn't say a word yet assumed the change was for him. No dude. You don't deserve a tip.
author: Veronica B.

description:
Food is decent but service is absurdly abysmal. Ordered a few dishes of dim sum. Sat there for 90 minutes and only received 4 of the 7 dishes we ordered. When we inquired with the waiter, he was surly and walked off saying it would be at least another 20 minutes. We sat around for another 20 minutes and gave up on this horrible overpriced place.

To top it off, the waiter tried to charge us for dishes we didn't even order and was only satisfactorily resolved after an argument with the owner and the waiter. 

Move on. Don't let the decor fool you. Many other places to eat with better food and staff that actually appreciates their customers.
author: Vince F.

description: Surprisingly good experience for a place with such weirdly terrible reviews. I never once saw any of the negatives mentioned in any of them. It's certainly not the best place I've ever tried, but it was still damn good.
author: Chris W.

description:
I'm visiting San Francisco with my brother who lived here years ago and visits at least annually.  We attempted to visit his favorite Chinese restaurant but it was closed so we walked to Far East Cafe.  I'm from the east coast, a DC suburban where the Chinese food, in my opinion, is just okay.  Far East was great.

We shared an appetizer of dumplings; the best I've ever had.  They were large, served hot and didn't taste mushy.   

For an entree, we shared Mongolian Beef.  The meat was very tender and the seasoning was perfect.  It also was not too spicy for a wimp like me.

I recommend this place.
author: Sharon F.

description: Nostalgic!  Excellent service.  100% Cantonese.  From fresh seafood to original chop suey it's all good here.  I don't they have made changes on the decor since WWII.  Loved it!
author: Mike W.

description:
To be fair: I was here for a small set banquet meal ordered by extended family. It was not a full banquet, plus it was ordered to be ridiculously healthy and with too many veggies, so I can only comment on the dishes that were ordered.

First was the crispy pork belly. There were exactly 10 pieces for 10 of us. This was good, but only a small appetizer.
Next was the typical asian seafood soup. It was alright.
Next was a huge platter of Hainan Chicken. This was also just alright.
Next was sweet and sour chicken. I dont like s&s chicken so I am no judge of it.
Lastly were two veggie dishes that were quite frankly what I would cook at home and what I cook at home is a mix and mash of tasteless veggies. It was a mix of bean sprouts, broccoli, and mushrooms. While its alright as sustenance, its not very exciting.

Parking is street parking as this is Chinatown. Also there IS NO ELEVATOR. So if you have a banquet on the top floor like we did and you have old people. You're gonna have a bad time.

Otherwise, they have tables on the bottom floor so you should be fine not having to go upstairs.

I pretty much just had a terrible meal cause all the old people can't/won't eat the good stuff :(
I wish we could have gotten dimsum.
author: Andrew S.

description:
First off, you have to understand this restaurant for what it is: it's a very old restaurant in a very old building with some wonderful architecture and provides a glimpse at what restaurants in Chinatown were like in the 1950s or prior. That is, to me, worth the price of admission of dining here at least once. You get to see some stunningly grand interior architecture and an approach to restaurants that is seldom seen any more but was crucial to formulating what dining out is to America and especially to how Chinese food was viewed up to at least the 1980s when the dreadful trend of these strip-mall take-out places cropped up. At a time, if you lived in a city with a Chinatown (yes, yes, all the more so if you are Jewish) a pilgrimage to one of that Chinatown's Chinese restaurants was a treat looked forward to and helped formulate how Chinese-American food became important in America. Also, many of the dishes long associated with Chinese cuisine more or less originated in restaurants like this one and not in some far-away kitchen in Shanghai during the Yuan Dynasty. 

So, a few notes insofar as getting the best experience of Far East Café:

--It's a seafood restaurant, a Cantonese seafood restaurant. It built its local repute on its Cantonese seafood, but now it does everything under the sun, including fixed-price banquets and the like. Stick to the Cantonese seafood dishes. Lobster with ginger, pan-fried sole fish, clams with black bean sauce and nearly anything they do with prawns should be quite good. If they have something like General Tso's chicken on the menu  . . . really? You're going to order Americanized Chinese you can get anywhere here? Don't. Mu-shu dishes they in general do well and pork dishes, especially ribs, they are prone to burning. Don't ask me why, I don't know, but they seem not aware of how long to leave the pig in the oven. Stick to mostly seafood dishes. And order the mustard greens with garlic sauce, too. It's a perfect vegetable for a traditional Cantonese seafood meal. 

--They're in a weird place in terms of patrons: they do get tourists here off the street and they get families who have been coming for years and years, most of whom are Chinese. What they don't seem to get is many non-Chinese locals. So, the attitude of the waitstaff is either a) you speak Cantonese and we can talk fine or b) I will never see you again and you don't speak Cantonese so I'll try but have learned tourists tip poorly and that's that. I mean, I cannot speak for them, but this is my summation of what's up with the "rude" staff, as others have called them. Also, in Chinese restaurants the waitstaff typically is not as charming and chatty as American waitstaff. That goes for this Chinatown, most Chinatowns, and certainly China itself. Most Chinese families eat out as an extended family, so you're catching up with the aunties and all and no one has the inclination to talk much with the waiter. 

--Their tea is very, very, good. Excellent old-fashioned oolong tea. 

--It's true, they really don't like you moving the furniture around. Even a chair. Better not scoot a chair over unless it's the one you're sitting in. I think this is because everything here is old and the staff has been admonished they might (or a patron might) break something. 

--The quality of food can vary a lot, I'll admit. Try to come early on a weeknight and pray no one's elderly uncle is having his birthday party here and thus consuming the staff's attentions. If you're on a weeknight and early, should get good food. And it's worth trying at least once. They're not real keen on you wandering around taking photos of the interior either, but try at least to look at it for yourself. It's really a grand example of something frozen in time.
author: Mike W.

description: This is one of the oldest buildings in Chinatown with decor to match! I've been here a few times for weddings/events because of the large space upstairs, but it is definitely not because of the food.
author: Colleen L.

description:
This is a nostalgic, old time San Francisco Chinatown restaurant. Décor is terrific, with hanging lanterns, murals on the wall, and curtained booths. I used to come here decades ago after late nights partying. Then you could actually find a parking space on the street. 

Decided to revisit this place yesterday. The hostess said the booths were unavailable. No one was in them, so I don't know what makes them "available", even though we requested to be seated in one.

Food was OK and we ate it all, including the appetizer which appeared at the end of the meal.

Service, however, was terrible. I know I won't get fawning service at a Chinese restaurant. I'm very experienced with gruff, abrupt, and taciturn Chinese servers. They take your order, bring you your food, and never inquire about how your day is going.  Fine with me. .However, asking for water five times is quite unreasonable.
author: franny s.

description: Food ok, but Service was Underground. They shoutet at me, when i explained why they will not receive an tip. Keep Out.
author: Heiko B.

description: Food was really good, service was kind of strange.  We were seated in one of the private dining rooms. The waiter came in right when we sat and asked what we wanted.  We ordered drinks and an appetizer.  When he came back to take the rest of our order he only took mine. Not my husbands or sons.  We did catch him and gave the rest of the order. Then another waiter came in to take our order and then another.  When the food did come out, it was only one dish at a time with long wait periods.. All in all I would go back, Mongolian beef was delicious!!
author: Pam H.

description:
The fortune inside my cookie said, "You will do something different today". Well here it is... I RARELY write one star reviews... but I rarely leave a restaurant upset.

The food may have been fine... I could tell you more if we had gotten to taste more than two dim sum dishes. I only ordered two to begin with because my wife had gone to the restroom and the server came over while she was gone from the table. I was waiting for her to return to see what she wanted. When she returned, I visited the restroom myself. Just about the time I returned, the server brought our crispy spring rolls and chow mein, both vegetarian. After that he whizzed past, around and behind our table taking other orders and checking on other tables, but we sat ignored... for twenty minutes. My wife and I wondered whether we did something offensive.

Another server finally asked to clear our empty plates and we asked him for our check, which he brought. We never had any more contact with our server. 

I am usually fairly forgiving for bad service and it takes a lot for a restaurant to upset me, but I was upset enough that, we had planned to spend more time in Chinatown, but we just left Chinatown altogether. If I am ever in San Francisco again, I'll go back to Chinatown, but I'll avoid the Far East.
author: Mark S.

description: This place is in the heart of China Town and only a short walk from a very reasonable parking garage on Sutter St. We had to wait about 10 minutes for a table even though it looked quite empty. The hostess was civil but definitely not friendly. Our waiter was horrible. He barely looked at us and was very distracted. Two of our dishes never came and we had to ask another waiter to help us and he immediately came back with the food which tells me it was just sitting there. Over all the food was good but nothing extraordinary. Well actually the pork spareribs were very tasty. The other issue I had with this place is how loud it was. Sound seemed to reverberate. Oh well. We did manage to enjoy ourselves and did not leave unhappy just not impressed.
author: Kerry B.

description:
If I could put 0.5 star, I will. There were lots of open tables and servers, but the receptionist told us to wait 15 to 20 minutes     
When we sit, we wanted to order dim sum, then the waiter suggested we order food from lunch menu to avoid another 20 minutes waiting, so we ordered chowmein and fried rice plus a roasted duck. Then the waiter said that's enough when we still wanted more. We also asked cold water but he said it's too cold and refused to give us water, we had to tell him that we don't mind at all, and we still had to remind him after food were served. 
Fried rice had no tastes; noodles were too greasy; duck was over cooked and turned black. 
Will NEVER come back or recommend it to anyone.
author: Y C.

description:
It was honestly.... Alright. 


Food takes a long time to come out, and the quality is a bit lacking. First time I had a meal where I was full, but dissatisfied. The service was good though, and the wait staff are very polite, which is why I'm giving them two stars. Overall experience, is just okay. If you're exploring the Chinatown area, I'd highly recommend to search a little further...
author: Mark K.

description: Worst customer service! Manager/owner has poor attitude and food was about she same quality as her attitude. We didn't care for a dish tried to exchange it for something else and the manager said we should have never ordered it. I will never come back and I recommend you don't either. Look else where.
author: Carlee C.

description:
This restaurant came at the recommendation of a local SF Foodie and they should be fired from their job.

Their food was average and nothing great.  
The worst was when I was done with my meal and the waiter insisted for a tip. (Tacky Tacky Tacky) !!!

Don't waste your time here, go to "House of Nanking" down the street on Keary & Jackson.
author: Charlie B.

description:
OMG I wrote my review and gave this place a 4 star until I realized it was for the wrong place! So deleted that and now here's my "real" review for this place, the pictures are for a different review, can't seem to figure out how to delete them so please disregard pics!!

Walking in Chinatown we wanted to find a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant for lunch. I loooove me some hole in the walls BUT My bad I didn't use my yelp app before walking into this place.

Customer service....let's just say there was none(until the very end). Everyone seemed like they hated being there. Decided on some dim sum for us four, nothing was good. Food was below average, bland and overpriced. 

And then.....I found a worm in our Chinese broccoli. I totally understand these things happen, especially with veggies. We were not grossed out about it but wanted to bring it to their attention. Flagged the waiter down, showed him what I found, he apologized and went back to the kitchen. Our main waiter comes out.....brace yourself folks....., instead of just apologizing he said "it's vegetable bug, these things happen. it's not like it's a cockroach or something like that." 

WHAT THE MOTHER EFFF BS!!! He has got to be joking! Our jaws nearly hit the floor. He literally stood there for at least 3-5 mins trying to justify it in front of other patrons sitting right next to us! We couldn't believe it. He even said "it's organic." Whatttt?!?!My best friends boyfriend finally had it and said "Just say sorry and walk away!" 

So he walked away to the back. I don't know why I did what I did next but I started to pick at the leaves of the broccoli and found more worms!!!!! And that was just the second layer of leaves!!!! So now we're disgusted. It was fatter than the first one I found! EPIC FAIL OF ALL TIMES!!!

With all this said and done, the reason for my 2 stars instead of 1 is because the waiter  did finally realized he was wrong. He comped our entire bill(over $50) and came out to apologized. I definitely understand that he was not the cook or prep cook in the kitchen, but how he handled the situation was unacceptable. We appreciated him realizing his fault, still gave a $20 tip and went on with our day. Next time please just say " sorry". That's it, less is more! I really hate to leave such a low rating but I needed to put in my 2 cents!
author: Tuyet N.

description:
Drove to San Francisco with the hubby and in-laws to eat at Far East. Hubby and FIL always talked about there food and I finally told them to take me since they always raved about it. 

We ordered the wonton soup, tomato beef, pork fried rice and lemon chicken. I thought the wonton soup was really good,  probably one of the best I have ever had. They had big chunks of shrimp which I love. The lemon chicken was also really good. Chicken was nicely fried with a nice light lemon sauce. The rest was ehh. It tasted like any other Chinese restaurant. 

I really liked the wonton soup but my hubby and in-laws did not like it all. They kept saying that they changed the recipe and it was their least favorite but I really enjoyed it. 

Not sure if I'll drive to SF for this but if I was in the area I'll stop for some soup.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Been coming here for about 15 years, and the last couple of times  I was here it wasn't that good, but I keep forgetting about the previous times. Came here again and it was the last time. Slowest service in a Chinese restaurant I ever had. Food was not horrible, but just fair, which is why they did not get one star. They been here 100 years, but have not progressed with the times. Too many great restaurants in China town, I would pass on this one.
author: Frankie W.

description:
Stay far far away from this place! The food is awful and the service is even worse. From the moment you come in there is a mute protest in your body that says, "get out of here"

First they got us the grossest most disgusting beer ever. 

Second they go s our order backwards: the soup came after the main course. When we complained the waiter got angry and said, "don't talk to me, I'm just getting your order from the kitchen"

Stay away. Stay far far away.
author: Adil Yousuf B.

description: For an authentic china town experience you won't need to go to far to find the Far Easy Cafe. The food was amazing but the service was less than customer friendly. If this place could invest as much as they do in their food quality, into the customer service side it would have been a top notch establishment.
author: Mike W.

description: Overall not bad, I got the sweet and sour chicken and my boyfriend had the duck. My chicken was good, a bit too much sauce for me but it was still good. My boyfriend did not enjoy the duck at all, he's had better before. Unfortunately that night I felt sick and ended up with food poisoning. I can't 100% say it was this restaurant but this was the only time my boyfriend and I had not eaten the same thing and he is perfectly fine, so I'm assuming it was this.
author: Lydia K.

description: Was walking through Chinatown with a colleague and decided to stop and eat here.  We asked to sit in a booth which was a small private room that could only fit the round table and about 6 chairs and curtain if you really wanted some privacy.  It felt a little creepy that every time a server walked by they would look into our booth.  The service was good though since they were always checking if we needed anything.  I don't eat Chinese often so I'm never really sure what's good.  I got the sweet and sour chicken.  It tasted alright, but eventually got sick of it.  I guess my stomach just wasn't feeling it.
author: Scott C.

description: I felt the food had a good taste and the service was mediocre. A bit over priced and the wait staff was not very attentive with refills, etc. (The lady at reception was so sweet and charged our cell phone for us.) However, my boyfriend and I felt extremely bloated and dehydrated after our visit. Most likely the MSG! Wouldn't come again but not completely disappointed.
author: Elaine C.

description:
My journey to the far east in sf!  Very good.  We took a nice cruise out to chinatown and found this place.

Soup dumplings were delicious.  Salt & pepper chicken wings were tasty.  Green beens were on point.  Potstickers were overfilled and moist.

Definitely ask for the Dim Sum menu - which you can get anytime.
author: Sherry A.

description:
Just had a great meal with friends. General Pow's Chicken was to die for. Best meal on the menu!!
Love your work Joe
author: Rob H.

description: This place is by far the best in china town ! Beautiful inside, the staff is very kind and made us feel very welcomed . Kathy the best bartender by far, very friendly and attentive. Best Mai tai I have ever had!! The food is amazing!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: IThis is the worst Chinses food I ate in a long long time. For $20 it was suppose to be pan fried sole. Instead it was some frozen deep fried poo. I cannot believe this place is in business. I pity the poor tourist who drop in here by mistake.
author: Abraham W.

description: We came in early and worried at their three star rating but the courteousness of the staff was very inviting, yet we should have skipped this place. To begin with the tea tasted as if the same tea bag had been used all day thus drained of any flavor. The soup was tasteless equal to the tea with terribly made dumplings, as if the dough was squeezed in an angry fist after stuffing it with only the entrails of a pig for content. The orange chicken was hard and chewy, the rest isn't worth mentioning. Management and cooks need refresher courses and cleaning crew need to attend to decades of dust on beautiful light fixtures.
author: Alain G.

description: Absolutely terrible by any standard or measure.  Ordered the "daily dinner special for 2".  About $20 pp. included egg drop soup -/ tasted like pure water-- no flavor whatsoever.  Terrible.  Really didn't know you could screw this up! Beef and broccoli was greasy.  Peking duck was burnt/ dry/ inedible.  Fortune cookie was adequate. As I departed, I ran into a group of 8 and when they asked if it was any good, I felt obligated to tell them this was THE WORST Chinese dinner ...ever.  And this was Chinatown in San Francisco!!! Can't imagine how these guys stay in business.
author: Gwen B.

description:
It was a bad mistake not to yelp this place before I stepped in. Someone recommended it to me. 

This place is the most over priced Chinese food for the quality.

I ordered the "roasted pork and oyster" clay pot. When it arrived, there was so much tofu and I didn't see any pork, thinking it was the wrong dish. It had 2 small pieces of pork (not the pork belly that the server confirmed before I placed the order). The measly two tiny pieces of pork tasted spoiled. It was disgusting. I didn't finished the rest. It costed $15.50 for that dish.

The "tender greens and mushroom", also $15.50, was bland and light. It was mediocre. 

This has to the be the most overpriced crappy Chinese meal I've had. Even Panda Express would've been better. Such a tourist trap. Avoid this place. Plenty of other good Chinese food around.
author: Vanae W.

description: Absolute worst hostess, asked for curtain room and was told it's only for reservations, then she proceeded to seat other walk-ins there. Food was average at best, zero atmosphere. I used to come often, will be my last time here. I'll be sure to let my co-workers know so they'll stop coming for lunch too.
author: David T.

description: Worst yang chow fried rice.  Did not know if it was rice I am eating.  All their other dishes taste the same.
author: Danny S.

description:
My one star review is based only on their customer service because we didn't eat their food, so cannot review that, but here is why:

When we walked in, a hostess asked us how many people and we said 5, she promptly brought us to a large table with more than 5 seats. We needed to move a chair to place a high chair, so we moved a chair to the next table. A waiter with black glasses then came up to us and asked us why we were moving the chair and that we can't move it there and took the chair we moved away. The same waiter brought us a kettle of tea, dumping it on the table and said "here drink some tea" in a very rude manner (All this in cantonese).

We felt he was extremely rude, and didn't like his attitude at all, so we got up and left. There are far more better places to eat than then this place.
author: Melissa O.

description:
Today while having a late lunch at the Far East Cafe our ears were assaulted by the tirade of a customer who was mad because the market price of his crab was $45 and that the crab was terrible, but instead of complaining, he ate the whole thing... Because he doesn't waste food... He was threatening the waiter with a bad Yelp review if he didn't take less money for the crab... I'm pretty sure that's not what Yelp is for. So if you see a review from this customer, please take it with a grain of salt... I would... 
Now my review:
I have never been disappointed by the food at Far East Cafe. The General Chaus Chicken was amazing. My only complaint is they were out of my favorite sesame balls... I will surely be back the next time I'm here.
author: Kellee A.

description:
Forgot about this one when I went to SF.

This was the closest restaurant from where we were dropped off during the tour so hunger was the only reason to stop by.

Atmosphere is old time - Americanized Chinese restaurant.

Modern small bar at the entrance.

Lunch was so so - not very Asian - more like Americanized 1950's type dishes - egg foo yung which does not exist in real Chinese restaurants...

A bit oily, salty and tasteless.

I would skip this place even though the prices are low.
author: Pat K.

description: Our second visit here after 4 and a half years. We split a black mushroom and tofu dish and another mixed veggies one also with tofu, I think. The dishes tasted pretty similar. Was kind of disappointed that rice was extra/separate but we only ordered one bowl anyway.
author: Tyjen C.

description:
Poor service. Food was average. We had to wait a very long time to get our food, and the waiter was dismissive of us. 

Not the worst place to dine but I would never return again or recommend.
author: Madison L.

description:
Pretty bad food. Bad waiter. Bad time

I wasnt too excited to check this place out seeing the other reviews. Came with family and got a private booth which ended up doing more good than bad. My mom gives no fucks so she hollered and waved a waiter down. He finally took our order.
The crab meat noodle soup was easily the worst thing to ever meet my taste buds. But then i ordered some Walnut shrimp and holy fuck were they great. 10/10. Theyre what brought this review from 1 to 2 star. 
Dont bother coming
author: Aldo A.

description:
Sandy and I woke up in the city this past Saturday with very little time until we had to head back home. Since we were staying at the Grand Hyatt, which is located right next to Chinatown, she wanted to grab a few pastries at Golden Gate Bakery, so we thought it would be a good idea to find a place to sit down and grab lunch in the area. 

We walked by Far East Cafe and noticed a ton of people inside. I mean, why would so many people dine at a sh*tty restaurant, right? Well, our hunch was wrong and we were morbidly disappointed. 

SERVICE: I just can't get used to the typical Chinese restaurant ran by old school Chinese people. Far East Cafe's service is terrible. Absolutely atrocious. When we informed our server about a dead fly in my cup, he didn't say a word. No apology. Not even a nod to acknowledge how disgusting it was. He just grabbed a cup from the table next to us, sat it in front of me and zipped off. Sandy tried getting his attention several times and he just looked at her and walked away. I was like WTF? What a douche. 

FRIED GREEN BEANS ~ 2 stars: These were pretty terrible. I just can't understand how you can even screw these up. There wasn't any flavor, the sauce it was sitting in was pointless and the texture was all off. The worst part is that this was the best dish we had, which speaks volumes about how terrible the rest of the food was. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=-JHOvnaZ7e3mr81AXQsC4Q&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

POTSTICKERS ~ 1 star: Terrible. Enough said. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=uUjFdmquv92vLO8PHqlwTw&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS (XLB) ~ 1 star: The worst I've ever had. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0WeEKBA_h1zRwVkty6qG6Q&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

THINLY SLICED BEEF SHANK ~ 1 star: The beef was thinly sliced and cooked well, however, the flavor was disgusting. I can't even explain what it tasted like. It was sitting on top of this bed of pickled cabbage and carrots, which was also horrendous. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gfIUvWASEROAcJ7wgrJDtA&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

HOT & SOUR SOUP ~ 3 stars: This was the ONLY thing I enjoyed at this restaurant. To be honest, it wasn't that bad at all. Yeah, I had to add a little bit of vinegar and soy sauce, but after that, it was pretty decent. I ended up downing four bowls of it, so that should say how much I liked it. I took a picture but I didn't post it only because Hot and Sour Soup is probably the least photogenic soup of all time. 

So check this out - we ordered four items from their lunch menu and a small Hot & Sour Soup. Our bill came out to $38 pre-tip. ARE YOU INSANE??? If you look closely at my pictures you'll notice the servings weren't very big at all. In fact, they were small. What really made me upset was that I was set on not leaving a tip, but Sandy insisted. She has a soft spot for people in the industry since she manages a restaurant in DT Palo Alto. Doesn't matter, she paid for the tip and a portion of the bill! HA!
author: Bruce C.

description: Ordered wonton soup, pork and oyster clay pot, clams with black bean sauce. All pretty good!
author: Weina L.

description: We asked a local and got the secret scoop: While all the tourist wait for 1and 1/2 hours at R&G lounge, we got better food without the wait. The best Pecking Duck I've had in my life!!! The place is not fancy, but the food is spectacular!!!!!. Authentic and good quality ingridients. Family friendly, and family style. The sweet and sour chicken I ordered for my kid was so good I wanted to steal it, from my own child. Big portions, good prices. If you are just looking for good food at a good price and dont care about fancy dont miss it. We will be going back before lesving SF.
author: Mayte G.

description:
Authentically poor Chinese cuisine -- Heavy on the MSG ! 

Har gow (shrimp dumplings) had thick, chewy skin. Avoid.
author: Abraham T.

description:
This cafe which is a restaurant is in the middle of SF china town and looks like a tourist trap. We went there to eat for the authentic atmosphere and were pleasantly surprised. 

Service was quick and waiters spoke decent english. The biggest surprise was the food. Tasty food cooked in traditional way. Orange chicken (not on menu, but you can order), broccoli beef etc.. all the classics are on the menu. 

Would comeback again, for sure.
author: sergey s.

description:
Stopped in here after a day of being a tourist looking for some tea and to warm up. Had the crab noodle soup, which was really good. The noodles did seem a bit overcooked. The service was spotty at best. The waitstaff was not polite or friendly at all. They took away one of my dining companions' plates before she was even finished. The restroom had graffiti on the wastebasket and there were no paper towels. 

OK at best.
author: Rene B.

description:
This place seriously doesn't even deserve 1 star. 
The food is honestly WORST than panda express. 
I could pay half of half the price at this restaurant and enjoy my panda express meal. 

First off, the service was terrible and the waitress seemed frustrated when we kept questioning  suggestions since we didn't know what each plate was. 
Spent over $60 bucks for food that we didn't even finish because it was HORRIBLE and still left hungry. We ordered roasted duck (oily and salty), spicy cashew prawns (salty and not spicy), mixed vegetables with beef (meager amount of meats and soggy vegetables and salty), flat rice noodles with vegetables (oily and salty). Overall, the food was so salty and was awful! It was such a horrid and negative experience and we honestly didn't want to pay for the food. Expensive and the food portions are so small and tastes nasty. 

NEVER EVER coming here again and they didn't even deserve the $5 tip.
author: Brenda Jiwon L.

description: Food was really good. Service slow. Recommend pot stickers and chow mein. Sweet and sour chicken and fried rice are also good
author: K W.

description: This place is complete crap, service was terrible, waiters are terrible, food took forever to come out and was not tasty or even close to good, i would never recommend this place to anyone!!!! Please don't go here.
author: Alan N.

description:
Based on the decor, this is an older place in San Francisco's Chinatown. One neat thing is that it has private booths that are partitioned by wood walls that go to the ceiling. Sadly--and this is certainly not the fault of Paddy Long's--the wood has been scored by people carving their initials into the wood. It is kind of disheartening to see that a long trend of desperate narcissists have found the need to deface the decor here in order to prop up their own egos.

But enough of that, what about the food?

Here was the day's selection:

Potstickers -- yum
Mongolian Beef -- Seemed a little heavy on scallions but was tasty.
Chicken Chow Mein -- I didn't eat any of it, but others said it was good.
Mu shu pork -- savory, well-balanced. I don't quite "get" this "Chinese Fajita" but I was constantly eating it from the plate. No plum sauce or pancakes required!
Mob poo tofu -- salty, salty, salty. I make this at home a lot and saw other Yelpers recommend it. I felt like my BP was going up as I ate it. The ingredient mix looked good otherwise though. Nice balance of ground pork, soft tofu, peas and carrots and a great--though salty--sauce.

The service was good. Very friendly and efficient. Even though we were tucked away in the walled-in booth, they still came around regularly to check on things.
author: Dave S.

description: Historic, Beautiful, a piece of old San Francisco China Town, a must when visiting! Oh and the food is spectacular!!!!!! Try the Honey Prawns with Walnut and the beef Vegetable saute, largest prawns we have ever had in the bay area! The 1 star reviews are just silly! this is what it was like in the 20's-30's Chinatown, also, you are in another country in another time here, if you were in China, cold water is never served, the servers are so polite, please keep in mind you are in the most historic Chinatown in the USA and this is one of its GEMS!
author: Randy , Michio U.

description: I have been coming to this place for years. But on my last visit, the prices were way up, and the quality of the food was down.  Usually we order a few dishes from the menu for our group. But this time we decided to order the Peking Duck Dinner, which offers several dishes for $25.95 per person. That's because the regular menu items were all about $15. It seems to me last year these dishes were about $9. Quality of the food was just okay, except for the Peking Duck, which was terrible.  It was served with bones on most of the pieces and was not tasty at all, unlike other Peking Duck we have had in the past. We went there after the Chinese New Years Parade, as is our custom, and were told the wait was one hour. A few minutes later, another group was told the wait was 1.5 hours. There were empty tables at the time. We waited and were seated in 20 minutes after we pointed to the empty tables. The wait staff was very efficient once we were seated.
author: Alan M.

description:
I dreamed a dream in time gone by,
 that this would be my Chinese place forever. 

This used to be one of my go to places in the city, especially with the theaters within walking distance (I mean, anything is in walking distance in the city, its just a matter of how determined you are). There was a time when it was actual pretty good. over time, the service got reaally slow, and now the food is just not that great.

 It got to the point one day when i look at my family and my family looked at me at the table and we were just like "why do we even come here anymore" and so we have never been back since.
author: Zachary H.

description:
My husband and I just held our wedding banquet at Far East Cafe. You might not be able to tell on the outside, but Far East has an extremely spacious second-floor. They can hold up to 64 tables= 640 guests. Which worked out for our initial guest list of 600. Fortunately, because we had picked one of the most popular dates to get married and considering that it was a holiday weekend, we were able to cut down to 46 tables. The manager is very friendly and honest, he was able to work with us on our menu which we had made quite a few changes. You cannot beat their banquet menu price listed on their website.
