Food: I was really worried about the quality of their food due to the bad reviews on Yelp. I spent every single day prior to my wedding checking Yelp for new reviews. When the day came, my guests were really satisfied with the portion and quality of the banquet food. The walnut prawns were plentiful, my guests claimed that they have never seen any restaurant gives so much. The sea cucumbers also received an honorable mention for its taste and texture. 

Service: I have to take one star away for the service. Personally I did not notice anything, but probably because I was the bride. My guests did say some of the waiters were too eager to take away their plates when they weren't even done eating. The cake also took a long time to go around.

Just some helpful info for anyone looking for a wedding venue, Far East has a "No Beer" policy, meaning you cannot bring your own for big events. You can however purchase it from them on the night of, which some of my guests did and they were fine with that. According to the manager, there has been too many incidents at the restaurant where guests drank way too much. You can still bring wine and hard liquor, but beer is just a straight no-no. They also did not have elevators, which is not too bad for guests but very inconvenient for moving everything we had to the restaurant.
author: Kheryn C.

description:
Terrible service! Do yourselves a favor and give this one a pass with some many great options around. 

Just to make my point, my wife asked for a side of buns and the waiter refused saying we could only get them by ordering an entire Pekin duck...
author: Emmanuel R.

description:
I was craving Chinese and was walking around Chinatown hoping to find a good place to scratch that itch. 

Happened to run into Far East Cafe and decided to give it a try without looking at Yelp, the gall... I know. You have a to live a little and take a chance sometimes.  Turns out I was pleasantly surprised. The decor was kitschy, touristy but I liked it.   Big chandeliers, lot of art, booths that were closed off entirely with a curtain...you could almost envision gangsters doing deals in there.

The food  came out in literally 2 minutes and was pretty good. I got to try the Kung Pao and General Cho's chicken which were both pretty good and came with white rice. They don't have lunch specials, this is not Panda Express, so don't ask.
author: Sunil R.

description:
My dogs were killing me from hiking through Lower Nob Hill, thru Union Square to get to Chinatown.  I've been a C-town visitor on too many visits to SF.  I've actually guest performed at one of the nightclubs there.  

There's something about hanging out in the lower Chinatown area on Grant Street with all of the tea shops, restaurants and bazaars.  I really wanted to check out my usual BBQ & dim sum joint on upper C-town along Stockton Street, but alas, da feet stopped at the Far East Cafe.  I actually used my Yelp app to find the closest restaurant on Grant that serves dim sum and FEC had decent reviews.

The host was dressed in a suit and seemed a bit perturbed that I asked if they were still serving dim sum as it was 2 PM.  He gave me their lunch/dinner menu.  I guess he didn't pick up on my desire to order dim sum.  He seated us in the center room.  I was intrigued with the side prohibition style era side rooms with curtains along the north & south walls of the cafe.  I have fond memories of other C-town restaurants and a French restaurant that had a similar design feature.  More on that later. 

The waiter was spot on, took the order and proceeded to deliver multiple dishes one at a time!  The first dish was their BBQ pork, followed by the potstickers and then finally the dim sum combination platter.  All were absolutely delightful.  He then presented the beef chow fun (his favorite), Kung Pao chicken, and the pièce de résistance, the Peking Duck.  Unfortunately we were 'tween lunch & dinner and they ran out of the buns.  Nonetheless, lunch was a hit.

I rounded up and gave them a four star foodie experience.  They lost me with the host's demeanor upon entrance; not offering me a dim sum menu; and the trashed men's WC upstairs.  They have a co-ed WC on the main floor which I finally noticed after paying the bill.  I'll definitely be back and will definitely remember to ask for a dim sum menu  and use my WC in my hotel room before I dine here.

Note to NB: be sure to ask for their dim sum menu!
author: Norris B.

description: Visiting from Orange County.. tried this place out of recommendation from Lyft driver. Awesome food
author: Nick M.

description: Please choose another restaurant when you're in Chinatown!   The service was terrible!  I work in a restaurant,  so I know servers live for their tips,  and would normally never think of not leaving a tip but the service was so bad we didn't leave a tip.  We never had our drink order taken,  we asked for water and he never brought it.   We ended up asking a different server for water.  The food came to each of us separately, and wasn't very good. I was facing the kitchen and when the servers would come out they would lock their eyes on the front of the restaurant and try to make it through the dining room without noticing the guests.  You really had to make an effort to get their attention.  Overall just a terrible dinner.
author: Robert L.

description: I ate here ten years ago and I couldn't wait to come back. I was kinda dissapointed. It was as if the wait staff was on their first day. If it wasnt, then I must have bothered them by asking if I could order a drink...after I ordered my dinner . I was with a small party and all of the food, including appetizers came out randomly. I was half way through my dinner by the time my drink came out.  The bbq pork fried rice was good, but the Hong Kong pan friend noodles were way too salty. I'd like to think I came here on an off night,  but I a combination of poor wait staff and mediocre food will not bring me back anytime soon.
author: David P.

description:
Husband and I visited because the joint seemed so historical. Well, the dust on the chandeliers is old enough, as is the super dated made for american menu. Our waiter had an attitude, especially after seeing the disappointment on our faces when the sizzling rice soup just sighed a little and died. The soup also had bone pieces from the ground chicken and used frozen peas and carrots. For the price I really do expect fresh veggies. Table condiments; salt, pepper, soy and sugar. No vinegar or chili oil etc.

Definitely a seriously overpriced tourist trap with bad service. The 1 star is for fairly clean bathrooms.
author: PeaJay T.

description: An absolutely perfect place to cool off and rest your  feet while walking through Chinatown.  Stop in.  Get a seat at the bar in the shade, visit with the hostess, and rest up.   You won't regret the stop!
author: Sara W.

description: Decent restaurant in Chinatown SF. Favorite dishes: chicken; believe it was orange spicy chicken and beef and broccoli. They're known for a rice dish with seafood.
author: Sarah R.

description: A place that asks/demands for a tip? How dare they. After terrible waitresses, dry food, rinsed not washed cutlery, overpriced food, i will not be back. Im sure there are better restaurants elsewhere.
author: Luis P.

description:
I don't know why we ended up at this place. My boyfriend and I usually don't go to anything with less than 4 Yelp stars lol this star rating must have gone down since September '13 : P. We were tired and hungry--I'll blame it on that!

This place is located right in Chinatown, which was a cool experience in itself. However, the actual restaurant really creeped me out. The whole private booth thing was so weird-looking to me. Our server was male and would not look at me nor my friend's sister. I don't know if it was his personal preference or a cultural thing, but it was weird not being able to comfortably order food or drinks. 

All bad decor and creepy servers aside, the food was tasty. I ordered General Tso and really enjoyed it. 

Next San Francisco trip, I will not be going back to Far East Cafe.
author: Blanca B.

description:
I was just kidding about the dog meat. I don't eat that shit. Dogs are not meant to be eaten.

What I did eat was the Far East dinner. Lots of food yo: sweet and sour soup, meaty walnut shrimp, fried rice, wonton soup, and beef and broccoli something or another. 

There's more: fried tofu topped with shrimp, vegetable lo mein, spring rolls, and a bottle of saki. Everything was tasty, but Chinese food isn't really my thing.

There are tables and booths with a curtain for privacy. 

It's a Chinatown restaurant. English is barely spoken here. The authenticity factor is right. 

Some of the Dungeness crabs looked dead in the tank.
author: David M.

description:
If I could give this place 0 stars, I would. 

We waited 20 minutes to be served. However, food came in a timely manner, about 10 minutes after we ordered (half duck, pan fried combo noodles, and chinese brocolli). The server who delivered our food asked us of we needed anything else and my husband said, "Can I have some hot sauce please?" The server LOUDLY groaned as he walked away. HELLO, if you didn't want to get us anything else, why did you ask?? RUDE AF Chinese man with glasses. How upsetting, why even ask then?! The food was mediocre, duck was served with no plum sauce AND  duck with no buns or shrimp chips, thumbs down! 

Our bill came up to $60+ and we left a $2 tip for horrible service. I just feel like why should I tip you if we waited for service and you groaned when we asked for something. THEN a different server had the audacity to say, "YOU LEFT $2." To which I responded, "I DIDN'T LIKE YOUR RUDE SERVICE. IT WAS HORRIBLE."   

Avoid this place.
author: Nina S.

description: Place looks kinda cool, so I'll throw em a few stars for that, but the food and the service are dismal. I ordered my food and received it 45 minutes ago; my boyfriend's food is no where to be found, which is ironically the same thing I can say for our waiter. My soda glass has set empty and been quickly passed over by numerous servers for the past 30 minutes. The food we did actually receive was mediocre at best. My best recommendation, go somewhere else.
author: Ashley M.

description: The food tasted OK--nothing special.  The interior looked authentic so that was impressive, which is what you we apparently were paying for.  Service was prompt and helpful when we could understand what they were saying.  There might be better tasting places in Chinatown, but the ambience was nice.
author: David S.

description: Bland,waited forever to get s table in a 1/2 empty place. My glass of wine was 1/2 the size of others. Avoid st all costs. Not a great deal either
author: Christina P.

description:
I can't believe I've forgotten to review this restaurant.  I've eaten here for decades, but only at banquets.  Given the closing of lots of larger restaurants in SF Chinatown, Far East is becoming the banquet location of choice these days.  Food and service are fine upstairs, Sound system is pretty darned good and they even have video equipment.  

I will someday have to eat dinner downstairs, especially in one of the old school private booths on the left.  Real throwback.  

I always park at Portsmouth Square and leg it in.
author: Doctor G.

description: The food was excellent.  Chicken with vegetables was great.  Portions are large,  and the experience was very good... I'll be back
author: Richard R.

description: DISGUSTING FOOD!!!!  had the bbq pork noodle soup and it was the most foul food I've ever had.  Old meat, cheap eggs noodles and broth tasted like dishwater.  Service was horrible," also.  The tea tasted like bark boiled in hot water.  Don't waste a meal or a dollar here.  Any positive review you see in here are fake!!
author: J A.

description: Awful. Bad service, worse food, lousy decor, and dirty. Shameful. We were dropped there by a Chinese taxi driver who told us he didn't like Chinese food. Should have been our first clue....
author: S. S.

description:
Food was good, nothing spectacular but decent. Prices weren't too inflated for being downtown. The chandeliers gorgeous and side rooms, quaint. Don't walk upstairs to use the bathrooms, as the carpets will scare you. They were so greasy and dirty, as I walked upstairs I was praying their kitchen was in better shape then the carpet and flooring. 

The service is what prompted this review. Once we were seated, it took 15 min to take out drink order and another 30 minutes to receive it. The waiter dumped my tea all over, used the napkins from our place settings and never returned with fresh napkins or a place setting. We also were never offered any water. All in all, it took over an hour to get our food. With all the amazing offerings in Chinatown, I would suggest trying somewhere else.
author: Vino's M.

description: Only reason I'm giving this a one star is because I won't be able to write this review. This is by far one of the worst restaurants I have came across. From the moment we walked in we were treated differently. They seated us and I kid you not it took them about an hour if not more to take our order. The worst customers service ever. They were rude and  not very attentive. The bathroom situation is horrible, and to top it off someone had bombed it and it wasn't Clean. Just when we thought things couldn't get worse. My friend found a piece of paper towel in her fried rice. Needless to say that ruined our meal. We left disgusted. We are never coming back.
author: Car L.

description: Insanely strong and delicious Mai Tai.  Kung Pao chicken was bland and disappointing.  The private booths, drinks, and location are really the best things about this restaurant.  For flavorful food, I suggest you look elsewhere.
author: Jason G.

description:
Why aren't there any good Chinese food in Chinatown?
We had a chance to visit the City last weekend and wandered the streets before deciding to take our chance at the Far East Cafe.

The private curtained booth and tall ceiling with old ornate lantern provided nostalgia to childhood visits to Chinese restaurant in the sixties.
That was the best part of this restaurant...

We ordered the fish with spicy salt.   The fish was deep fried and hot but pepper and onion condiments were cold and sparsely sprinkled on top.
Peking style spare rib was oily and too sweet and saucy.
Bok Choy with garlic was plain...and Hong Kong style fried noodle was just okay.

This restaurant reinforced my image that restaurants in SF Chinatown caters to one time tourist visitors and they are not expecting repeat customers.
Very unfortunate as it is fun to explore this beautiful city and roam through the narrow alleys of Chinatown.

And when I have craving for Chinese food just I will remind myself to hit the Millbrae-San Mateo El Camino corridor where you can find the best in the Bay Area.
author: Mark M.

description: First - We can't confirm the negative comments on their service. Very polite and friendly. The prices are reasonable for the good food quality they are serving. Recommended!
author: Chris L.

description:
I was more impressed with their antique lanterns. Food was typical tourist gruel. 
I do hope one does not view the food as 'authentic'
author: John D.

description: If I could, I would give this cafe 0 stars. I don't usually come to San Francisco, so I did not realize that this cafe catered to tourists. I wanted my mom to feel at home because she is Chinese and only likes Chinese food. When we got there, there was a wait of around 25 minutes even though there were empty tables. The tables were not cleared for a while even though there were other customers waiting. When we finally got a table, we knew what to order right away because we looked at the menu prior. However, no one came to our table even though, when we were seated, they assured us that another person would come to take our order. It just couldn't be that worker. After another 25 minutes, with no service, we just left. Our day together was ruined.
author: Emily C.

description:
When in San Fran then a visit to Chinatown is a must! I wanted to come for dinner and with a couple of friends we wandered along (well up a big hill anyway!). 

One of my dining companions had paid many visits to Chinatown before and when we passed the Far East Cafe, he reckoned this was a gem. It looked pretty nondescript from the outside but on wandering in, it turns out this wasn't the place he had been thinking of. 

We stayed anyway (stomachs rumblings) and as two of us were tourists, our companion ordered the buffet for us. I'm gluten free and when asked if our choices were gluten free, I was told yes, only corn starch is used - result :-) Also, I had the full meal with no after effects so definitely a safe for GF place here!

The food was amazing with too many dishes for us to eat! It was a shame there was so much we couldn't do justice to. There was soup, fish, chicken, vegetarian dishes -the spicy beef was gorgeous, as were the prawns in corn batter - yuuuummm! I loved the honey and walnut prawns too! Gorgeous rice with chicken and pork and veggies - would have been a tasty meal on its own.

Lovely surroundings - we sat near the back but we all thought the booths looked pretty cool, with some pretty great Chinese art on the walls and gorgeous ceiling decorations. 

Great service, lots of lovely fresh tea continually topped up. So don't judge a book by its cover like I nearly did - just dive right in :)
author: Claire L.

description: Nasty restrooms and tables but otherwise the food was good don't get the water taste it taste like the sewer.
author: Mahdison B.

description: We really enjoyed our time here! The service was great! The ambiance was great! The food was good! I believe it is an experience to remember!
author: E J.

description:
Do NOT go here unless you have a ton of spare time to waste. Maybe if you feel like going in a group & catching up on chit-chat with people you haven't seen in forever you won't mind the excessive time waiting just to give your order. Place is pretty big & we were awed by the cool chandeliers. Our waiter didn't seem to care about us & I'm pretty sure he only came by our table because we flagged him down, even after looking up at him & trying to make eye contact. We actually were not even assigned a waiter. No one ever came to our table to greet us. The guy we flagged down was just some employee walking around. 

We decided just to order dim sum since we figured it would take way too long to receive entree portions. Even the dim sum took too long to get to our table. Food was meh. A couple weird things on the menu; can't recall what they were, but I believe it was an animal I've never seen on a menu. They make a cool dish of fried rice in the shape of a yin yang; didn't order it, but there was a photo on the menu that looked cool.
author: Ashley A.

description:
This is a 1920's restaurant with really cool features like the wall art and the curtained off private rooms. Not sure if it is an original building but it sure seems like it. 

Quick Review:
1. The restaurant is really old so understand it will look and feel old. However, yes, it could use a deep clean. (This is why I gave 4 stars)
2. Most of the waiters speak limited English and do not provide the typical American service. If you have been to authentic Asian restaurants you will understand. This is not a bad thing, in case you read this as negative. 
3. Get the Peking Duck and/or Ginger crab. It's sooo good!! 

Long review: The hostess is some what friendly but everyone besides the manager seem to be extremely shy. Possibly because they speak limited English. Or at least the several times I have come I have never heard them say more than a few stumbled broken English. But that is all a part of the experience. Be patient and kind. I have had a few of the dishes but the ones that stood out was the Peking duck and wet Garlic Crab. Amazing!! I have eaten duck and crab in so many places and this is my favorite! The duck comes with sauce, fresh warm buns, and green onion. Order a side of rice since it is not included. I always request a booth since the crab is very messy. It's nice to close the curtain so the rest of the restaurant doesn't need to watch me eat like the movie scene in "Splash". The waiters do check on you often but don't really offer much, you need to express your needs instead of them initiating the conversation. Once you give a request they are very prompt. I will continue to come to this restaurant for years to come as long as they don't change their duck and crab recipe.
author: Martha R.

description:
My girl and I are from the east coast and were looking for some good Chinese food in Frisco.  We were told to go to house of Nanking.  When we got their the line was an hour wait.  We decided to travel thru Chinatown and stumbled upon Far East.

First, know that this isn't a Hakkasan of other high end Asian place.  This is just great Chinese food you eat on a Sunday night.  The service was phenomenal.  Very attentive.  

We started with the hot and sour soup.  Awesome, best I have ever had.  We split BBQ spare ribs and chicken wings for appetisers.  They were spot on.  Accompanied by great sauces.  We ordered pork fried rice and chicken with broccoli for our main meal.  They too were also spot on.

If you're looking for great food, great service, and a fun atmosphere, look no further than Far East in San franciscos Chinatown.  Also, prices are very affordable!
author: Craig A.

description:
The Far East Cafe provided a tasty lunch for us today.

 We had table service from a very serious and efficient, older waiter.  He did eventually crack a smile but it took some effort from the three of us.  He tried to steer us in the direction of ordering 3 different dishes and told us to "share" with each other.  We joked with him that we don't like to share with each other and he completely took it the wrong way and said , "that is your decision".   Then he just stood there blankly waiting for our order.  When we laughed at our own comment, he finally realized we were kidding around and then things got better.

The three dishes that we ordered were all wonderful-- we shared a combo chow mein with Hong Kong noodles, the chicken and broccoli and one of their combo soups loaded with noodles.
Our server even came back with extra broth for the soup when he noticed that we were down to just the noodles.

We parked in the Sutter/Stockton garage and walked the few blocks down Grant to get to this restaurant.  There are so many restaurants in SF--this was a good find.

In addition, the private dining booths are an interesting offering at this establishment and next time I'll make sure to ask for one.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Wow I was so sadly disappointed with the service and food. We were drawn in by the large party of chinese coming out. We figured it must be authentic and popular with such a large party eating here. 

The service was abrupt and awful. Less then a minute after we were given our menus we were asked to order, we asked for a couple mins then it was around 10 before they came back. Drinks were delivered in a timely manner, however my beer was placed before the child, while he was in the bathroom. We all ordered an individual soup, the soups came out one at a time and the first came with little bowls to share. 

My soup was so bland I could hardly eat it, I asked for hot sauce that never came. The child at the tables food came after everyone was almost finished eating. The guests next to us received the same abrupt service.

I have been in the hospitality industry for 19 years and totally get it when a server is slammed. This was not the case. This meal will go into the top 5 worst services I have ever had.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Where do I begin. 1st was served a trial size bloody mary for 7.00. Then waiter took forever to bring food. Asked for check before appetizers served. Little excursion. 28.70. NEXT
author: Renee R.

description: Was very disappointed with the roast duck wonton noodle soup - the roast duck wasn't fresh (it looked re-fried) and the wontons were sour. I told them about the wontons but they still charged me the full price.
author: Rosa C.

description:
Went here for my sister in laws dad's Annual Beneficiary Banquet which rings in the Chinese new year. 

I would say that the flavors were traditional and pleasant to my palate but the quality of the work was lacking. Meats and vegetables were cut inconsistently across most dishes and rendered some quite difficult to eat. Service was definitely good especially for the volume. 

It is hard to comment on each dish simply because I don't know what is standard and what is special for the event but suffice to say the food is fine for what you pay for. 

Overall Thoughts

I can see why they pick this venue each year but I don't see myself coming here with my friends outside of any special gatherings.
author: Eddie W.

description:
I've been to San Francisco a few times, & naturally Chinatown is always a stop. This trip I was traveling by myself, & thought I'd grab a quick bite (keep the word "quick in mind here), before starting my night.
The interior of the place is like a step back in time, which I really liked. And the tea was very good. It ENDS there.
After I had to explain a few times that it was "just one" for dinner, I was seated WAY in the back by the kitchen, & pretty much ignored  most of my time there. I started with a Hot & Sour soup, which was fine, & was brought the check a few seconds later! Multiple requests for water, from servers who seemed like they were busy, in a place that had maybe 15 people in it.
When I finally got the waiter's attention to order more food, 45 minutes had already gone by. I ordered in spite of myself, (BBQ pork & chicken/shrimp fried rice). Not visually delectable, nor taste wise. The icing on the cake was severe stomach cramps/discomfort all day today.
NEVER AGAIN.
author: Larry A.

description:
Came here craving Dim sum!
Sadly this place does not have a huge selection of Dim Sum. They have a whole bunch of different dumplings tho.  I ordered the Shark Fin and Shrimp Dumplings: do not let the name fool you, there is NO shark fin in this dumpling, believe me - i asked!

I also ordered the fried chicken, greens, and more dumplings - all the good was ok, nothing really stood out. The veggies were bland and the chicken was a bit on the dry side. Over all it was a decent meal but the for the price i don't believe it was worth it.
author: Mya M.

description:
As we were walking around Chinatown, hubby really wanted some authentic Chinese food. A very nice store owner highly recommended this place to us. When we walked in (middle of the afternoon) they were on a slight wait. The hostess was so nice and friendly, even took some pictures of us while we waited. 

The decor is amazing from the beautiful huge chandeliers, statues, artwork, it's a bit overwhelming. So much to look around and see. We did notice 90% of all the patrons dining were of Asian decent, hhmmm score! 

We only waited about ten minutes then got seated. Our waiter immediately came over to get our drink order. He was fast, efficient, and to the point. They have a huge menu and he kept coming over to get our order. Talk about wanting to turn tables quickly. Although he was a very good waiter, he was not friendly at all. 

We started with the wonton soup to share. We ordered a small and when it came out it was more than enough for two people. Yes this was great wonton soup, highly recommend it. Flavorful, good broth, the only weird thing which was no big deal was instead of green onions they put celery in it. I had never seen it made this way. Either way it was delish. 

Entree: 
I chose the Beef Mu Shu, it was good, no complaints but I have had better. Hubby chose the Egg Fou Young, he loved it. The platters are of good portion sizes. I did want steamed rice and our waiter got offended because I had the Mu Shu and he did not think the rice went with it. I told him I wanted a side order anyhow. He was not very happy. LOL strange. 

The place is big, hostess was terrific, food was good. My biggest complaint were the restrooms. After drinking so much tea, I had to use the restroom before leaving. As usual they were in bad shape. It always scares me to think if they keep the restrooms like this how does the kitchen look. Thank goodness I had already ate.

If anything walk in and get a real feel of the history and appreciate all the fine decorations.
author: MICHELLE C.

description:
I've been here twice--both times it was great. However--it's a bit dirty and dingy.

Location/Atmosphere--3/5. Location is 5/5; very easy to find in Chinatown. Atmosphere could be better; 1/5. Chandeliers are so dirty that they look like they're in a haunted house. Place in general is dirty and sticky. I didn't really mind this because I didn't experience any *personal* hygiene offenses either time I visited, but I would not be surprised to hear that people have varying experiences with this. Bathroom is gross, and there's only one that both the servers and patrons (regardless of gender) use. 

Service--4/5. Honestly both times we were here I can't complain. Everything came out as it should have, and when we had questions they were promptly and politely attended to.

Food--5/5. I went with multiple people both times I was there, and we each got a large dish to share. I like that it's family style. We had all kinds of dishes--beef, tofu, chicken, prawn, etc...all were delicious! I'm actually very surprised to read all the negative reviews here. 

Bottom Line: This place could stand a good cleaning, and a better restroom. But both times I've been here I have had no complaints, and the food has been excellent. I would go here again.
author: Kate T.

description: I usually avoid places like this (and areas of Chinatown in general) so I wasn't thrilled when my friends picked this place to eat, but I was pleasantly surprised. The food is your standard Americanized Chinese food and isn't anything to write home about, but it's also reasonably priced considering the area it's in. It would be an average rating of three-stars except the waitstaff was very attentive and not as distracted as they could have been at noon on a Saturday in one of the biggest tourist attractions in the city. The ambience is also really cool and they have some really neat authentic decor.
author: Kay P.

description:
Excellent place. After walking around in chinatown we finally saw this place. Service was great. Potskicers and spring rolls were amazing. I ordered  the general chicken and it was great. 

Greatly recommended.
author: Viviam S.

description: Oh my god this place is amazing. We went in here cause it was our anniversary and we wanted real Chinese. So we where walking around and we happen upon this place. It says it's like a banquet dining but it's awesome. But the food was so delicious when we left I couldn't move. Best Chinese food in Chinatown
author: Laudenia Z.

description: Great place, took family there on a Saturday in the afternoon. An order of fried rice is enough for 5 people, the BBQ chow mien and Chicken chow mien were really good, the Sweet and Sour prawns were amazing. Definitely put this on our regulars list. Great spring rolls and pot stickers too.
author: Toby V.

description: Just popped in here on our way to the Fishermans Wharf. All the food was excellent from the spring rolls to the fortune cookies. We had Kung Pao shrimp which was awesome. The wonton war soup was also superb. Just an overall awesome place to eat.
author: Philip A.

description: My family & I had the best egg Foo young I have ever tasted. All the food was good actually. We were seated right away  & greeted by a friendly staff. I will definitely be back.
author: Ann S.

description:
Food similar to Panda Express. Except for price and location.
Expensive for portions, and quality.
We were very hungry. Their beef with oyster sauce was very good.
Service when seemed,  adequate.
author: M.P R.

description:
A three star meal and experience that was knocked down to two stars based on the truly inattentive and disappointing service.

Our meal was perfectly adequate for Chinatown dim sum fare. There's better to be had, but considering this was the heart of tourist Grant Avenue, it was acceptable. The setting was fabulous with the old Chinatown feel of the place. There's a lot of history to be had here, and that's pretty amazing.

The service... *sigh* I mean, it's not like I expected to be waited on hand and foot, but the fact that they totally didn't heed certain requests just frustrates me. Three things come to mind: (1) I asked for the dry fried fun noodles without bean sprouts. Of course they arrived with bean sprouts. (2) We asked for three boxes for leftovers. We received two boxes. (3) We asked for change on the bill. We received no change until I went to the front and asked for our change. No, we were not leaving you a $10 tip on a $30 tab. Nice try.

All in all it was fine, but the service made it quite disappointing. I would have gone elsewhere, but this was convenient. There's better dim sum in the Sunset and Richmond.
author: Audrey J.

description: Its very good and you should go there. I went there for a wedding and the food was crazy good, the waiters kept on coming I enjoyed the night.
author: Nq V.

description: We made a reservation for 9 on a Saturday night but it was totally unnecessary because was pretty empty. We sat in the private booth which was so much fun! It felt so authentic, like we were in a restaurant in old China! The waiters were polite and gave us privacy but weren't super talkative. I ordered Hot and Sour soup and orange chicken. My friend ordered Wonton Soup and Lemon Chicken. We both had steamed rice. I absolutely loved my Hot and Sour soup. My friend thinks the Wonton soup wasn't traditional because there was both pork and shrimp in the soup. She didn't love it. Water waiter was very attentive and would check on us often. Main course took a while to come but exceeded expectations. My orange chicken was delish! It was a very light textured chicken and the sauce was really good. My friend also loved her lemon chicken. It was a thin chicken breast that they fried and cut into strips. Lemon sauce was light and not too sweet. The price of the food was on the more expensive end but what do you expect in a touristy town?
author: Catherine B.

description:
Enjoyed the decor, especially the ceiling. Felt like I was in some old town in China or something like that. Ordered Mongolian beef, Clam with black bean sauce, House special chow mien, and Spicy spareribs. I liked Mb and Ss. Clam was good too, except it tasted too fishy for me. Chow mien was the most disappointing one. Wasn't convinced that the place was one of the 100 best Chinese restaurants in the US, as the sign on the entrance door said. Prices were high for me, as well.

The worst part was their bathroom (unisex)! It didn't look dirty but the smell was atrocious! Therefore, it must have been dirty. It stank like someone urinated but not in the toilet. I seriously felt like I was going to throw up! Because of this, I will not come back. I am sure I can find a better place next time.
author: Jen B.

description:
Wanted to try this place because it's been around for so long. The place looked run down. We came here for some dim sum but decided to order very little just to get a taste of the food. We ordered pork dumpling, shrimp dumpling, and chicken wings. The food tasted like to go dim sum. It was pretty bad, would not come here for dim sum but maybe to try out their dinner dishes. The waiters were very nice, but the food was not great.

We checked out the upstairs just to see the banquet layout and it was huge and pretty nice. The stairway upstairs probably need new carpeting but it wasn't too bad. The dance floor was huge. They also have separate rooms for the VIP section/small gathering which was very nice and clean.

Will write another review if we ever come back for dinner.
author: Helen N.

description:
Exceptionally disappointing.

Szechuan Prawns tasted like they were covered in spicy ketchup and chicken curry was bland.  No option of brown rice and the meal was relatively expensive ($20 a plate). 

Manager seemed concerned over our food, but I will not be returning.

Tourist trap.
author: Justin D.

description: Love this place! Food is amazing. I especially enjoyed the duck. The service is great. Friendly, funny servers. Right in the heart of China Town. Nevermind the haters, this place is fantastic.
author: N N.

description:
The decor was sadly the high point. Some of our food came out lukewarm (shrimp fried rice, har gow) while some was reasonably fresh (salt and pepper calamari, gai lan), and one dish was in between (steamed tofu with shrimp, the outside pieces were starting to get cold but the insides were hot). 

The food was nothing special. The fried rice was disappointing. Someone commented that they'd had better from the frozen section of a grocery market. I don't disagree. 

The calamari was pretty tasty however. 

Service was slow and we had to flag down a waiter for just about anything. Basically had to stand and put on a coat to get the bill...after talking with someone and waiting 7-8 minutes.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I can't tell you how many times I've gone "exploring" and walked into somewhere looking for an authentic experience and ended up eating some not-so-delicious strange food that I'm not even completely sure is what, I think, I ordered. 

If you're walking around Chinatown looking for a place to eat, stop in. It's a great place for tourists. You'll get an authentic San Francisco Chinatown experience.
author: Claire O.

description:
Retro-cool, I loved this place.  It reminds me of my old favorite from Columbus, Ding Ho.

I was with 3 fellow conference goers who walked down from our hotel Union Square to Chinatown.  We choose Far East based off of a local recommendation.  We ordered the family style meal, which at $20 a person seemed pricy for the quantity of food.  However considering the location seemed pretty reasonable.

The service was decent and the food came out pretty fast.  The hot & sour soup was really good.  The rib appetizer that came as part of the meal was fatty and chewy like it could have been cooked longer, but that was really the only downside.  We had a chicken dish, a beef dish and a shrimp dish and all were good.  I especially liked the shrimp that came with candied walnuts.  I'd never had anything like that but the shrimp seemed well cooked and the candied walnuts gave just a right touch of sweetness.

If you're a tourist in Chinatown, I think this is a good place for dinner.
author: Laura J.

description:
so so disappointing.  How could a Chinese restaurant located in the heart of china town SF fail so badly.  We were here for Chinese new year from south bay.  We were starving so at this point it really doesn't take much to impress us but this place did not deliver.

We ordered three savory dish plus fried rice and two ha gao and two Xiu Mai  order because my sons love love dim sum.  They came back and said they can only fill one order of dim sum because they are out (4 piece of dim sum, plus 1 cabbage egg roll and 1 pork buns = $12).  the rest of the dishes came out pretty fast we finished everything and then they bring out the fried rice 20min later...that was the only good dish but maybe that's because it's the only one they freshly made everything else was pre made and sitting in there waiting to be reheated, that's what it tasted like.  

And my sons who will eat a shoe at this point ate the sad looking dim sum that they brought out and said to me mom this is really not good, I like yours better.  (mine is the frozen kind that I re-steamed from the groceries store).

So to sum it up, food bad, expensive, decoration dark and dingy, all the black booths along the wall give a shady feeling to the place, floor and bathroom is smelly and dirty.  Will not ever return here or recommended to anyone.
author: Neyu V.

description: This is a historic SF site.  The owners and staff are nice and efficient.  I came here for a fellowship dinner and the second floor was perfect.  The podium, stage, dance floor (no dancing but still, it's an option for an event) and plenty of tables and chairs.  The space is quite large and has a bar in the back.  The carpet and things are a bit dilapidated but it has some charm.
author: Chris L.

description:
I will be the first to admit that I have not had  authentic Chinese food like this before .. just what most Americans are used to at our usual take-out places.

We were in SF for my birthday and were looking for another place that had been recommended to us (Empress Of China) .. but just couldn't find it  .. and were too hungry to keep looking  ... that, and my partner was ready to kill me if I dragged him one more block.   So we came upon this place and went in.

We were greeted immediately by a red jacketed hostess and host who welcomed us and walked us into the dining room that I picture restaurants in China to look like!   Kinda dingy ... high ceilngs, very severe but oddly tacky at the same time!   Strange little curtained off private dining rooms line one side ... they look very claustrophobic to sit and eat in .. theyre like a  fitting room in a clothing store .

Friendly waiters .. though we never saw the same one more than once .. one served our drinks (full bar), one took our food order, another served our appetizer, another served our main course, another brought our check, another took our money .. it was weird.

Food was a little odd .. I got Chicken Curry and it had potatoes in it.   And my partner for the Braised Duck .. I told him it would be on the bone .. and he was OK with it ...  well it was mostly all bone and skin!   not alotta meat .. but he crunched happily away and said he enjoyed it ! 

Would I come back?  No.  But I am glad I went .. I feel like I may have gotten "the authentic Chinese experience"!
author: Anthony W.

description:
I came here for an event. I know this is china town, but am i the only one who thinks its disgusting and unsanitary to reuse the same two serving spoons?

I was able to try:
-vegetarian fried rice w/ carrots and peas - it was ok tasting but anyone could probably make a better fried rice themselves
-egg drop soup - very bland
-sweet and sour pork chop - extremely sweet and the meat was tough and dry
-popcorn fried fish - 
-walnut shrimp
-chicken w/ colorful chips

Ok i cant even finish the descriptions for the review since i cant say anything good about the food not to mention the service was unorganized and rude. Tables around us got different dishes at the same time, pretty sure the waiters forgot to serve at least one dish to a table. 

The only decent dish was probably the shrimp walnut which is hard to mess up.

 I know this place has a long history but I could care less about its history if the food is no good.
author: Michelle H.

description: Beautiful restaurant, the service is amazing. Once you enter they treat you with respect and our food was ordered quicker than we thought. However, we found a piece of hair in our beef fried rice. We told the waiter and he was kind enough to bring us a new platter. Perhaps using hair net or chef hats to prevent hair from falling to food is required? Idk. If only that didn't happen  id give it 4 stars.
author: Lee X.

description:
Ate here for lunch last week solely for their curtained booths!  Reminds me of a place in Florida when I was little.  

The salt and pepper prawns were good as was the lemon chicken.  Fried rice was nothing special.  

Service, well, what can I say.  It is very rare to fine, good chinese food and great service.  I'll keep it at that!

Apparently, you have to make reservations for these booths, so make sure to call ahead.
author: Maria S.

description: My husband and I stopped in here for Dim Sum.  It was really hot fresh food, the waiter friendly and efficient, the restaurant was clean.  I have had Dim Sum in many restaurants in several countries and this was very good.  Obviously a little touristy but what do you expect here.  The shrimp dumplings were some of the best I've ever had.  We thought it was very reasonable at $3.75 per dish.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I went to eat dinner with my wife and we order the combination  set dinner for two.
The food was far below average.  The most disappointing dish was the roasted duck.I told the waiter that we ordered roasted duck, not duck bones with no meat.
His reply was " the chef did it , not me!" The service was very poor and the food was not worth $40.
author: Winglik G.

description:
Don't be fooled by the location and exterior because hidden inside is a cafe with an upstairs for wedding banquets.  This is one of the first places known for their shark fin soup.  Although I can't say I tasted the shark fin, I did enjoy the squab, abalone, lobster, and other dishes.  

Service is fast and what you would expect for a typical Chinese restaurant.  The ambiance an decor upstairs has improved with a dance floor area and dressed up tables and chairs.  Parking is tough on the street, but there are some garages nearby within walking distance.
author: Jenny L.

description:
We stopped at this random restaurant in china town.  It has some great chandeliers, private booths and fish tanks.  

We had the jelly fish, salt and pepper calamari and stir fried string beans.  Everything was very delicious.  Dim sum menu so it was $5 per dish.

I asked our server for a mixed drink suggestion and he said "Shirley temple".  I ordered the Mai tai.  

I would go back to this place.
author: bryan h.

description:
Old school.

I wish they had the decor of this type of restaurant in Vancouver.  The majority of restaurants like this are either demolished or closed up.  The closest comparable would be Foo's Ho Ho in terms of decor, but definitely not as fancy.  Silly as it may be, I like this decor.  This is the type of environment of Chinese restaurants that I grew up in for fancy banquets and weddings.

I was here for a wedding banquet.  For those of you not familiar with this type of setting, the food is different.  Drastically different that what you would eat on a "day to day basis" at a Chinese restaurant.  Older generations of Chinese aka, my parents, consider this food to be "superior".

In all honesty, I was never a fan of this type of "banquet" food.  Even though I've eaten this stuff for like an eternity, I don't like it very much.  It's boring.  It's dull.   There's nothing wrong with it, but I don't care for the majority of the flavours, or lack thereof,  I don't like some of the ingredients, and I don't like some of the preparation.  The other comment I have about this is that it's expensive.  Why is it expensive?  Because it is all for show.  Conspicuous consumption , but almost nobody realizes it. It's a vicious cycle of the way it works with Chinese wedding banquets.  I'll spare you the details.

In the older Chinese generations and traditionalists mind, if it's "expensive", it "must taste good", because it is "expensive".  Load of crap.

Classic example is shark fin soup.  Expensive as F.U.C.  Ignoring the ethical element of this, shark fin is cartilage.  There is no flavour in cartilage.  I saw a show on the Food Channel where this so called "maitre d" was expounding on the virtues about how a shark fin with this certain shape would make a beautiful and delicious soup.

What an idiot.

The flavour comes from hours and hours of simmering pork and other bones to create a stock that is seasoned and thickened subsequently.  The shark fin adds texture only.  Nothing else.  It is tasteless.  Take the shark fin out of the soup, and it tastes exactly the same, minus that status symbol associated with it.  To me it tastes like a thickened broth of sorts.  I don't hate it nor I do find the taste to be anything near exhilarating nor satisfying.

Back to the food.

It's OK.

I'd rather eat some of the dim sum, and "normal" food to get a real feel of the place, but oh well.

Far East, you get a neutral review.

The wedding reception itself was a whole lot of fun tho!  Nothing that a couple of bottles of Macallan Scotch couldn't do to liven up the atmosphere.
author: Herman E.

description:
not a bad stop. Interesting interior and you can see that it is attractive for nighttime or once in a while activity.  Food was good. Not much different form back home chinese.  The facility could use and interior decorator and a team to provide cleaning instructions. Although not filthy - it was far from spotless. 

If you are in the mood for a quick bite and want Chinese...this is a good stop. Service is fast. food is good.
author: Bill W.

description: Drop the average age of a server below retirement and got some live crabs in the tank - current inhabitants have long passed away
author: Daniel M.

description:
"Yuck!"

With "details" being my calling card (and verbosity my cardinal sin), I thought I would do an about face, and write a 1-word-4-letter review.  But Yelp wouldn't let me off that easily, urging me to "finish" my review.  So I'm back to my old ugly self.

With our heart set on yummy dim-sum at grand old China Town in San Francisco, but rain driving us to make foolish choices, we came across this establishment.  One look inside should have been warning enough.  It's a Saturday, but half the tables were unoccupied - guests were almost outnumbered by loitering waiters.  "This is China Town - how bad can it be?" became sort of famous last words for us.  

We were promptly seated.  This place is a real throw-back - I half thought a reincarnated Bruce Lee would bound onto the scene without warning.  I mean, they had side booths that boast discreet sets of curtains for privacy.  Who knows what hanky-panky went on within back in the days?  I suppose moans of ecstasy can be drowned out by the sound of mah-jong?)  

Tea, when brought and tasted, was out-of-this-world abominable.  We seriously considered cutting our losses and beating a hasty retreat, but the Gators' game on tv in the final 4 min. held some allure for us.  we quickly ordered an assortment of dim-sum, which was the only thing they offered.  At $10, it had a sampling (usually 2 each), of some dumplings, spring roll, BBQ pork bun, siu mai, har gau and a couple of other non-descript varieties.  But compared to the crab meat soup noodle we also ordered, the dim-sum was iron-chef caliber.  This bowl of noodles did hold a few tiny pieces of crab in it, but the noodles were under-cooked, and, the soup, fishy and funny-smelling.  Plus it had absolutely no taste to it whatsoever.  Never did I think that I would ever cry out for a pinch of msg.

Well, at least the Gators won.
author: Paul L.

description: This place was terrible. The crab was 45 dollars on the bill  and came out slimy and was not able to separate from the shell.  The fried rice was also terrible and tasted burnt. STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE WHEN I COMPLAINED THEY YELLED AT ME LIKE I WAS STUPID! Worst experience we have had in San Francisco.
author: Gary D.

description: Went there for banquet. Food seems to be improving and service was good. Needs some updating but not much choice for large Chinatown party
author: Ben G.

description:
Was walking through Chinatown, drawn by the Decor. The personal was very kind and helpful. The atmosphere entertaining. 
The food however was marginal.
Ordered the veggie spring rolls and potstickers.
Then veggie fried rice had canned/frozen carrots and pees.
Kung Pao chicken was ok.
Prob wouldn't return.
author: Sacha R.

description: We did not enjoy the food one bit. We ordered the two safest things on the menu, garlic chicken and general tso's chicken. both were very poor tasting. the tso's tasted very off. the oil they used must of been filthy. it reminded me of a Chinese doughnut flavored chicken. the garlic chicken was a MSG bomb. was drinking water for hours after that. the one redeeming bit was that my wife complained and they removed the tso chicken from the bill and left her choose a steam veggie dish instead which was still subpar. the tufu had a very strange texture. seriously you can do better for the money. don't blow it here.
author: Anthony S.

description: Sesame chicken tastes like sweet and sour chicken. Chunks if gristle in every other piece if chicken. Bland Kung pao shrimp. Rice is an extra $9. This is the point where we should have walked out, but we stayed unfortunately. Rice was served 10 minutes after chicken which was then cold. Worst $50 lunch for 2 people ever.
author: Kelly S.

description: Terrible, we ordered the Peking duck, they brought a nice well cooked Perking duck to the table, cut 4 mini slices of it and returned it to the kitchen "to supposedly cut it", first time in my life they take the duck back to the kitchen instead of cutting it on sight at the table, 10 minutes later they came back with an inedible version of the duck, just bones and awfully cut, nothing good, pretty sure they swap it back at the kitchen for something else, very bad experience and worst Peking duck in my life.
author: Jordi G.

description:
Ugh, what a tourist trap. It is the closest restaurant to the Dragon gate. The place is a bit dingy but they do have the chinese decorations going for them. The food is average for a chinese food place. It isn't spectacular but it isn't horrible. Also note, the food is completely AMERICANIZED chinese food. Nothing I saw on the menu was authentic. Great for non-asians I guess. The serving sizes are ok. 

Service is terrible, waiters are quite rude.

I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.
author: John W.

description:
Best Dim Sum. Enjoyed every bite. It is more traditional Chinese food so if Panda Express is what you want, you won't find it here. Staff is awesome. Wilson the waiter is taking English as a second language and is great to talk to. 
5 stars for the food and staff. The restroom gets 1 star but when you gotta go you gotta go.
author: V S.

description: I brought my parents here for lunch. We love the bbq pork bun, crispy noodles, walnut shrimp, beef woth brocolli and the yang chow fried rice! We will definitely recommend this place.
author: Crystal P.

description:
I was pleased. I have never had dumplings or dim sum before & it was very tasty. They chow mien was yummy as well. 

The decor is very cute & I loved the lanterns & what not. It always wonderful to try new things & new foods and I'm glad this place turned out to be a great first try.
author: Vanessa X.

description: While I didn't experience "terrible" service I can see why people give this place low ratings. We didn't know who our waiter was and didn't get brought water and no one asked for our drink order. The actual food was excellent though a bit on the salty side. It was very hot and tasted fresh so no complaints there. I think the prices are average but the indoor decor could use some work. Decorations are taped on and seems cheap and dusty. Not sure what to expect from Chinatown but at least the meal hit the right spot.
author: Cleveland B.

description: Food is greasy, some bland, some overly salty and the prices are ripe off.  Their quality didn't taste fresh and the service is horrible.  If you want to have really bad Chinese food with really, really poor service this is the place eat.  You are better off going to Panda Express!
author: Jan S.

description:
A mainstay in Chinatown for many many years.  This review speaks to the food served at the red egg ginger party today held on the 2nd floor.  The food was piled high on our lunch plates.  Peking spare ribs, fried chicken drumstick, chow mein, roast pig, shrimp with bok choy, and beef and broccoli.  Typical southern Cantonese style food.  Fruit punch flowing from a punch bowl and hot coffee and tea from urns.  Hubby said the coffee was terrible.

Dirty plates cleared immediately to the point we were afraid they were going to take our plates away the minute the forks were laid down.  The women's bathrooms look like recently remodeled, and ADA compliant; but no elevator to reach the 2nd floor.  Clean bathrooms are a huge plus in any Chinese restaurant.

Carpeting on the stairs leading upstairs very old and dated.

The ground level restaurant still looks like it did when we used to come eat as kids and for large family dinners and weddings.  And the booths are still intact.
author: Shirley N.

description: The service wasn't as bad as some of the other reviews said, but the food itself was extremely subpar even for an Americanized Chinese restaurant. The pork dumplings were bland and full of unrendered fat and the schezuan shrimp was sugary sweet. The tea brought out at the beginning of the meal was nothing but hot water, and the waiter didn't bring us water until we asked twice. The higher points of the meal were the Hunan shrimp and chicken with mushrooms, both of which were average. I am giving this place the benefit of the doubt because I am a tourist, but I am sure there are better alternatives. Do not recommend.
author: Priya S.

description: Food was delicious pot stickers big and delicious service was good nice waiters friendly and polite price not bad will definitely come back again
author: Michael R.

description:
I have to confess that I feel a bit disloyal rating Far East Cafe so highly, given that I'm more than a little bit fond of Sam Wo.  But since Sam Wo is closed for renovation, one has to get one's chow fun fix *somewhere*.  

As is our usual style, we go for cheap Chinese food after leaving our club.  We've tried a few places in Chinatown that seemed like they had the right vibe, but they all felt like a few steps down from Sam Wo in food quality and ambience.

And then, a few weeks ago, after a few martinis, we stumbled into Far East Cafe.  The entry is not promising; equal parts glitz and grime.  And their name is instantly forgettable.  But once one gets past the bar and the hostess' station, you enter the dining room.  And then the magic kicks in.

I don't know how old this place is, but the dining room is pure 1930s faded glamor.  Unbelievably ornate brass lanterns festooned with colored lightbulbs hang from the high ceilings.  Old (late-19th century?) paintings of outdoor scenes grace the walls.  There's a "pagoda" type screen that separates the dining room from the front of the space.  The lighting level is *perfect*.  And along the south wall is a row of private booths with curtains for privacy; the only such restaurant in Chinatown.  You want a "Big Trouble in Little China" fix?  Here you go.

The waitstaff is straight from Central Casting ("wanted: Chinese waiter with unctuous manner and maroon vest"), ubiquitous and helpful.  The tables are spaced far enough apart so that one never feels too close to the neighboring diners.  And the chow fun?  Let's just say that it's the best that I've ever had.  And that's saying something.  

Again -- no disloyalty to Sam Wo who turn out a tasty, greasy chow fun for just $4.50.  But Far East Cafe's $8.25 chow fun is thinner, less oily, and with excellent wok-hei; that characteristic of noodles that get caramelized from having been tossed in a really hot wok.  The seasoning is flawless and the broccoli that I always order with chow fun is perfectly cooked.  

Tonight we tried Far East Cafe again and it proved that our previous experience was no fluke.  Yeah, it's unlikely that we'll ever be on first-name basis with the wait staff, but that's OK.  The faded charm of the decor and the excellence of the food more than make up for it.  

If you have an appreciation for vintage decor from the "mysterious Orient" of the mid-century and earlier (think Tretchikoff paintings, Marwal busts, Les Baxter and Martin Denny, "The World of Suzy Wong", etc.), this is one of the few places in town that still retains it.  I'd come here even if the food and service was crap, just to soak up the mood.  That the food and service are quite good cinches the deal for me.
author: Curran H.

description: Overall is say this place was disappointing not to mention dirty. Between the completely disgusting fish tank in the front, the piles of dust caked on the wooden chandeliers or the cheep Chinese paper wall decorations that were just taped on the wall I'm not sure why we stayed. The food is okay to good depending on what you get with fine prices but the service is not very good. Our waiter only came to our table twice for a drink and then food order and we never saw him again. So overall the experience is is not very good and we were bummed we even went when right down the street a couple blocks was a revolving sushi bar where the sushi revolves on little wooden boats on water that goes around the restaurant! Which looked like an awesome experience so I would recommend that cool sushi restaurant a block or two down and not this place.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: The food was good, but service terrible.  They brought us the wrong orders, then tried to convince us that what they brought was what we ordered.  We constantly had to ask for our waiter to ask about missing food.  Bathrooms were dirty too.
author: Mary O.

description: Worst dim sum that I've ever ever had.  The dumpling skins were far too thick and doughy, definitely not cooked long enough.  The meat fillings were just off tasting, and sometimes under-cooked.  One of the things that warned me not to come in was the fact that the dining area was empty when I arrived--never a good sign for a dim sum place in the middle of Chinatown during lunch time.  The only thing that was ok were the vegetable dishes, because they don't require as much skill and technique to prepare as the other dim sum dishes.  I was definitely severely disappointed and lost my appetite coming here.  I've been to a lot of good dim sum places, some of them in San Francisco, but this was not one of those places.  The only possible saving grace this place could've had was in their service, but even with an empty room, good service wasn't there.  Never coming back.
author: Christine W.

description: Maybe it is because we did not order the Chef's special. Food overall is a little salty. Great customer service. And dishes came out very quickly.
author: Tina Q.

description: If I could give it zero stars I would.  It's a disaster.  Went with reservations as there were 4 tables of 8 in our group.  Three tables were served except for ours.  Our waiter was rude and anxious and abrupt.  We were served our tea (1 teapot for 8) and soup.  The other tables got their food and we waited and waited only to see that the chef and his staff sat down to eat.  We were still waiting.  When they got up, the waiters sat down to eat.  We're still waiting.  FINALLY, we were served and four people at our table never got their rice until we were ready to leave.  The food was barely edible.  So, if you want your blood pressure to go up, eat here (or try to eat here!!!!).  HORRIBLE!
author: Marilyn R.

description:
Well I've only eaten here once, but I'm surprised the rating is as low as it is!

I came in here with my father recently and we ordered roast duck, Chinese veggies, and pan fried fish.  The duck and the fish were exceptional, and the veggies weren't bad at all.  To be completely honest, I wasn't expecting much, cause usually when I see a really nicely decorated Chinese restaurant, I'm ready for mediocre food (hey, it's been a pretty good rule of thumb thus far!).  But Far East Cafe is not only nice looking on the inside, it had really great food.

The only con for that visit was that it was really cold and it felt like the heater wasn't on.  We ate with our jackets on, which wasn't too comfy.  Not enough to take off a star, IMO.

Overall it was a great experience, and was probably the best restaurant we stumbled onto during my father's visit.
author: Catherine Y.

description: BAD experience. Food was cold and not fresh. We were a big group. There are much other better choices, watch out.
author: Letty P.

description: The service was amazing!  Lee was super friendly.  We had only planned on getting a drink, but Lee was so friendly we tried the food and loved it!
author: Jen B.

description:
My husband and I stopped here for lunch while waiting for our hotel to get our room ready.  What a nice find. 

The service was fast!  We were seated right away and drinks appeared within moments of us ordering them. We ordered our lunch and it was at our table super fast. 

We had prawns with honey walnut (ok, not real Chinese food but it's good!) and bbq pork fried rice.  We were hungry from doing the whole waiting to be on a plane and then taking transit to our hotel but the food was better than average for sure.

I'm just sad we didn't end up going back a second time during our week in SF.
author: Gina K.

description: Go ANYWHERE but here! Probably the worst Chinese restaurant I've ever been to. Got there 10 minutes before closing but they sat us at a table anyway, with a reminder that we needed to order quickly because the kitchen was closing in ten minutes. Several servers interacted with us when we first sat down and it was unclear who our server was until after we placed our order. Our server was a little strange and seemed like we were bothering him. Towards the end of the meal we needed more soda but our server was seated with the rest of the staff eating so we had to ask the hostess to get it (she was actually very nice). I got scallops with bok choy which tasted very average and looked like it had been sitting around for a loooooong time. The scallops were plentiful but tasteless. My friend had chicken curry which also was very average. Both plates were expensive and didn't come with rice. Rice was a la carte and we were reminded of that fact several times during the meal. The restaurant is obviously very old. It is dirty and dilapidated and needs a thorough cleaning. It appears that no one really cares about this place and the owner has given up. Under no circumstances should you eat here, unless of course you are desperate for food and you have had your taste buds surgically removed!!!
author: Michael G.

description:
Old school. Real old school.

Went here for lunch after a sight seeing bus tour.

The place has been open for over 90 years and it shows.

Faded murals on the walls, privacy booths were you can draw the curtain closed, cracked checker board floor tiles, ancient lanterns and chandeliers hanging from the ceiling.

Full pot of tea brought out when we were seated.

But the food. Oh, the food. Great.

Had the combination platter appetizer (spring rolls, fried wontons and calamari), the mu shu pork, Mongolian beef and the dim sum combination platter. All delicious.

With a couple of ice cold Tsingtao's. 

Fortune cookies presented with the check.
author: Gregory C.

description: Good food and good portions.  Gets pretty busy and loud but the private booths were cool!
author: Ana And Ernest M.

description: Very fast table food service, good Chinese food. No fuss, lots of vegetable options. Private booths moved it to 4 stars. Inexpensive for the amount of food.
author: Thomas M.

description: I just ate a wrostest dim sum meal I never had in my whole life.....and the dim sum here are over price too....don't come here and waste your money.
author: Andy L.

description:
As an Asian from Melbourne Australia, the food is yummy, prices were average. We ordered beef chow mien, BBQ pork fries rice, and from their dim sum menu, salt pepper calamari.. Bill came to $24. The yummiest was the salt pepper calamari. 

The place has a musty smell, dark and not very inviting, although its big. Their fortune cookies were crunchy and yummy! Waiters can't wait to get you out!
author: Sonja L.

description:
Atmosphere is great with beautiful lanterns hanging from the ceiling. There's private booths complete with privacy curtains for a more romantic meal. 
While we were dining there was dragon dancers performing upstairs. We could hear the loud drums but they never come to the dining room.  :(
Sweet & sour chicken was tasty with a nice crunch. The BBQ pork appetizer was a little sweet for my taste and the shrimp chow mein wasn't anything special.
As I was eating I realized we made the one mistake of eating in a Chinese restaurant. We picked one where all the diners were tourists, always best to eat Chinese where the Chinese eat!
author: Tamara L.

description:
The worse! I wanted to find an awesome Chinese food place in Chinatown. So I looked on yelp to find a palace and I saw this one had lots of stars. So ok, I walked maybe 14 blocks. I walked inside and saw pretty cool stuff like live fish and many other cool decorations. I picked a seat and looked at the menu and I was very thirsty from walking a long time and I didn't get my drink order in like 15 minutes. When he comes he carried cans with him and in the back I think they don't have a fountain. About 30 minutes later, the guy asked what I wanted and my food took like maybe an hour. I was starving the entire time. 

My food came out and it was like normal Chinese food . I thought it would be something really special but it wasn't . The food was expansive too. 

Next time a go to a Chinese food place in Chinatown. I will go to the other one I saw on the map.
author: Austin A.

description: Just randomly walked in cus we were getting hangry. What a delight. So good!  Super fresh food, fast/great service, and of course delish! Good atmosphere and decorations.
author: Laura F.

description: My husband and I enjoyed our lunch at Far East last week.  We were so hungry while making our way through Chinatown.  I ordered the Buddha's De lite which was a vegetarian dish of vermicelli noodles and vegetables .. several types of mushrooms.  It was good and I really enjoyed it.  The sauce combining the noodles and veggies was very light in taste which allowed me to taste the varied mushrooms.  My husband ordered the special chow mein and he enjoyed his as well.  We also ordered some dim sum of BBQ pork buns and pork shu mai which were also tasty.  We were served a very full pot of oolong tea which went very well with our meal.  The total experience was good.
author: Julie C.

description: Truly horrible service. I had a hair in my rice. I argued with the server, and he wouldn't initially refund me the 1.50 for the rice bowl. Arguing with the server was so unpleasant that I debated walking out, but didn't want to embarrass my friends. DO NOT GO HERE.
author: Chuck S.

description: Clay pot seafood combo was not very good. Jf stuck here try potstickers. Nice ambiance. About all is going for it.
author: Oscar C.

description: By far the worst restaurant ever! Waited over an hour for our food while everyone around us got served.  By the time we got up to leave after waiting they decide to bring out the food.  As we are leaving the waiter decides to be rude and start arguing with us. STAY AWAY AWFUL CUSTOMER SERVICE!!  One star is too good for this place!! AWFUL AWFUL AWFUL!!!
author: Sonia R.

description: The restaurant has a old-time China feel to it and the private rooms looks interesting. You walk in and you feel like you're going to enjoy the experience you're about to have. That being said. This was one of the closest Chinese restaurant near I was staying and I chose the wrong place to dine. The dim sum was just salty and and the soup was below mediocre. Chao fun was extremely oily and it didn't even taste right. If I knew better I would have gone to another place.  To be honest it's a tourist trap and we fell for it.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Had a nice, quick and quiet luncheon here with my girlfriend before our little shopping spree today. It's not hard to see this place if you enter Chinatown thru the main "gate" and just walk straight. The venue is pretty spacious and I appreciated all the tacky decorations. They have private dining booths for large parties which is a nice touch they have.

Anyways for lunch we opted out of dim sum and that led us to just have some hearty hot and sour soup with an order of the roasted half duck with steamed white rice. The soup was what I expected, I love it and try to order it everywhere and it seems to taste pretty much the same, no surprises. As for the duck it wasn't amazing but it definitely satisfied my cravings. It came out hot and crispy with some hoisin ginger sauce on the side of it. The duck was plump and fatty, just the way I like it!

Peking duck was $36 and our roast duck was $18, not bad but not cheap! Overall our experience was what we thought we'd get. Service is almost non existent but here and there they try their best to clean up while you dine, smile and wear suits, lol.
author: James D.

description: I was looking for dim sum and made a mistake by coming to this restauant. The food was cold and very little was worth eating. The potstickers were good, broccoli cold, sliced pork inedible, shrimp dumplings slimy. Maybe the food on the regular menu would be worth eating but NOT the dim sum. Not cheap either.
author: Be A.

description: Did not have a very good experience here... Service was sub-par, better food found in Cerritos for a much better price. To top it off, they charged us a 20% tip for our party of 12. It wouldn't have been an issue if we had received service worthy of it! Should stayed Far from this cafe!
author: Ryan C.

description: I went last night with a friend from China, and it was horrible! We ordered the Ying Yang Fried rice, and it was goopy and tasteless. The won ton soup was cold, the bbq rib appetizer, small and yuk, and we never got our soy sauce chicken dish, the service? What service? Horrible experience, will never go back.
author: Mazzy M.

description:
LOVED their spring eggrolls & Mongolian beef!! I asked for extra spicy & that they did. The wait staff was pretty nice and constantly checked on us. We sat in a private booth but we were not forgotten about. 

I even ate my leftovers at room temperature & it was still just as good. 

I would definitely return!
author: HU H.

description: "127 Hours. Thats how long it felt like to get service." That's what I said in my original yelp Quick-Tip. What happened after that, honestly, is that we hunted down our waiter. We eyed him, recognition was made, and he came over. Waiter apologized and said there was an accident in the kitchen. He made it up to us in his own way. If you have the time, this is good -- not great -- dim sum. Shark Fin & Shrimp Dumplings, if nothing else. Like fish had a perm & put on a hat (visualize it). What else? How about those Shanghai Dumplings -- little bombs of soy-saucy joy -- you put entire dumpling in your mouth then chew, feel the sauce explode in your mouth. Nickname: Da Bomb.
author: Sean C.

description:
i think we've been here twice but forgot what it was like. I came here again for my cousin's baby's red egg ginger party. the upstairs is definitely a good size for a large party, with a stage and nice set up.

but the food that they served and what they had to pay...was not great. the simplest of foods, chow mein, beef & broccoli, sweet and sour pork....etc. 

not much to say!
author: Christine M.

description: Best Orange Chicken I've ever had!!! The chicken was very tender and the breading on the chicken managed to stay crispy despite the wonderfully tangy sauce. Actual orange slices to garnish the plate were an unexpected treat. Even the ginger ale tasted homemade. Definitely recommend!
author: Carly F.

description: They have carry out! you can just wait inside where they have a nice seating area. They also have clean restrooms. They are a little hard to find because you have to go to the end of the restaurant and then up to the second floor. Also the decor looks very authentic.
author: Diana C.

description: $500 per table for wedding banquet. Ordinary and bland dishes with no dessert nor fried rice and chow mein. Killer stair with no elevator. Way overpriced and under delivered. Stay far far away.
author: Alex C.

description: I had a late night dinner here with the family and was very disappointed. The fried prawns were extremely greasy, the pork ribs were mostly fat and the fried rice was mediocre. However, I would recommend the honey walnut shrimp and beef vegetable stir-fry. For the price we paid, I would take my business elsewhere: $90 for dinner for 4 is a bit expensive for Chinese. The restaurant has a authentic ambiance but it doesn't substitute for the lackluster food.
author: Marisa T.

description:
I don't think they make this on site. The pork was old. Dough too thick.

The staff is not aware of where the food is made and yet it appears- once ordered - to arrive quickly. 

It could be re-heated but when the dough is soggy I have my doubts.
author: Terry S.

description: Have just had a ten star meal in this tourist area of San Francisco. The fish was so fresh and tasty. Service here and atmosphere demands a return visit.
author: Bruce B.

description: Came for a fundraising dinner for Our Children Our City. Picked up dinner on my way home after this dinner. Enough said?
author: Carrie W.

description: The interior was nicely decorated and the service was pretty good. I was disappointed with what I ordered though, the combo appetizer. It was flavorless; I would order differently next time.
author: Megan E.

description:
This was a great place to go after the Chinese new year parade. It's very large layout allows you to feel the energy of china town. The downstairs dining room features very old carved chandeliers from the 1920's. There is also an expansive upstairs dining room for large parties. This location features little private dining rooms with a pull curtain for privacy. 

The location is right across from the Old St. Mary's Catholic church on California and Grant. It's easy to find and parking is nearby in the financial district. 

The food is surprisingly good for the number of meals they turn out. The cost is average and the people watching is priceless.
author: Veda F.

description:
The food was commercial and tasteless with huge chunks of onions and vegetable cut into everything. I was really disappointed with the quality and flavors!
We ordered Sichuan chicken which was made with an artificial sauce.
The prawns with cashew nuts had huge pieces of bitter courgette.
If I could give this place NO stars I would.
There is nothing authentically Chinese about this restaurant. I recommend you skip this one altogether
author: Hemla m.

description:
I know I may be harsh with this rare one star review, but that's the rating that cones to mind. It's based on my organization's annual Chinese New Year luncheon held here this afternoon. It was buffet style which around eight items to my recollection. I'm not picky about food, but for me the quality of some items was terrible considering it's coming from a restaurant kitchen. In particular the chow mein and the fried chicken, they seemed worse than that of most Chinese hot food takeout delis.

I've been here before for company parties but was never inspired to come here otherwise. This is because I'm suspicious of restaurants in this part if Chinatown catering more to tourists than locals. Today's experiences increases exponentially the unlikelihood I'll be coming here.
author: H K.

description:
