This place should be ashamed of themselves! I think I've had plenty of bad experiences but this one has got to be one of.. if not THE worst place I've been to. Everything from the food quality, the service, the price, the cleanliness and the after effects once I got home were BAD!

We spent the day shopping in China Town and were ready for dinner. I probably should have yelped this place before coming in but just went with it since my inlaws insisted on trying it. The place was empty except for a big party upstairs. This should have been my first clue! We were then seated in one of the private booths with a curtain that closes off the booth which was crammed.  To summarize, since there were 5 of us we opted for the "Far East Dinner". It was priced at $19.95 per person and had a preset menu that listed what you would get. I felt it was quite pricey to charge 20 a person for something that was not buffet style and would be individual plates but I gave them the benefit of the doubt. BIG MISTAKE. 

What was included in the Far East Dinner was:
Fried Prawns & Barbecued Spareribs
Hot and Sour Soup
Prawns with Honey Walnut
Beef with Mixed Vegetables
Yang Chow Fried Rice
Tea & Fortune Cookie

4-5 persons add:
Kung Pao Chicken

Now to the bad things...

1) First waitress was very rude and dismissive. Plopped down some worn out menus and left without a single word.
2) When tea was served there was a faint lipstick smear on my cup.
3) My plate had dried pieces of whatever was previously on it that I had to scrape off.
4) Second waiter came in and when we told him we wanted to sub out the Kung Pao Chicken for Mushroom Chicken due to some of our guests having acid reflux issues, the guy kept pushing the Kung Pao Chicken and stating it was not spicy. He finally gave in and said "just this one time".
5) Food did not come for a good 30 minutes after he left.
6) Hot and Sour Soup, BBQ spareribs and Fried prawns finally came. Soup was extremely spicy (we already explained the situation with Kung Pao Chicken and he didn't mention that this soup was really spicy). Tasted like there were multiple mashed chilies in it. It was also really salty. BBQ spareribs were extremely hard and mostly gristle with a layer of FAT. Fried prawns looked like they came out of a bag that you buy from Costco and were just heated up in the oven. (No sauce was served with prawns... usually other places give you sweet and sour sauce or hot mustard with fried prawns).
7) Drinks were never offered other than tea. We had to practically flag down the first waiter to get soda. When we went around the table to say what we wanted she looked super annoyed and had trouble keeping up with our 5 drinks (3 cokes and 2 sprites.. how hard is that to remember?)
8) We also ordered a side of pot stickers... gross... wrapper was thick and doughy. Filling had a bad after taste (think cabbage but in a bad way).
9) The second waiter came back and started collecting up emptied dishes while people were still in the middle of eating. (i.e. when I was still eating the guy reached over me to grab the next plate).
10) When my sister in law tried to give him her plate he looked like he was about to swat her hand and then yelled "NO NO NO I do it!!!" I mean how DARE she politely hand her empty plate to him?
11) Since my brother in law was the only one who could stomach the hot and sour soup and was clearly still slurping it up, the waiter dumped whatever was left over in his bowl while he was mid slurp.. didn't even ask if he wanted more.. surprised he didn't jam the ladle in his mouth!
12) He zipped outta there and we waited another 30 minutes till the Mushroom Chicken, Walnut Shrimp, Beef with Vegetables and Fried Rice came.
13) Walnut Shrimp: Looked exactly like the breaded fried prawns we received earlier but smothered in overly sweet thick syrupy sauce. Walnuts tasted weird like they were old.
14) Beef with vegetables: Where's the Beef?? All vegetables.. and what beef was there was hard and chewy
15) Mushroom chicken: the only decent dish but again all vegetables and no meat!
16) Fried Rice came last (Um... I like eating my food WITH the rice thank you). There were dried pieces of rice in it but otherwise was just OK.
17) Refills on the drinks: Waiter practically scolded us by saying "NO REFILLS!" Um can we at least pay for a second drink instead of you walking away?
18) TO TOP IT OFF: the bill..... $150 dollars... believe me my jaw literally dropped. For the CRAP quality of this food $150 is a freaking joke! Thank God my sister in law dropped the cash for this. She probably should have made sure there weren't any extra charges (I couldnt read the chinese on  the check to break down the bill but i'm guessing there was added gratuity and who knows what else?)
19) Finally when I came home I was treated to a hefty dose of diarrhea (and so did a few others that were with us).

All in all avoid this place at all costs. How this place got 3 stars I have no idea!
author: Vinny M.

description:
Best Dim Sum I've ever had..... And what a great location to have it!!!!  Everything we red red was hot, really tasty and pretty fast!  

My suggestion....relax! The China Town crowd is always there....enjoy the different cultures and the great food!!
author: Bob P.

description: Ok food. Small portions for large groups. Nice authentic ambiance. Being in Chinatown I expected more but I have actually had better food in strip malls in LA.
author: Brent C.

description: The atmosphere is really authentic and enjoyable. But the food is very avarage, the general chou's chicken is artificial and the appetizers are aesthically unpleasing and small. The servers were nice but Wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Joni M.

description: They played hide the chicken in both chicken dishes we ordered. The mu shu chicken tasted like cabbage and egg. General Chou was basically spicy fried dough. Where's the chicken?
author: Tomi C.

description:
Love the sweet and sour pork and the chow mein. Place is huge.it gets busy. So its 
best to get there early.
author: Egor M.

description:
The stars are mostly for the excellent ambiance as I believe most of the food to be average to below average.

The room is beautiful and feels like it has a lot of history.  The dark wood, high ceilings and closed off booths on the side are what I'd imagine Chinatown in San Francisco was like many decades ago.  It feels like there should be a hidden opium den available to locals "in the know".

What we ordered:

Shredded Dry Scallop Soup - average.  I liked the amount of shredded scallop but the taste was lacking.  Bland.

Seafood Chow Fun - below average.  They skimped on the noodles and it was mostly bean sprouts.  Fair amount of seafood (shrimp, scallops, squid) however was also bland.  Needed to ask for hot sauce to give it some taste.

Salted Cabbage with Stewed Pork Clay Pot - above average.  I would recommend this dish and thought it was tasty and would order it again.  It is pork belly (reminded me of pork belly I often get at Korean bbq) in thick slices over a tasty cabbage stew.  Needed to order a side of rice to absorb the stew.  Pretty yummy.

It was just an uneven experience with some good and some really ordinary parts.
author: Michael S.

description:
This weekend I met up with some out of town friends to spend a few hours in SF checking out Chinatown and walking down to see the parrots come in to roost by the Ferry Building.  We didn't realize that this was the weekend of the flower market before Chinese New Year though, so OMG was it every packed!  An estimated 400,000 people attend the 2-day flower market, I swear at least 350,000 of them were there Saturday afternoon! Heh.  

So anyway, we walked up from the Powell Street BART station and then checked our phones for somewhere to get a late lunch - whereupon the challenge was finding somewhere both open and not too busy.  We decided to give the Far East Cafe a try. None of us had heard of it, but I liked the name, it was closeby, it was open, and they could seat us right away.

In the end that was most of the positives used up before we sat down.  I really found the rest of the experience rather mediocre.  The ambiance has the potential to be cool, with the little curtained nooks and the huge lanterns hanging from the ceiling - but in honesty it has the feeling of somewhere that was posh and amazing once upon a time but is now waiting for the Jellical Moon so it can get a chance at a new Jellical Life (sorry - just saw CATS and it's sort of stuck with me!)  The place is shabby and tired looking.

The food was pricey and I didn't find it all that stellar.  We had chicken and corn soup that was bland and rather tasteless, spring rolls that were cold in the middle (not frozen, but cold), and while I didn't try the spicy beef dish, it looked greasy and unappealing.  The service was lackluster - our waiter seemed rather put out that we didn't order a lot more food (he told us that the amount of food we bought would not serve three people - when in fact it was more than enough), he reached across people to put things down on the table rather than going around the other side, and took FOREVER in bringing us the bill so we could get back to exploring.  Oh, and the fortune cookies tasted weird - which I think was the most disappointing part for me (maybe I'm just weird that way).
author: Ailsa B.

description:
After walking by for many months on our way to/from the Chinatown Y we decided to have lunch there.  

We were attracted by the vintage Chinatown decor...wooden booths, Chinese chandeliers, Chinese empire paintings, etc.

Our waiter was friendly & attentive.  He accomodated our request to sit in a booth.

The Salt & Pepper Fish...tasted more like fried Calimari than fish.  The batter was too thick, the fish fillet too thin.  I would not order it again.

The Crab Claw dim sum...was actually a shrimp ball.  It was good for a shrimp ball, but I was expecting some crab.  I would not order this again either.

The Chinese Broccoli...was fresh, tender, & delicious.  I would order this again.

The Fried Stuffed Tofu...was crisp, not oily, & good.  I would order this again too.

The Stuffed Green Pepper dim sum...had a fresh crisp green pepper, & the fish & shrimp stuffing was flavorful.  I would order it again.

So there were some misses & some hits.  While I would return to try other items, I would not go out of my way to dine there.  At their price points I prefer other restaurants in the area...like City View or Great Eastern.
author: Saul M.

description: Don't know why all the negative reviews. Best place in Chinatown to go and eat, service was PHENOMENAL, food was done well, better than most other "top notch" places here. 10/10
author: Eric K.

description:
I wish the Far East Café was further east so I wouldn't have come across this restaurant. The food was mediocre at best, the price was much more than I am used to paying for Chinese food, and the service was terrible.

My friend and I had the dinner for two for $18/person. This consisted of egg drop soup, two egg rolls, fried rice, duck, and beef and broccoli. The egg drop soup and beef and broccoli were acceptable, nothing special but at least 3-star worthy. The egg roll was pretty delicious but it was tiny and there was only one per person. The fried rice was stale, so we asked for some white rice as well. It took us at least three minutes with my arm up to get a waiter's attention. And insult to injury, the extra bowls of rice was tacked on to the bill. This is also something I am not used to at most Chinese restaurants. The duck was extremely oily like it was soaked at the bottom of a tub and was put directly onto a plate and served to us. I had to go through two cups of water to wash everything down. I assume I won't have to go into detail about my wait getting a refill.

I would have given this place one lone star had it not been for the fact that I got here shortly past 9:30PM and they closed at 10:00PM. I am giving the wait staff a little slack for I am sure they wanted to get their dinner on as well. This does not mean I am giving them a second chance.
author: Eric K.

description: Often rude gets what rude does so I an a bit reluctant to take the reviews too serious.  Been coming here for years and always had good service, but a meal here is not meant to be fast food so that might affect some diners opinions
author: Cary M.

description:
We went to a Red Egg & Ginger Party here last Sat. 

Wow...... 

After reading the reviews, I was expecting pretty mediocre food. 

I still wasn't prepared for how gross it was. I took a bite of most of the dishes offered. Unfortunately, both my hubby and I decided none were worth any calories. 

I get that this place has been around forever, and people go there for that reason. BUT, why do they get away with serving such horrible food? 

Regardless of historic significance, it's still a restaurant, and restaurants serve food. Therefore, every effort should be made for the food to be (at the very least) decent. 

It makes me sad to think how much money our friends parents spent on this event.
author: Amanda G.

description:
(See pics)

I have passed by this place a few times and have always wondered the decor more so than the food... this evening me and a friend decided to give it a try.

The salted fish with tofu and diced chicken was bland as the fish should have been quite salty. The spicy eggplant with minced pork was actually quite good with the "wok" style even it was not spicy at all. The side dish of Gai Lan was also good.

The deco of this place was like the old China that I only know from TV soap. The high ceiling and big old style lanterns were a bit rusty but adds a little character. There are also side semi-private rooms that are fairly interesting.

I sometimes am in the mood of a sucker of looks and decor even I knew the food would be a bit "fusion", and this was the night.

And I guess with the name it's just not far east enough to be totally authentic Chinese...
author: T L.

description: Stayed at a really conveniently located hotel to Chinatown. But since wife was sore from just running a half marathon, we decided to go to the first restaurant that looked somewhat appealing. What a disappointment. Nothing we tried was good. Only thing it had going for it was it's location, in the heart of Chinatown and an above average service. This is what happens when I don't yelp the restaurant before trying it.
author: Eugene G.

description:
Ah yes. Far East Cafe takes me back to my childhood as I remember my dad used to bring us here after the Chinese New Year's Parade. Me with my Dennis-the-Menace cowlick and in my little Bermuda shorts and white knee socks. I was precious. Can't you picture it? But I digress ...probably because it pains me to admit that the place is really mediocre. I doubt if my palate could tell what was good Cantonese food when I was six, but at fo-o-o....well, more than six...I think I can tell you this is just not a great dining destination. 

Sure, they have the private booths where they squeeze 12 people around a table for six. Sure, they have decorative lanterns above. Sure, they have the lazy susans at their banquet tables. But Jamie really wanted almond chicken, Michigan-style, and I Googled to find that Far East cafe serves almond chicken. Alas, not even close to his expectations. He was wanting something deep-fried with almond slivers and some gloppy, yellow sauce on top. What they serve here is diced chicken mixed with almond bits like a cashew chicken with an unappetizing-looking sauce. And all for $ 11.50. 

I actually ordered Steamed Chicken with Scallions which comes with a minced garlic sauce. It's a deceptively simple dish that's ordered only by grandmas from the old country and me. Still, it tasted wrong somehow (Hunan Homes is still the only one in Chinatown that does this dish justice). And yes, you guessed it...$11.50. To add to our disappointment, we were seated in between two large banquet tables that were leaning over us to shoot videos and pass the deep-fried crab. I think I'll just go to Sam Wo's where at least the food is better than the ambiance.

FOOD - 2 stars...on the bleh side...even for Chinatown
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...like an ancient palace for really loud families of tourists
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...on the forgetful side
TOTAL - 2 stars...Far East - sad to say - is far gone
author: Ed U.

description:
The best part about this restaurant is its history. When walking in, there are old Chinese lanterns, a friendly but semi polluted fish tank in the lobby. The ceiling work in this restaurant may remind you of an old Victorian while the private rooms on the left side of the restaurant may remind you of a church confession stand (with a curtain). 

I've been here maybe 10-20 times for various occasions, such as Red Egg & Ginger parties, lion dance performances, Family Association banquets or some kind of wedding. 

Food here is decent, touristy shit. The "Dow-mew" and steamed black bass may be the best things to order here. Everything else is meh. The tea is never boiling hot, but I can't really complain since I'm not the one paying. x) 

Service is decent.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Very Good Restaurant - We Enjoyed Ourselves

We were visiting San Francisco and were debating where to eat. We thought Chinatown would offer some choices and were not disappointed. The place was packed on a Saturday night so we had to wait a while. We were lucky and got a private booth. The staff was nice and punctual. Cheesy décor with massive chandeliers and bright colors, but at the same time, it was fun and beautiful (in a crazy kind of way). We had three chicken entrée dishes (yummy and nice portions), two side dishes and one alcoholic drink (tea and cookies are on the house), and were shocked to get a bill for only $42! 
Excellent prices, great food, and fun place! Who could ask for more?
author: Ronnie R.

description:
We wandered in here around 3 on a Friday afternoon, after I decided I was hungry in the middle of our exploration of Chinatown. It was really packed - with tourists, with locals - this place was hopping.

First, the space is huge. Funny how you take space for granted when you live somewhere so spread out like PHX - I feel like most bars I went to in SF were basically a long hallway with one or two tables at the end.
Anyway, it was a well-decorated space, too. Nothing cheesy, plastic or cheap in here (see: the rest of Chinatown for that). Wood-carved tables and chairs, elaborate chandeliers, private booths and fish tanks (for eating, not for admiring).

I braced myself for the prices to be a reflection of the care taken to make their joint more authentic than the circus outside, but it was reasonable. $5 for a small bowl of Egg Flower soup, $5 for a Tsing Tao and $6.5 for six of the biggest pot stickers I'd seen in my life. Not to mention the aforementioned food was quite tasty - I generally dislike all Chinese food because it tends to be too salty, too greasy and somehow flavorless all at the same time.

Service was great, too. We liked it so much that when we found ourselves back in Chinatown two days later, we stopped in again.
author: Lauren V.

description: A friend and I stumbled across this restaurant during a walk through Chinatown. I was skeptical because the reviews seemed really mixed. I should have listened to the negative reviews. The restaurant wasn't even full and we had to wait 10-15 minutes for a table. The waiter was extremely rude and aggressive. I don't think it was a language barrier at all...his tone was almost condescending when we placed our order and he really tried to rush us out of there. The food was okay; not the best but also not the worst. I would have rated this 3 stars if not for the service.
author: Michael N.

description: The decor could do with an upgrade - and the toilet!! But the food was delicious and authentic.
author: Kira G.

description: Great service & great food! We had general tsos and beef with snow peas! The vegetable spring rolls were great as well
author: Idalia A.

description: This was my second visit.  I doubt I will be back.  The food isn't bad, but it isn't exciting.  My fish tasted a bit old & was supposed to be spicy & was bland instead.  I could be wrong here, but my impression is that this once was a really good place, but standards have slipped.  You can see what remains of a great restaurant, but service is slow & the food is so-so.
author: Phillip A.

description: This is my second time here. The corn soup is great and the lemon chicken is okay. As far as service the waiter forgot our water two times. But was able to provide tea. I had to ask for water for the third time. The bill was reasonable. The front desk lady is super nice. She validated my parking saving $6 which is why I rated this a three star instead of two.
author: John F.

description: Food and service were awful. The Sesame Chicken was just orange chicken with sesame seeds on it and tasted and so sweet that it was entirely inedible. My kids got the chicken Lo Mein and would hardly touch it; so my wife tried it and said it tasted like someone had dumped liquid smoke on it. We also never received our full order and were entirely ignored by the wait staff after receiving our food. Our drinks were never refilled and we had to chase down a different waiter to get our bill. This was the first time in my life that I left no tip at all. There's no shortage of Chinese restaurants in China Town so I recommend going just about anywhere else.
author: Spencer P.

description: The food was excellent, service as well. Everything came out as ordered and fast. Nice chandeliers, very romantic.
author: Joe K.

description: The hot & sour soup was really good.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
In recent times, I've been here twice - once for their bar (and take out Chinese food), and once for a company event. It's...pricey. I immensely enjoyed my first experience here compared to my second - the drinks were strong, the bartender was nice and chatty (though you could tell they weren't used to people coming in at 7PM and asking for a Long Island, as they had to pull one of the head guys to the bar to serve us). Food was expensive, but it tasted good - we got fried rice, fried wontons, and some fried chicken wings (I know, we had the munchies).

When I came for my company event, I don't know if it was the stress of trying to serve the same dish to 200 or so people, but the food was mediocre tasting. We had 10 dishes, ranging from duck to fried rice, string beans, etc etc, and the only dish I really enjoyed was the fried egg roll things in the beginning. My coke was also severely watered down, which I could immediately taste since I drink a couple cans of soda everyday.

Service-wise, they're okay and pretty nice. I'm just not sure how I feel about the food.
author: Melody L.

description: It wasn't the best restaurant I've been to. It's a bit more on the expensive side, and the wait time for your food is a little too long. My friend ordered the Soy Sauce Chicken they offered, and they literally would not stop boning her...
author: Eric J.

description:
Alright so last night was the Chinese New Year parade and it was pretty busy. They told us a 45 minute wait and we were seated in 20 minutes...off to a good start.

The first waiter was happy we filled out what we wanted on the menu card and went over everything...another good sign.

That was about the end of the good things. It was so hard to get things like water or chinese mustard and by the time we got water it was 30 minutes in. Getting more was not possible. They quickly dropped off the food and it was brought in the wrong order. We ordered crab soup and it came with the fried rice...shouldn't that come first? The soup was extremely bland and not tasty.

The rest of the food was mediocre at best, although I will say the fried rice was not greasy and cooked (or is it woked) lightly. All in all a very forgettable meal.

Last but not least is the cleanliness of the venue. Don't look up and be careful with the floor. If you look up and see the chandeliers they are caked in nastiness. I don't think they've been dusted this century and probably not since the 1960s. I mean have some respect for your customers and clean up your awesome looking light fixtures. The floors were slick and greasy. I'm hoping it was because it was so busy that day but it doesn't seem like much cleaning goes on here.

Sadly next time I'm in China town I'll check out somewhere else.
author: J. S.

description:
We attended our friends' Red Egg & Ginger Party this afternoon celebrating the birth of their new little one. (Congrats Dawn and Dave!) Far East Cafe is nestled in the heart of SF Chinatown. It can be a bit hard to find amidst the huge crowds of pedestrians and traffic in the area, however once you're there, you'll be pleased with decor of the establishment that's been here since 1920.

The celebration was held in their private banquet area up the flight of stairs. The hall was large and I think could seat over 300 people. Food was tasty, particularly the fried chicken drumsticks.

Note about parking--it's horrible. There are two main structures nearby but pay close attention to not miss them because having to swing back around in this area is a hot mess! :) My suggestion, save yourself the strain if you need to get to Chinatown and hop on the bus to avoid parking fiascos.
author: Nam N.

description:
I have never experienced better service in a Chinese restaurant. They went above and WAY BEYOND to make sure my parent's anniversary was special. I'm definitely going back.

so here's the longer version of the story...
my parents had their wedding reception there 33 years ago, so we decided it might be fun to celebrate their anniversary there.  

earlier in the week we made a reservation and there was some miscommunication about the amount of space that would be there that night. they called us and left us a message but we didn't get it so when we showed up, it was a full house and we thought we might have to find another place to eat.  I described the situation to the FABULOUS hostess, Kathy and she was very apologetic and went above the call of duty and started getting creative with how she could help make the night special. Somehow she pulled out all the stops, got us a table, our own waiter (who was really good and attentive).  Everyone was so incredibly awesome, we're considering making this an annual tradition (if not more).

Food was also good and at the right price.  thanks a million Far East Cafe, we couldn't have asked for a more memorable night!
author: Elaine G.

description: Average Chinese food and poor service. 2-3 wait staff could not even understand simple requests. Appetizer came fast but then entrees so slow we had to ask. They forgot one item; said they would go back for it but then later a guy came back and shrugged his shoulders. Keep walking....
author: Diana C.

description: An enjoyable experience. I thought that Chinese food was good in TJ & Mexicali, but this appeared much more authentic. We had & recommend the Kung Pao Chicken, Duck Noodle Soup, & fried rice.
author: Hector M.

description:
The average 3 star rating is mostly for the service not the food; the food is outstanding, but the service sucks. These guys try to get you out of there with your plates still half full and continue to bug you with "Are you done, Are you done?". 

I can careless if they smile and be super friendly, but don't kick me out 10 minutes after I sat down :)
author: Jack L.

description:
I think at this point my ratings are pretty arbitrary anyway, so before you're all, "five stars are you crazy??" pump the brakes and let me interject.

Sure, the food is terrible. Probably the worst actual Chinese food I've ever had. Just go home and microwave some Trader Joe's siu mai and call it a day. For god's sake stay away from the vegetarian chow fun. (Also, do you know where you are? this is CHINATOWN. it's like being disappointed in the cuisine at Disneyland.)

But the Far East is a real asset in two ways. 

One, it keeps tourists out of really good places we like in the Richmond and Sunset. 

Secondly, it is the most beautiful place in the world and I will be attempting to rent out a private booth as my studio apartment. Because I am happy only when the decorative arts are right, and I don't know if you looked up at the ceiling on your last visit but this place is RIGHT! It's post-edwardian chinoiserie at its absolute finest/shabbiest/fucking coolest and I would like to live there, please, exposed pipes and possible rodentia and 50-year layer of dust and all. This is me.
author: Megan W.

description:
The main reason I came to Far East Cafe was to attend a red egg and ginger celebration for a friend's baby. I looked on their website beforehand and looked at the menu for such an occasion and was prepared for mediocre food to be served. I didn't really expect much at all.

When I arrived, I was directed to the large hall where this event was being held. This is also where elderly Chinese couples come to ballroom dance each week I'm told. There is a dance floor and it looks like one of those large rooms where Chinese wedding banquets are held. In fact, there are those big well wishing words aligned on the back wall for such occasions. They didn't even change them for the baby's celebration.

It was kinda chaotic. There must've been more than 200 people there all scrambling to take a look at the baby and then rushing over to stand in line to get the food at the buffet. I was waiting for a friend to arrive so I watched as people brought their plates of food piled high to the tables and started to devour. I felt like I was in a Wayne Wang movie. It was kinda surreal.

It was the same things on each plate: roast pork, chow mein, bok choy with shrimp, beef broccoli, deep fried chicken drumstick, eggroll, Peking short ribs and of course, the ubiquitous red egg. 

When my friend arrived, we went to grab some food. I must say, it was kinda like eating Panda Express. Not surprisingly, I enjoyed the red egg the most. After all it was just a plain boiled egg dyed red. Unfortunately when I went back to grab another one there were none left.

I think Far East is the only place in Chinatown to cater to such a celebration and that's why it's a monopoly and they can get away with serving this sort of food. There was also a fruit punch fountain (I wish I had taken a photo of that -- it was classic in a bad way) which spewed fruit punch out in a weird way. I guess you had to be there.

Having said all this negative stuff I did have one encounter with one of the servers at the buffet line which was hilarious. I went back for more veggies -- broccoli and bok choy -- I told the man in Cantonese I only wanted a little of each. He piled my plate high. When I started to stop him his response was "veggies are good for you, eat more". HAHA. Okay mister! 

He made me laugh and for that they get an extra star.
author: Anita L.

description:
4 dim sum items for 30 dollars?

i can pass

why did i even walk in here, it was already really dead.. that shouldve been a sign..
i kept on having to scream out for a waiter and still they wouldnt come. 
THE FOOD SUCKED AND THEY DIDNT HAD THAT MUCH DIM SUM EITHER! no carts like normal dim sum restaurants. 

im really not a mean person when it comes to servicing because i work at a uhh restaurant type business.. BUT damn!!! you dont need to ignore someone for that long and still have that "fml, i dont wanna serve you" look!!
author: Holly V.

description: Food was ok. Service was horrible. The only saving grace was the polite and cute older Chinese manager. I would not return! The waiter was awful! Rude and inefficient!
author: Claudia H.

description: This is an example of the power of social media.  As a group of 6 out of towners, we  were standing on a  ChinaTown street and just walked into this place because it looked OK--turns out they have been serving here since 1920.  I thought the food was better here than at R&G, where we went the next night because of 2500 yelp reviews and a recommendation from none less  than Chef Bourdain. The food here was very good and the prices are on the low side.  Fantastic egg foo young!!!--Look at the picures others have posted--you sit in private wooden booths.  Clay pot vegtables were excellent.  The duck was a little dry, but very flavorful and the waiter ( in his red vest) prepared rice bun sandwiches with perfect elegance.  Sorry i did not get a chace to go back here--you will notice from other yelpers that this is a place that has been used for family parties, and work gatherings.  Highly recomended
author: AV G.

description: Very positive experience here. The host saw that i was waiting and asked if i wanted to sit at the bar. I said "why... Fo Sho!... he took my order himself, offered me a beer and I was in heaven.... i had just eaten a couple hours before, but loved the pork dish. I ate the whole thing! I would go back. In a china town with A LOT of options. I would recommend. It was clean, service was good, reasonable prices, and nice people.
author: Ricky O.

description: Great food in China town San Francisco. The kung pao chicken hit the spot. The Mongolian beef and beef fried rice were also big hits.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Neat place, they even had extra-private booths separate from the general dining area. There can be a slight language barrier though. My GF and I stopped by, and wanted to have our main entrees with a size of rice and chow mien. I told the server we only wanted a side of these, so we'd end up with two main orders, and two sides, and he said OK. We got four main order sized plates, and the check to match.
It was OK though. The food was delicious (I had the lemon chicken), we left stuffed, and even with the mix up, the tab wasn't that bad. Definitely well suited for larger groups or parties of people.
I did scoff a bit though, when we were charged $0.10 for a plastic bag to put our to-go boxes in. The lady said it was a rule of the area though, not just their store. I would go back, but I'll know not to try ordering "sides" anymore :-)
author: Curtis B.

description: We tried this place for lunch and it was quite good. Service was excellent. The decor was nice... Loved the antique looking chandeliers. We ordered the egg rolls (The order came with six rolls, which we thought was a nice big portion), the sweet and sour pork (super yummy), the lemon chicken (bland... Don't order it!), and the chicken chow mein (tasty!). The best part were the shrimp dumplings. The dish was twice the size we were expecting. I think we got eight dumplings and they were absolutely delicious! I would go back just for those! Three stars for the icky bathrooms and the bland lemon chicken (which is normally my favorite dish). I'd try this place again, though, if we went back to China Town.
author: Susanne A.

description: Dont be deceived by the looks.  We got seated pretty quick and were more than excited to be in china town for Chinese food. Boy were we into some surprise or what. The quantity was very disappointing and the quality was horrendous. These guys make you hate Chinese food. Prices are over the top. Avoid at all costs even if you have to walk a few more blocks for some good food. Johnny the waiter sucks big time! We asked for some hot sauce twice as the food just lacked both spice and salt. He made promises to cone back and never did.
author: Pfe I.

description: Peking duck was mostly skin and bones. What happened to the meat?! I was pretty sad and disappointed. The dim sum wasn't that great either. The Har Gow had a distinct odd smell to it, I couldn't pinpoint what it was. The interior was nice. The service good. Would I come back? Probably not since there's another dim sum place around the corner.
author: Vicky N.

description: Why are restaurants so cheap with ice and napkins?  You would have to ask the people at Far East.  Their minced chicken corn soup is absolutely FANTASTIC.  Their shrimp chow mein is great, as is their hunan chicken.  My only issue with Far East is the cheapness with the ice (boy, do they get upset when you ask for more ice!) and extra napkins (ditto!).  The food is very good and the waitstaff is adequate.
author: Sandra P.

description:
The food was really tasty, but I am sure it is possible to find a best place for less expensive. The average price was $15-16, and interesting complete menus were between 20 and 30.

The biggest problem was the service. We didn't receive our meals at the same time and I could have already finished my meal while another hadn't received his yet.. Moreover, the waiters were kinda rude and impolite, personally I had never seen that. The last point was that we were not all done when they wanted to start removing the plates, which made us even more uncomfortable and hurried to get out of there. 

In brief: food ok but can find as good somewhere else,  and service definitely sucks
author: John C.

description: Made me sick. Literally.  Held a family birthday dinner here in one of the charming private booths.  Had super service and enjoyed the Peking Duck as well as other items now forgotten.  The next day I had a luxury flight to Europe which was ruined by the constant need to go use the facilities, thanks to the previous night's meal.  I do wonder what their health inspection report is.  This occurred in August of this year.  Memorible, but not in the right way.  BTW, our family is part Chinese.
author: N K.

description:
We rocked up at 9:50pm and were ushered inside with "we're closing in 10 minutes but there's still time". We were seated straight away, ordered in 3 minutes and served less than 5 minutes later. Incredible.

The potstickers were fantastic! I wasn't a huge fan of the hot&sour soup, but I'd give it 3 stars. The Mongolian Beef was pretty decent as well.
author: Beth C.

description:
http://www.fareastcafesf.com/photo_gallery.html CAUTION-the web site shows many ugly and boring pictures of the banquet room upstairs.  The dining room is really beautiful AND OLD!!

 LOVE this 1920's Chinese restaurant with its secluded booths,and incredible Asian chandeliers!!!! Plus the food is pretty darn good.  Far better than I expected on often touristy Grant Ave.  The not-too sweet Mai-Tai, (not a traditional Chinese drink) is tasty, although it is not the traditional Trader Vics recipe.   Check this place out!
author: BRUCE S.

description: Packed. No service. Charged me $3/glass for water--no notice. Fatty beef and broccoli, egg soup consistency of mucus, day old Peking duck. Thought the crowd indicated a solid find...seems like just a bus drop off point.
author: Urban L.

description: Good food at reasonable price. Nice private enclosed booths for families.
author: Jerry G.

description: Had a horrible experience and really should have called the law enforcement. We were on a field trip with 6th graders who were only given a certain amount to spend on their lunch. When we entered I asked to see if they had a lunch menu and the lady handed me two menu one was dim sum and the other was a regular menu. The girls in my group asked if they could go to the bathroom. As they went to the bathroom I reviewed the menu and decided this place was too expensive for lunch. I told the waiter who had yet to serve us water that I changed my mind. I went to get the girls and as we were leaving they closed the door a lady blocked our exit and the manager a heavy set man started to yell at us and pointing his finger stating that we should not have used his bathroom because we were not customers. I then proceeded to tell this man that I would pay for using the bathroom. After he continued to yell and point his fingers at us they let us get out. We felt very threatened and made our Chinatown experience very bad considering there was also a shooting nearby. Moral of the review, do not use any bathroom at Far East unless you are prepared to be a victim of high priced food.
author: Maria S.

description: GREAT FOOD! SLOW SHITTY SERVICE! took forever for someone to come over & even take our drink order!
author: Joshua B.

description: Average Food. Average Service. Don't see all the negativity that people post about, but don't see anything awesome either. Quick dinner, warm food at a fair price for San Francisco. Major kudos for seating is at 9:45 with a 10:09 closing time. A lot of places would not have done that.
author: Davis N.

description: The only thing that, I like about the Far East Cafe is how the inside is decorated. It feels like, I am in one of those very old chinese style movie. I did eat here before several times for lunch.
author: William B.

description: Food was ok. Interior was cool to look at. I do not recommend the Kung pao chicken.
author: Christina W.

description:
My husband and I attended a Benefit Banquest a the Far East this past week.  We were very impressed with the food and the service.  It is amazing to fathom their serving 600 persons so promptly and efficiently.  The attendees all seemed to enjoy themselves.  The space did not seem crowed once we all sat down.  I would suggest that they have a better system for passing appetizers before an event, however.  It appeared that only the folks near the back of the room by the kitchen entrance received the passes appetizers. 
However the rest of our meal was delightful.   I even found a new dish to count among my favorites;  Whole Duck, boned and stuffed with a mung bean and barley with gravy.  Can I say OMG enough times.  I could have licked the platter it was so delicious. 
The rest of the meal was just as wonderful.  I especially enjoyed the whole fish, the shrimp balls and of course, the lobster:)  WOW was that good.  
Ultimately, I highly recommend this restaurant for any large event you are hosting in the future.  If you want good food and kind and efficient service, this is the place to go.
author: Erin S.

description:
Craving Chinese food is not something I experience very often. As a matter of fact, I never crave chinese food and I think the last time I had it was about a year ago. I don't know why because I love it!

I was on a short shopping trip with my friend Jillian R. and a sudden craving for pot stickers/dumplings arose in my tummy. So we marched in to Chinatown on a mission. Far East Cafe was the first place we came across that looked decent enough.

Long story short, service was decent, and they move quickly which is great because we were in a bit of a rush. Total came to $19 + tip and we ordered the Won ton soup, and Mu Shu Pork. Great portions and both dishes were great.

The dumplings were perfect little balls of shrimpy goodness, the broth was light and not too salty. The pork was also good, it had eggs, mushrooms and scallions with a hoisin sauce and the rice wrapper for a do-it-yourself dish.

Tip: don't wait for the bathroom downstairs...you can creep upstairs (stairs are towards the back right end of the restaurant) and there are bigger bathrooms up there. You'll avoid the tourist crowd.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Amazing.. .wonderful... delicious... Far East Cafe.

My experience here was fabulous and pleasant.  Four of us, dined on live crab, beef chow fun, Hong Kong styled string beans and Mongolian Beef.   We found it plentiful, savory and the most memorable dining experience.    We were able to obtain a privacy booth, curtained in a heavy crush velvet with dark stained vintage booth walls surrounding the table on four sides.    Outside the booth was the regular restaurant, plus that fact that we had a stationed server "Gee" outside of our booth ready and willing to keep tea pots full, bus dishes and wait on whatever need we had.  

In the most wonderful fashion, the first dish chow fun came to our table.. and by the we passed around this very warm and delicious dish, then came the delicious string beans, and Mongolian Beef.  Each slowly passed around and biting them one by one. The flow of Chinese beer and warm tea was like a cleansing to the palette.  The crab, came wonderfully presented, and was without a doubt delicious and perfectly made.  

Dish after dish poured in, each so tasty and so delightful. The surprise at the end when even at the end, like a memory from the past, the most wonderful fortune cookie was elegantly placed on our table.   

I will return to the Far East Cafe all I can.
author: Tito Y.

description: I went there for lunch for Dim Sum..  There were lots of choices.  The food was good and came fast.   Timing was important because I couldn't wait long for the food.   I like Chinese food and have eaten it all over the world.  This place had good Chinese food.
author: Bob S.

description: Yummy authentic Chinese American food in a great "old school" setting with private rooms for tables of six to eight. Just don't expect jasmine tea as they serve oolong.
author: Sheila W.

description:
My friend and I stumbled upon this place while wandering about Chinatown like your typical tourists in the city of San Francisco. With time to kill, an appetite/Chinese food craving to satiate, my friend and I decided upon this place after seeing decent reviews on Yelp.

We walked in and were promptly greeted by the host who quickly sat us a table. (Sidenote: As soon as I walked in, the scent of incense was overpowering to me, but that could have been because Chinese New Year's just passed.) Anyways, so we were seated and given menus and water before we ordered, which I really appreciated because I hate having to ask for water and especially refills since I drink like a horse. 

So after a few minutes of contemplating our order, my friend and I ordered some egg drop soup, garlic chicken, and white rice. The food came out quickly and smelled great. To the eye, everything looked great. However, to me, the eggdrop soup was pretty bland/plain and the garlic chicken was not evenly heated. I don't understand how parts of the dish can be cold while other parts are steaming hot? Not sure how that happened, but it did for me at least. Another thing that kind of irked me was that the wait staff did not check on our table after we were served our food. This may be petty, but as a former server, I always made it a point to follow up with customers to make sure everything was meeting/exceeding their expectations.

All in all, Far East Cafe accomplished its job of supplying Chinese food for me and my friend to consume and energy to continue our trek through Chinatown. However, it was a bit costly for our meal cost $27 not including tip. Decent food...all right service...Meh overall.
author: David U.

description: Do not get their duck.  It is too salty, unless you like salty duck.  The ambience is nice and the waiter was attentive to our needs, but the food was mediocre.  I had better Chinese food in San Diego.
author: Carlene R.

description: This restaurant was highly recommended by two different Chinatown shopkeepers, so I decided to take my two friends visiting from Michigan, who wanted to experience an 'authentic' Chinese meal.  We ordered the dim sum platter and two family meals because of the selection provided.  The food was old and tasted like it was on the verge of spoiling--I could not eat it. There is no flavor to their dishes and I can't put into words how awful it was. Hostesses are friendly, but service goes downhill fast.  Waiter service was very poor and the restaurant wasn't even that busy.  I would make another choice and not recommend this restaurant.  Stay away!
author: r r.

description: Food was completely average, ambiance was nice.
author: Sam W.

description:
Took moms and auntie here and was pretty disappointed.   Had a few of the clay pots and fried rice.  Prawns and Walnuts were good but everything else was mediocre at best.

Our waiter was terrible.  Would not got back if you paid me.
author: Cesar V.

description:
I was toying with the idea of giving it 3 stars, but decided on only 2 stars.  Service was very good, but food left something to be desired.  The wonton soup tasted much too salty (although the won tons were good), so my wife and I added water from our cold water glasses to cut down the salty taste.  Our kung pao chicken was OK.  The seafood chow fun was not that appealing.  Prices for what we ordered, and for many of the main dishes on the menu, seemed quite high to me, and while I have not eaten Chinese food for quite a while, my guess is that maybe prices are less in a local neighborhood Chinese restaurant (like the Richmond District of San Francisco) compared to a Chinatown restaurant. To summarize:
Service - 4
Food - 2
Ambiance - 3
author: M T.

description:
i saw the sign reading "dimsum" and was very happy cuz it was what lured me into FAR EAST CAFE.  To my vast disappointment, though this place is elegantly designed, has lots of nice decor of the far east (banners, statues, murals), and is vast to fit 50 or more people, but the menu was poor on dimsum and i mean poor!  

Yup, I was looking for the dimsum and flipped through the menu pages and saw one little photo of 4 pieces of dimsum!  oh what a disappointment!!!!  We eventually ordered the 2 people special and it was served in a timely fashion...spring rolls were tasty, egg soup not that great, fried rice,duck, beef and broccoli all very good, but not the best chinese food.  The portions were actually smaller than other places that have these specials, so that was another disappointment- we didn't have take home :( for the price we paid about.  but all it all i give it a 3 star but that's because came here and didn't get what we really wanted, dimsum.
author: cheryll t.

description: I looked on yelp reviews for this place before I went and I was expecting it to be a 3-star place.  However, the food was quite good, claypots are tasty, garlic spinach made to my satisfaction, egg soup perfect for a cold night, and the service was fast.  Decor inside is vintage and unique but it looks a bit beatup, servers can be rude at times if you want them to do anything other than taking orders and delivering food.  When I first walked in, it looked like it's a tourist's restaurant because there are no Asian customers, so I was pleasantly surprised by the taste of their food.  Tea was pretty good too.  4 stars for food. 3 stars for customer service.
author: Eric H.

description:
Note: I never ate in the regular dining room, this review is about a private party.

I came here for a private birthday party for my moms best friend. I guess this restaurant was my moms friends favorite place to eat. It was hard finding the place, we passed by it twice. Then at the door they sent us upstairs to a big old hall. Their were very nice tables, and a dance floor (that no one danced on) Party was good, service was great. Food was good! I love the general tsaos chicken! awesome! very americanized chinese food.

I really want to try this place out again, except sitting in the regular dining room. Will definitely be back to try it again and update the review!
author: Daniel S.

description: Place is ok. Better then most though. Price is similar to other places. This is probably one of the restaurants that I'm most comfortable going in to eat.
author: Julie Y.

description:
The best thing about the Far East Cafe is its old world history, decor and setting. It has been here in Chinatown for over 90 years! 

It has beautiful ornate ceiling detail work, with huge red Chinese lanterns hanging from the high ceilings, and dark wood private booths all along one side of the restaurant. It is more like a set of an Agatha Christie book or movie than simply a place in Chinatown to eat Cantonese food. And that is what they specialize in, Cantonese food. 

90 years ago, when this first opened, Chinese in America were mostly from poor and mostly from southern Canton regions of China, and came over in the 1850s - 1900s to work on the transcontinental railroads here, or the sugar farms in Hawaii. They were given the jobs to load dynamite in the mountain sides when the railroad tracks were being cut through the Sierra Nevadas, and many died building that railroad. After that, many opened restaurants and laundries to try to earn a living. When many would work for cheap at manual jobs nobody else wanted, there was a huge backlash, epecially during the depression of the 1890's from the Caucasians. (Does this sound familiar to today? Latin American immigrants perhaps?) They were called "The Yellow Peril". 

So California passed a law, called the Chinese Exclusionary Act, which made it illegal for Chinese to own land, become a citizen, or basically have any equal rights. It was even illegal to have a certain hair style that was culturally popular (long pony tails). That is why China Camp in Marin was so named, because the Chinese men who had no work lived there off the land and fished the bay waters for food. That is also why many Chinese who came over belonged to the Community Associations (aka Tongs), as these extended families had to take care of their own and help each other out (they still exist today, often dens for Mah Jhong). That is also why Chinatown was a ghetto of Chinese crammed in a very small area of San Francisco. That is also why on Angel Island there was a rentention center for Chinese immigrants, where they would be interrogated, and often held for long periods of time and/or deported.

It wasn't until the 1940's, when Japan was at war with China and China asked the US for help, and after Pearl Harbor that America finally repealed the Chinese Exclusionary Act of the 1890s! But that is when we took all the Japanese, rounded them up with Presidential Executive Order 9055  and Interned them (many being American Citizens) into concentration camps in the desert, where most lost all of their livelyhood, businesses and possessions. No due process, just racism. (Does this sound familiar to post 911?) 

So this is part of the backdrop of this restaurant, a Chinatown landmark for nearly a hundred years. The food is OK, and not necessarily that cheap. It sort of has a proud heritage that it holds onto, with waiters in black and white attire, now serving mostly Caucasians who are mostly tourists who come to Chinatown to buy cheap trinkets and momentos, and discover the mysterious Oriental fantasies and images played out in old American stereotypical movies. 

Only now, the Chinese can own the land and shops that they work so hard to get and maintain, so generations of their off spring can attend the finest Universities in the country, to have a better life than their ancestors. 

So if you want to know why UC Berkeley is 42% Asian and the largest ethnic group at that prestigious institution, or 60% of the med students at UCSD are Asian, this brief history will give you some perspective.
author: Wanugee N.

description: We've ate here before and is one of the few places we'd consider in Chinatown.  Service is always decent and this time was not different.
author: John F.

description: Let me just tell you, i've spent a good part of my life in Chinatown and this is the first time i've stepped foot into this restaurant.  i have to say the decor is really different from normal chinese restaurant.  Larger parties have the option of getting their own private room. i think its pretty good.  the food is ok, i came here for a banquet type of dining so the food is obviously a lil different from what i would've ordered.
author: Shirley H.

description: Stopped in while walking through Chinatown. It was just alright. I ordered the potstickers and I've had better. These were a bit too soggy. Husband got a dish but thought it was weird it didn't come with rice. Service was very slow and our waitress barely said 5 words to us.
author: LeeAnn N.

description: No. My plate of sweet and sour chicken smelled like a mop. I couldn't finish it. Cheap chicken rejects fried in dough. No. My companion wanted hot sauce (not on the table) and that took ten minutes and 2 people. Then we wanted water. How dare we. That took ten minutes. I can understand coming in here for the decor - it really is amazing - but all I could think of was the shipping container that these sad pissed off employees had to squeeze into before being forced into a life of servitude at the Far East Cafe.
author: John E.

description:
Mmm...
PRAAAAAWNS!
I never had a hankering for those little crustaceans prior. Now I dream of PRAAAAAWNS!
This food was delicious, and after an hour long hunt from Chinese food that didn't look like it may contain various creatures in it, it was well worth it.
The food came really quickly and the people were rather efficient.
Unfortunately, there was a really loud table with drunken businessmen, but I would hardly blame the restaurant for that one.
So, 5 stars for you, Far East Cafe.
And...
PRAAAAAAAAAAWNS!
author: Jessica G.

description:
we had our wedding banquet here a few month ago and everything was fabulous! We booked the top floor which can accommodate 400+ people (we had 320) w/a large dance floor. They have a bridal room that is large and had a large TV so that I could rest and watch as people arrived. Bathrooms were clean. The food was great - we had compliments from everyone about the food (the husband and I only had a few bites since it was busy, but when we did our tasting, it was great as well). 
Everyone is really easy to work with (definitely helps when my father-in-law knows people ;) ) Also, they have cameras installed in the ceilings which was great because they gave us the DVD at the end of the night of our banquet and since we didn't hire a videographer, that was nice to have.
author: A W.

description: Ok. I wanted to come here yesterday because I saw seafood dim sum. Couldn't because the wait was ridiculous. Now I know better than to go to Chinatown for Chinese food but I do this once a year because I'm an idiot.   Not too bad but my expectations were a little low.  That being said the waitstaff is wonderful hence the two stars. Other than that I can't say I will be coming back for any reason other than if I am very hungry and nothing else us available.
author: Sarah O.

description: This restaurant really is as meh as it gets. We went in because it was open late. But it wasn't until they were seating us did we notice that the clientele is 100 percent white. Not a good sign. Food was barely even mediocre, and service was horrifically slow.
author: M S.

description:
Thank you Far East Cafe for holding our wedding banquet upstairs two months ago that accommodated close to 600 guests. Yes. You read that right. That's alot of people. With that many guests, space was tight, but everybody was having a good time. The food I was able to eat (I don't think I took more than 5 bites that night because it was so busy) was delish.  

They had a bridal room where I stayed in while guests were arriving, and they have a big TV so that I could watch who came and what everyone was doing.  The waiter serving our food and refilling our drinks when we went around toasting was really attentive and really helpful.
author: Jocelyn W.

description: Unfriendly staff, forced tipping, charged more than on the menu, extremely expensive and low-quality dish ($25+tax for 8 bite-size fish fillet). Zero star if possible.
author: Darson L.

description: Came here for a fundraising dinner. The food is just ok but the service was great. Second floor had a nice open feeling. Had a great sound system, stage and huge dance floor.
author: C B.

description: The decor is fun but we really paid a premium for the equivalent of greasy Chinese buffet food.
author: Casey F.

description: Nice place with good food. Rice was good and so was noodles. But it is very loud. Good restaurant among the many in Chinatown. Nice setting the service is good. Authentic chinese food at its finest! (Outside of China itself!)
author: Nick W.

description:
We were there for lunch after a funeral service for my friend's wife who passed away from cancer. The service was across the street at the Old St Mary's Church so it was a convenient walk to the restaurant. We filled the whole floor and and there were not enough tables to accommodate our group. However, the waiter was kind enough to open up a side section to allow for the overflow. Just then in front of everyone the manger started to yell at the waiter in Chinese, "I told you not to open that section!" It was abusive and unnecessary. 

At the end of the so so meal we asked for some take home boxes and a bag. They said they did not have any bags and if we wanted a bag they would charge us a $1.00. WTF!! So we carried our take out boxes without a bag. As we walked out we thought we give it a shot and ask the hostess in front for a  bag. She said, "No bags, one dollar." My friend saw a stack of paper bags in front and took a couple for our takeouts not thinking they would charge us $1.00 for a paper bag after we filled their restaurant with a big lunch crowd. They didn't ask us for a $1.00 but the hostess did hide the bags behind the podium and told the waiter in Chinese not to give out any bags until the diners are charge $1.00. I grew in SF Chinatown and I would never recommend this place.
author: Joseph W.

description: yummmmmm, and thats for chinatown food! REALLY clean for chinatown, or even just a chinese restaurant, even the bathrooms. impressive!
author: kim w.

description:
After the Chinese new year parade, we thought it would be fun and appropriate to have dinner in Chinatown along with tens of thousands of other bridge and tunnelers who had the same idea.  We're a smart bunch.

We decided on Far East Cafe because it was the restaurant we happened to be near when my son decided that he has to GO POTTY NOW.  I respond to little kids' potty demands like a marine to his drill sargeant.  Sir, yes sir.  I know the consequences if I don't.  

The restaurant is large and cavernous and reminiscent of a bygone era so I was hopeful.  I noticed that the menu while extensive is really pricey for Chinese food but I was hungry and grateful to be away from the parade crowd.  

Then things started to go down hill.

The service was slow.  It took 30 minutes for our appetizers to arrive.  Then another 45 minutes and nothing.  And the server was no where to be found.  By this time, everyone is hungry and grumpy.  When I ask our server what happened to our food, he said the kitchen is extremely busy because of a large party upstairs and just walked away.  It was only when I tracked him down to tell him that we are leaving did he beg us to give him another 2 minutes.  Immediately, our food started to arrive.  Most dishes were cold and tasted mediocre at best.  Actually, the food sucked all around.  As hungry as we all were, there were a lot of leftovers.  We did not take any of it home.  

Even if the service hadn't sucked (it sucked big time), I cannot recommend this restaurant based on the food.  There are too many other restaurants within a few blocks where you can get much better food at half the price.
author: mia s.

description: Lobster was great - nice, authentic experience.
author: Mark N.

description: We have eaten in this restaurant in the past and so there was no reason not to return when we were in the neighborhood.  Never again.  The service was extremely slow, the pot stickers were cold, the chow mien just ok, and the shrimp dim sum we ordered as an appetizer came 25 minutes later, as we were ready to leave.
author: Marge L.

description: Its not bad, but I've had better....the food is not bad. the place itself could use some updating. The service was good and the staff was nice. Overall I would east there again if I walked by and was hungry, but s wouldn't make a special trip.
author: Aja L.

description:
This is only one of two places in the Bay Area where I will eat Chinese food. The other is Queen's House on Castro in Mountain View.

I found this place by chance one day in 1996 while visiting SF with friends. I've been going here ever since. I've never had a bad meal or a bad experience here.

It's actually the only restaurant in San Francisco that I patronize on a regular basis, as the other SF restaurants I've visited have failed to live up to my expectations.
.
I'm not Chinese, so my knowledge of Chinese food is based on what's usually present on the steam tables of Chinese fast food joints.

Still, this is the best sweet and sour pork, chow mein, fried rice and chicken with vegetables I know. They have a huge menu, but I seldom venture into the unknown.

I usually ask to be seated in a private booth. These are basically rooms with walls and a curtain surrounding your table; very private. It's a big place so there's seldom a wait.

I've never experienced anything but exceptional service here. The servers appear to be recent Chinese immigrants and are very efficient although a bit curt. I think that's a cultural thing. 

The prices aren't more than you would pay at any standard Chinese food restaurant.

Again, let me repeat. This is the only SF restaurant that I patronize on a regular basis, and I only live 50 miles away from SF, and visit SF regularly.
author: Hugo J.

description: This is a good place to go if you want a good meal in Chinatown. The service is lightning fast and the food is great. The place does need some repair and maintenance. The stairs up to the restrooms are filthy. Do not tough the handrail! But my grandma and I get a good laugh making fun of the place.
author: Michael K.

description: Very good food. Fast, attentive and friendly service. Try the dim sum. That's why we went.
author: Terrill W.

description: First meal in Chinatown, and SF in general, and I loved it. Exactly what I was looking for..really cool-looking place with great ambience...funky chandeliers, decor, private, curtained-off booths along the side, a look that tells the diner the place has been around for a looong time and coujld care less about updating its look or changing with the times...and I approve. The food was delicious...fried salt and pepper calamari and fried sea bass with szechuan pepercorn had such amazing flavor and were fried perfectly and not the least bit greasy. Such a great meal after being on a plane all day.
author: Rich J.

description:
good - cleanest restaurant in Chinatown. recommended by my SF Health inspector friends.
bad - banquet food was lacking flavor in most of the dishes.
ugly - the olives used in my bombay sapphire martini. (old and past its useful life)
this venue has been around a long long time and has stylish dining booths with curtains that you can draw closed for privacy and added atmosphere.
author: Jeff W.

description: Decent food.  Service ok, not great.  Large space upstairs for events.
author: Ken L.

description:
Another day, another CNY banquet.  This place is much ritzier looking than New Asia, and I didn't feel like I needed to use antiseptic wipe to clean off my plates and glassware.  The decor is a little nicer in the banquet room, which is quite large with a nice-sized dance floor in the center with karaoke capabilities.  There is also a plethora of TV's and screens so that you can always get a view of either the person karaoking or the karaoke video itself (usually featuring a scantily clad Asian woman lounging against a waterfall or some other insipid scene).

The banquet menu was pretty good.  It started off with the cold appetizer platter, then moved on to soup, prawns with cashews, crispy whole chicken, pork belly with preserved vegetables, a beef dish, mushrooms with mustard greens, and finally, deep-fried fish fillet in a creamed corn-egg drop sauce.  The last dish sounds strange and doesn't seem very Chinese at all, but it was delicious.  Everyone at the table kept saying that it was strange, but good and we had to ask for extra rice to go along with it.  We polished that dish off, even though we were stuffed from all the other food we had had before.  The crispy whole chicken was moist and flavorful and the pork belly, while very fatty, was delicious.  Nothing like slabs of fat and meat to make my family wolf down their rice.

Overall, a very clean Chinese restaurant where the food was quite good.  I didn't feel grossed out going to the bathroom and the service was actually quite good, considering how busy the waiters were trying to serve 30 tables at a single time.  I'd like to come back here and see if their regular menu matches their banquet menu at all in taste.
author: Angela H.

description: The food was decent, but as we were leaving, there was a little issue with our credit card, not really a big deal.  Instead of working to figure it out, the manager treated us as if we were criminals, yelling at us and threatening to call the police.  Even after we resolved it, he still was upset, and shouted, "Have you never used a credit card before?"  Anyway, we won't be going back there.
author: Tom M.

description: Let's just say that we found a cockroach climbing into one of our empty bowls after we had finished eating. Not the cleanest place and the food was subpar as well.
author: Samuel Y.

description:
As D&D pointed out. As a Chinese person I will have to point out that I too was disappointed in the food.   The food they tried to pass off as authentic Chinese was not even that.   I couldn't  believe I spent so much for a few bland dishes.   It was obviously catering for tourist dollars and not locals because the dishes were a bit Americanized than most other place I been to.

I will not be going back here.
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm generally unpicky about my Chinese food, but there's a definite bright line where the tummy and wallet feel sorta robbed. This is one of those places where I'd bring my non-Chinese friends who want a nice, unrushed meal with decent "Chinese food."  Everything is clean, there's English on the menu (and Japanese too, wtf?), the waiters speak English and are courteous by Chinese standards (they have this neutral look and actually look you in the eye instead of the normal grimace), plating is nice, and we even got a private booth enclosed in a room without having to rsvp (it was around 2pm on Sat). The food is just ok though -- the dimsum was cold and kind of hard, the chow mein was a bit too greasy, but the minced seafood in lettuce wraps was decent.  If it weren't so pricey, or if the food was slightly better, I'd probably give them 3 stars.

I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and just try ordering different dishes if I go back again, b/c the first time I went was for a Asian-American attorney banquet upstairs and the food there (all 10 courses of it) was pretty good.  But then again, I didn't have to pay for any of it, so maybe my standards were slightly lower, a la "Ham on the Street" (the Food Network show).  I would never ever think of bringing Chinese friends here though, otherwise all hell would break loose and they would disown me as a food traitor to my race.
author: Erica Y.

description:
The interior is exquisite, the waiters are polite and courteous, and when you walk in the door, there's a bar on the right hand side with a ice cold Tsingtao calling your name. Definitely a beautiful restaurant. 

I was definitely expecting more from the food. The menu is standard Americanized Chinese food. We first ordered the chicken with snow peas then I asked the waiter to recommend his favorite dish. He suggested the General Tso's chicken and the Mongolian beef, two standard Americanized Chinese dishes. I re-asked the question and he tried his best to suggest various other Americanized Chinese dishes. Instead I ordered the beef with broccoli, yes I know, another Americanized Chinese dish. Both the beef and the chicken had the texture of super soft something, as if they had been soaked in baking soda or been pounded to a very weak consistency. I prefer the natural chewiness of meat and poultry. Overall the dishes were both very bland and generic, as was the complementary tea. I was glad that there was white pepper available, but alas, it too tasted very weak, as if it was the cheap kind from Walmart. Fortunately I requested chili garlic sauce, and together with a bit of soy sauce and white pepper, dinner was saved.
author: Melissa K.

description:
I'd give this place a 2.5*; but clicked the 3rd * coz i was actually surprised that it tasted better than i thought!

was here for lunch, really coz i had no choice; every other place was packed and this place was 80% empty, which is always a bad sign. 

Anyway, i ordered the chicken + salted fish fried rice and it came with a small bowl of hot & sour soup

the fried rice was big enough for 2 ppl, really...and it was $11.50, which was definitely exp. 
But it tasted pretty good; definitely better than i thought. 

not sure i'll come back here...the ambience was DARK and dated...but if i HAD to, i'd know where to stop in Chinatown for a quick, fast bite; we were in and out of that place in 35 mins, around noon
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Far East Cafe is inconsistant., but still fairly delicious Chinese food. Sometimes the food is excellent, other times mediocre. The dishes are well prepared and make a great take out meal for you and whoever else you are diing with.

The man who answers the phone to take orders is a gem. If you know who im talking about you will agree. The most enthusiastic take-out man, but not the brightest when it comes to remembering fortune cookies and soy sauce.

They have a wide variety for you to choose from and a quite large "dine in" area. Set in the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown.

OH and dont order anything with shrimp...you wont get it anyways. (Two dishes of ours we ordered with shrimp went sadly without).

Follow me on twitter! "Jaelove42187"
author: Jason L.

description:
Hmm well the food was not spectacular. It was average cantonese food. They had steamed fish and the fish wasnt quite completely cooked. So there was a fishy, raw taste. The peking duck was ok ... as was the fried rice and stuff in general.

What I did like about these guys is, their service was good. I asked them for a bottle of 7up and it was there and available for us. The food also came out quick.
author: Amlan S.

description:
We had our wedding banquet here and I liked the food. All the standard Chinese stuff but done right (cold plate, shark's fin soup, lobster, Peking duck, etc...) The waiters and waitresses were attentive and organized.

I don't know what it is like for regular lunch and dinner. Also, I think some may be put off by the old style decor.
author: Calvin L.

description: I have been to about 30 banquets this year and about 8 times here, the food sucks....We all know that...before we go, we had better eat.   The food is always bland here......I don't know what else I can say...The 2 stars is for the service and that's about it.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
It was the only kitchen open past 9 pm on this cold and foggy night. I needed some hot and soothing carbs badly. 
The sweetest host and the speediest waiters make this place, along with the classy, time period interior of the dining room, man what a trip! 
Piping hot tea, horay!
I ordered vegetarian singaporean noodles. 
it was essentially thin rice noodles stir fried in yellow curry powder... uhh cooking skills???
however the portion was huge and it was laden with tonnns of veggies, bok choy (which was impossible to eat, i think they call them mustard greens even though they are definitely not mustards), broccoli (i love how it sops up the sauce), baby corn, mushrooms, onions, peppers, zucchini, carrots, ... everything!! it was really yummy to a vegetarian like me. 
I don't think I'll ever return unless I am in dire straits again and in Chinatown. On second thought, I'll be A-Ok if I never find myself in that situation again! 
Well done Far East, you've survived for a reason!

p.s at kitchen closing, the entire male staff sat down for a huge family style dinner. heart warming indeed!
author: Libra J.

description: I just went to far east cafe for my brother's wedding reception. The food was excellent especially the shark fin soup. This soup goes well with the duck plate. The waiter service was good and I got to meet the manager Wayne. If you have a dining problem, go to Wayne. He will do everything he can to make your stay enjoyable.
author: Larry W.

description:
In the heart of San Francisco's legendary Chinatown is Far East Cafe, a primarily seafood restaurant.  I was here for my friends, Jen and Ricardo, who had their wedding banquet in their 2nd floor banquet space.

We were served a very tasty 8-course meal - completely authentic Chinese cuisine.  It included a Hong Ning combination platter (crispy chicken, ham and beef cold cuts), deep fried shrimp balls, sauteed scallops with broccoli, braised shark's fin soup with shredded chicken, steamed filet chicken with ham, Peking duck with buns, Lobster with ginger and scallion, and steamed whole fish.

I'm not much of seafood eater, but I have to tell you - the scallops did not even taste seafoody at all, and I ate a lot.  And I NEVER eat scallops.  Granted, the soup turned my stomach after getting a whiff of its pungent smell, and I never eat lobster of steamed fish... but I still really enjoyed the rest of the courses that I did eat.

In any case, the review is mostly based off their banquet service, but I'm sure this place offers a really good dine-in menu for the regular visitor.  I have no idea how much this cost (since it was a wedding), but for whatever it was worth, it was really quite good!
author: Jim D.

description:
After the Chinese new year parade, I decided to join with my friend and her cool friends, which I thought would be fun and interesting to share a new year's dinner in Chinatown.

When I glanced at the menu, the prices was very expensive for their huge selections of food. We made careful selections of the food and we ordered many varieties, from clay pots, to chicken, to fish, to fried rice. Once the food starting to come out, the quality of the food was disappointing for their ridiculous price.  The eggplant claypot was extremely oily, the chicken was over cooked and it was a small hen, the fish had a lot of bones. 

We weren't satisfied with the oily clay pot and had to dispute with the waiter to take it back. (didn't want to be seen as a trouble maker, but if it ain't edible you definitely don't want to pay for it) The customer service wasn't that good and I didn't have a great experience. 

The only thing I enjoyed about this restaurant was the architecture style that strongly depict the ancient Chinatown in the 1900s.  But the food wasn't good.
author: Lelan Q.

description: Fun, thematic, and authentic China town restaurant.  We just dropped in and ate a few items quick style.  Booths have curtains and are numbered= cool!
author: D B.

description: Went to China Town for lunch. Since we have never eaten in China Town before we stumbled upon Far East Cafe. We are so glad we stumbled upon it. Best Chinese food I have had in years. It reminded my husband of old school Chinese food. I wish they delivered to San Ramon. We are going to be back and have already recommended it.
author: Theresa S.

description:
I should have known as soon as I walked in, it was all tourists...but I came here on advice from the concierge at the Westin, bad advice, glad I did not tip him. 

Dumplings are one of my favorite foods on the planet - what better place to get them then Chinatown.  These were inedible, so doughy I almost gagged.
