The frozen ling -lings my 10 year old makes at home are far superior. My entree was slightly better, not sure why they are so busy....wish I could have a mulligan. 

Staff was great and thank goodness the beer was cold. Big mistake to eat here. Hunan homes is only a few blocks farther in and they Rock.
author: T M.

description: Very expensive for the quality of food offered. Small portions. We ordered pot stickers: mystery taste to the meat, not side sauces offered, but otherwise ok. Lemon chicken: just ok, a little dry. Won Ton soup: slightly strange gamey taste to the meat, just a few pieces of cabbage, no other vegetables, fairly ok broth. I've had much better soup elsewhere. There were no local Chinese folks eating at the restaurant, only tourists. That's a bad sign. The decor was fascinating, we loved the chandeliers & the ceiling moldings. But I will not ever return to this restaurant. There has to be better place to eat in Chinatown. I didn't do my usual Yelp research before we made the trip into SF. My bad.
author: Elyse B.

description: This is one reason to go to SF and one of the 2 Chinese restaurants I'll eat at. Plus, I love the little rooms that we eat in. This is a fantastic place to eat!
author: Melissa J.

description:
Far East Cafe is good. Good for chinese food in Chinatown. Try the wintermelon soup...yummy

I also like the restaurant vibe inside. Huge hallway, and always packed. Waiter service is pretty good. 

Better than a lot of restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Sav B.

description:
I'm from Raleigh, NC and I was visiting my boyfriend when we decided to take a day trip up to SF.  We were wandering around Chinatown, trying to find a good place to eat.  We ended up picking this place and I was a little disappointed.  I was craving some lo mein, but could not find any on the menu so I picked some fried rice instead.  While plentiful, it wasn't as tasty as expected and left a bad, dry aftertaste in my mouth.  The spring rolls were delicious, but expensive ($7 for 4?  Please.).  The complimentary tea tasted like it had vanilla in it.  Chinese tea with hints of vanilla?  WHAT?

I visit my family in NYC a lot and we often go to their Chinatown.  Maybe it's because all the restaurants we go to there are pre-screened by my aunt or maybe it was my high expectations but, overall, I was extremely disappointed.
author: Melanie D.

description:
I thought the choices on the menu sounded a little "different" from what I've seen in other Chinese restaurants, so that was what prompted me to try Far East Cafe.  I ordered the Shredded Dry Scallop Soup and was disappointed - it had no spice, no flavor, no nothing.  No taste.

Hunan Style Prawns were good, though.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Awful.

I expect much better when I am in Chinatown!

I order a not-so-healthy staple, General Tso's (maybe poor choice by me - but I love it).  It was hard to tell if there was even CHICKEN inside of the fried / stringy / breaded / toughness.  Could have been mystery meat, whatever it was - it was not good.  Also, the cooked with very oily onions and then some raw onions thrown in last minute (just plain bad combination).

I was eating by myself and I think the waiter was disinterested in me because I wasn't a large party.  

Honestly, it might have been the worst Chinese food I have ever had!
author: Katherine W.

description:
The decor in this place is so cool. It's been around forever, and the food isn't bad. Sometimes I get food to-go, since I work around the corner.  Only annoying thing is that you'll order something "over rice" and they'll give you one cup of entree and three cups of rice. I'd say, add a cup of entree and take away a cup of rice and it'd be perfect. 
I usually order beef and veggies over rice which is darn tasty. My co-worker likes tofu and veggies over rice which is pretty good, too. They use the deep fried kind of tofu instead of the plain white kind, which is a bonus. 
They also have a full bar which is unique for a Chinese eatery.
author: Jessica O.

description: I'll start with the atmosphere: meh.  It's very open and large and I'm not the biggest fan of huge places like this.  The service was not that accommodating - This was in part because of our language barrier, and part because he was a bit cold.  The food: Double meh.  My friend Luci is normally a huge fan of cheese filled wontons.  These wontons came as large pieces of flat fried dough with maybe a little ball in the center of ... something.  My vegetable spring rolls were okay, but so loaded with grease I think anything dunked in that vat would have tasted exactly the same.  I would never come back here again and perhaps it was our mistake to enter in the first place.  Word of the wise in Chinatown:  Stick to the small, quick bakeries and shops that make their food fresh daily - shops that you can't necessarily sit down in and be served, but you will get a quality food experience, for a much lower price and much more of the overall Chinatown experience.  Across the street from Far East Cafe is a place with red bean sticky buns and assorted goodies.  Go there instead for a midday snack.
author: Julia H.

description:
If you are a yelper that gives this place less than 4 stars, it's because you're not ordering the Hong Kong style Beef Fried rice. It's out of this world. So are the spicy prawns, and any other dish that hasn't been Americanized!

Maybe I get special treatment since I am a local and a regular.... But the beef fried rice hits the spot when you're looking for a quick jolt of Chinese food yumminess.
author: dj z.

description:
Very average food. Whle I'm not one of those people who thrives on things like sweet/sour sauce, I don't have to have my "Chinese" be truly authentic. If I like something, I'll eat it, authentic or not. 

With that said, this place was average at best and just yucky at worst. The good: the egg rolls. Hot and actually pretty good. They were the best part of the meal. The bad: stir fry beef. Just didn't like it. 

I went back and forth between giving it 2 or 3 stars. I can't say anything truly horrible about the place but I can't really praise it either. It probably won't kill you, it's cleaner than some of the other hole in the wall places but it isn't particuarly good or memorable. I'll take the egg rolls and leave the rest. All in all, much better restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Anita B.

description:
Came here for a banquet, upstairs is large, roomy for 200+ ppl. 

First restaurant I've been to with closed circuit tv, where they can show the entire banquet room on tv sets, for anyone who can't see the important party, or if you just want your event video taped.

Food wasn't too bad... I think there was 10 courses, but it could have very well been 8 or 12 dishes... I wasn't counting. The fish was sorta blah. The soup was good. The chicken was 'juicy', the duck fatty as usual, fried rice was so-so. The walnut prawns was mayo-prawny. Food came out fast.
author: qirk z.

description:
This place used to be cool, it definately doesn't feel that way anymore. The oldschool booths have been taken down so there's only one wall of them left. My dad used to take me here when I was a kid because it was near his office, so I remember what it looked like somewhere around 1986-1997.

The food is so-so, I wasn't really impressed with what I had, but it wasn't bad. $7 for regular eggrolls?

It feels touristy, might be a good place to bring the folks when they're staying nearby...
author: Tom S.

description:
Awesome spot for a fun, delicious and reasonably priced Chinatown meal.

The atmosphere is 'authentic' or at least attention is paid to details. I love getting a private little booth - it makes you feel special ;)

Best of all though is the service. Each waiter was more friendly than the last and we all laughed a lot for some reason.
author: Douglas C.

description: Pretty good place to eat, compared to the last place went to in SF Chinatown. We had the egg rolls, mu shu pork, and seafood chow fun. The place was pretty quiet on Sunday, though I was hoping for some dim sum, this place was still pretty good.
author: George S.

description: The food was decent. The waitstaff kept coming by regularly to see if we wanted any more food. I just wasn't that inspired by the food, especially for the price.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
This restaurant has been open for 85 years. Lots of history and really good food. I won't lie - we came here with a connection and were treated like royalty. BUT the food was really YUMMY. We had:
- pot stickers - perfectly pan-fried and not too oily. Good meat! 
- chicken with black bean sauce - the chicken is soooooo tender! YUM!
- deep fried tofu - my fav. really good.
- clams - another fav. equally good.
- seafood claypot - oskar p's fav. he really enjoyed it. i like the braised tofu it came with.

Everything just melt in your mouth and tastes delicious. They have private booths on the side of the restaurant and they are intimate and really cool to dine in - on a date or with a group. 

The service is awesome. All the servers are really friendly and attentive to your needs.  Definitely check them out!
author: Gladys C.

description: As usual I have patronized this restaurant for over 3 years and usually found it to be an enjoyable experience. However, seems that since the President dined here and gave it a big boost, their service has gone down the drain. They seem to think that we need their food and have become too confident and now have chosen to ignore their customers.  We reserved our table in January and when we arrived they gave us a hard time. To make it short they needed the seats for other people too, so take it or leave it attitude and not what you ask for, what we give you. Smaller incidents occurred as we dined. The food was good, not excellent anymore. But the big problem was as we were winding up the dinner, they wanted the table back for other customers so they asked us when we were going to leave.  They refused us the complementary desert because they didn't have time and again asked us to leave as others were waiting.  We complained to the management who gave us little notice, basically showing us the door.  We usually have a party of 6 or more.  But, no longer, we will find another fine dining restaurant down the street.  Sorry!!
author: Alfred M.

description:
yeah dimsum!  we spotted a sign outside and scooted right in.

just in case...we asked if we could order dimsum before being seated and were told that we could.  (some places only serve it at morning time.)

for having a sign outside saying dimsum...this place only had one small mixed platter to order.  disheartened, my bf and i had already settled down and were sipping away at our little cups of tea - so we decided to stay.

it was an average medley with a pork bun, eggrolls, shrimp dumplings, and pork dumplings.  after drowning it in chili sauce, i was happy again.
it's not noted but you can order a half portion of the peking duck which
worked out well for us.

on the plus side: the space was great for groups.  lots of table choices and private booths along the wall - there was a whole other floor upstairs for banquets.

however for dim sum, i'd hold out for other choices in the area.
author: Anh V.

description: I'd like to come here for dinner some time.  At lunch, the place is dead, the service is terrible, and the food in uninspiring.  The other reviews seem to brand it as a better dinner spot.  I'd give it another chance.
author: Michael J.

description:
I walked into the restaurant because I wanted food and their sign happened to catch my eye.  The staff is very friendly but the food was disappointing.  I don't know what the dish is called in English and I don't know proper pinyin, but it's called "gan tsow neoh huh," which I will refer to as "beef noodles" for the remainder of this review.

Everyone keeps telling me that the Chinatown in SF is THE PLACE to get Chinese food.  Everyone and their mother spoke Cantonese in Chinatown and the beef noodles are Cantonese, as far as I know, so I was expecting noodles on the scale of amazing.  I would have settled for even just plain passable.  Unfortunately, they tasted funny.  I'm not sure how to describe it ... sour?  Perhaps I should have asked the waiter to recommend a dish that they were known for because beef noodles, while it is a pretty basic Cantonese dish, ain't it.  While I wish I could say that I would go back and give it a second try, the noodles were just so awful that I just don't really want to.
author: Cat C.

description: This place is OK.  They have an interesting, throw-back decor inside complete with private booth areas.  Prices are decent, but really don't go out of your way to eat here.  It's just your typical tasty American Chinese food that you can find in most Bay Area cities.  From what I understand, however, this place has been here for ages, so if you're into Chinatown history it may be a spot to poke your head into.
author: Jeronimo L.

description: Food was ok. Small portions and very bad service. Not going back here again. Do yourself a favor and find another place.
author: Igor K.

description: We ordered the honeyed walnut prawns - yum yum! - and one other dish to go. Delicious and reasonably priced, friendly staff and quick service. We'll be back!
author: Colleen a.

description: "I wish I could give this place a negative zero. They rushed us the entire time and didn't care about the service. I felt so dirty eating their food, the environment is filthy. They really don't care. Awful food and service . Do not eat here. I don't know how anyone could give this place more than 1 star. I'm serious save your money. It was expensive for no reason. The food made me want to vomit. Awful awful place. You can tell they never clean that place, the kitchen had cleaning supplies right next to the food and they didn't wash their hands after touching said cleaning supplies.
author: El R.

description: If you're in Chinatown, go to a different Chinese place. The food was warm, not hot. They got our order wrong (we don't even know they gave us) We had trouble getting a waiter. It wasn't that filling or that good. Seriously, Chinese take out was better than this place.
author: Robin J.

description: We gave this place a try after hearing great things from some other friends. Was not that good, very expensive and we were all really disappointed :(
author: Tori M.

description: Have been here many times over the years. This old historic restaurant in Chinatown has been the host of countless Wedding Banquets and Red Egg & Ginger Parties (Baby Parties). The banquet room located upstairs is quite large with a huge dance floor. The food and service is good and acceptable.
author: Les W.

description:
My aunt, cousins, and I were looking for a decent place to eat for lunch. I was kind of skeptical about this restaurant because it looked kind of dirty on the outside. We decided on this restaurant since my aunt had tried it beforehand and was tired of looking around for other restaurants to eat in the area. 

We came in and we were greeted immediately and got seated quickly too. The restaurant was pretty big and wasn't too crowded. I noticed that there were little private rooms to the side that were covered with curtains where guests could choose to dine in. The servers here were pretty friendly compared to most Chinese restaurants that I've been to. When I was looking at the menu on the outside of the restaurant  there were pictures of dim sum dishes. As I looked through the menu inside of the restaurant, there was only 1 page of the menu which was dim sum, and it only had about 5 pictures of the dim sum dishes they served. I was quite disappointed because I thought it was a dim sum restaurant. Anyways, as I continued to look through the menu, I became very uninterested in the food. I decided to look at the lunch menu and came across the Seafood Chow Mein. I thought this was a safe choice, so I ordered it. 

The food came out fairly quick and my portion was decent. My noodles were mediocre and there wasn't much seafood. My aunt ordered a dish of peking duck, which was VERY expensive and tasted gamey. I got to try some of my cousin's Yang Chow Fried Rice, and it was the tastiest thing out of those three dishes. 

Our bill was pretty pricey considering we all ordered from the lunch menu. (There was 4 people in our party.) 4 lunch menu items + 1 peking duck order = $50. Definitely not worth it.
author: Catherine C.

description: I went to Far East Cafe for a volunteer recognition lunch today and was not wowed by the food at all. It appears to be a good venue for hosting large groups because the event was held in a private dining room upstairs but I would not choose to return when there is a plethora of choices for Chinese Food in Chinatown. The dim sum was average. The beef chow fun, pan fried noodles and fried rice was not memorable. The orange chicken was a little too sweet for my taste. It should have been spicier and the sauce a little more tangy. I could find better versions of the dishes they served at other restaurants.
author: Lisa M.

description: The wonton soup was bland; the sesame chicken was fried in very thick batter with hardly any meat; and the Buddha delight was not at all delightful!  I could get better Chinese food in the mall!  Our server was inattentive and unfriendly -  we had to flag him down twice to get the rest of our order; every time he delivered food to our table, he quickly turned and just disappeared and only cracked a smile at the end when picked up payment from us! We will never come back!
author: L P.

description: I used to go there in the 80's to snort coke in the private booths. Now I go there to eat pretty good Chinese food and wonder what the kids are doing in the private booths. It's a must see in SF.
author: Jonnie T.

description:
I was very pleased with the service and the food that far east provided. When you first walk in it looks like a hole in the wall china town Chinese place but it is a very nice place once you get in. 
We sat in one of those private dining rooms which was cool and got the cheapest (which is far from cheap) family meal which was 16.50 a person. The meal its self was good, it was the best sweet and sour pork I have ever had and I will defiantly want to come back if I come to San fran again!
author: Caleb S.

description:
I won't go back.

Pros:  The service was excellent.  This was on Easter Sunday night (2009) and it wasn't too crowded.  Every serve who walked by wouldn't hesitate to stop at our table to complete our order, ask if we needed anything, gather our used plates, take the check, etc.  They were not constrained by the fact we weren't at his/her table.  That was nice.  Also, the main dining room is kinda cool.  It has these large tables separated by walls and curtains on the left for larger groups.  I've eaten in one of them before and it was a nice cozy way to dine, even for a business meal.  The rest of the dining room is spartan, but the lighting is very cool (see some of the pictures) and the atmosphere reminds of a bygone era before every restaurant tried for a jazz lounge look.

CONS:  The food was average at best.  I had pot sticker appetizer, and it was a huge portion and very tasty.  I had cashew chicken meal, and it was lifeless and bland.  The Mongolian beef was similar, and had kind of a slimy texture.  I had been here a few years ago and had much better food.  The appetizers are too big (serving 2-3) to be ordered individually, or even for a table of 2.  
Actually the worst part of the experience, which colored the entire rest of the visit, was the trip past the kitchen, upstairs to the restroom.  It was beyond disgusting.  The stairs going upstairs to the restroom were originally (about 500 years ago) burgundy, but they had worn down to white surrounded by what looked like black mold.  Worse yet, they were actually wet and sticky, as if a dynasty's worth of won ton soup had been spilled on them and just sat there.  My foot made that spongy sound when walking on the carpet and it was sticky too.  I'm so glad that I went there at the end of the meal rather than at the beginning, as it definitely will ruin the appetite.  I did not notice anything patently and specifically unclean in the kitchen on the way back, but its spartan accommodations do not inspire any confidence in the hygiene being practiced there.

The meal was also too expensive for all of the foregoing reasons.  I had been there for a business lunch years ago and had a good experience.  Not sure what's changed (or maybe I didn't explore the restaurant last time) but it's definitely time to find a new Chinatown spot.
author: Mark A.

description:
Hey, I think the food here is really good!  

Mom hit 82 this week, almost as old as the restaurant, and we took her here for lunch. My Lady has been eating here for her entire life, and everyone was happy with this excursion.  Naturally, My Lady grabbed a booth, and we ate in private, like conspiratorial bankers determining the fate of politicians.  

The food leans heavily towards Cantonese, and they prominently display a seafood menu.  For the cuisine, it's quite flavorful and filling.  Since we were a party of 3, we did not see the banquet scene, which is where most of the complaints in the other reviews originate.  My Lady points out that banquets are very difficult to handle, in any case.  

The food:  
Westlake beef soup:  My Lady swears by this stuff.  The waiter laughed when I called it Daly City soup.   
Rolling lettuce minced seafood:  Think of it as a Chinese protein wrap.  I quickly learned to go easy on the sauce, as the seafood had a delicate flavor.   
Black mushrooms and baby bok choy:  My Lady and Mom relished the mushrooms.  When Mom declared she didn't like bok choy, I went ahead and ate all of them.  I love bok choy!   
General Chou's chicken:  Yay!  Deep fried chicken strips in orange sauce!  The deep fry batter tastes a lot like fortune cookies.   
Steamed rice:  Well, of course.  How else can you finish off all the sauces pooling on your plate?   
Black tea:  The world-famous sauce solvent.  All you can drink.   
Tsing Tao beer, actually brewed in Tsing Tao, according to the label. 
Fortune cookies:  Mine said, "Seek out the significance of your problem at this time.  Try to understand."  My big problem here is trying to understand what the heck it's talking about.  I'm going to play the lotto numbers on the back, though.   

All this food stuffed the 3 of us for $64.  That's a better deal than we've seen on Clement Street lately.  The waiters were very pleased that I knew how to say "Thank you" in Cantonese, and kept repeating "Thank you" and "You're welcome" throughout the meal.  That was more appreciation than I got for the effort back in Silicon Valley.
author: David D.

description: The reviews that say meh are accurate. Not bad, just nothing special. You can easily do better.
author: Ben S.

description:
I dine here once a year for the annual Chinese New Year banquet
with about 300 people I don't know - I guess we're one big giant extended family!  It's been pretty consistent the past few years, so when I was here this past weekend I had an idea of what to expect.  We're always booked in the dining area on the 2nd floor so it's nice and private.

I like coming here because they always provide a dance floor and karaoke machine - this provides plenty of entertainment.  I get the 
privilege of listening to little old people sing Chinese music like they're on American Idol and watch cute little grandpas and grandmas dance away.

The food is actually pretty good - we got the usual 7-8 item banquet menu with lemon sponge cake as the dessert.  The first item that was served was the cold appetizer plate consisting of jelly fish, bbq pork, etc.  This was followed byshark fin soup, sweet and sour spare ribs, fried chicken (with an excellent sauce), veggies with mushroom, shrimp with cashews, and fish.  All the dishes were prepared very well and seasoned perfectly.  The only one that was kinda bland was the shrimp with cashews - I didn't care for that too much.  My favorite dish was the deep fried fish fillets covered with a clear white egg gravy of some sort, with some carrots and peas.  It kinda looked and tasted like a super thick version of egg drop soup.  It was spectacular and our table had to ask for extra rice to eat with this dish, it was that good!  Although this was the last item to be served and we were all completely stuffed, we managed to inhale it - we didn't leave a drop of sauce on the plate! =)  

Service was great!  The waiters were always around to refillour tea, bring us more rice, and even serve us extra slices of cake (it was delish)!  We got to meet the chef at the end of meal and we complimented him on a job well done!  We let him know that the food was yummy and we enjoyed it all, especially the fish!  He was glad to hear it, especially since he looked like he was ready to pass out after cooking for so many people.

I've never tried the food here from the regular menu, but I can only assume that it would be as good as what we were served.  I look forward to returning next year!
author: Cynthia H.

description: Just attended an annual fundraiser supported by Far East Cafe. They do a lovely job serving a succession of platters to 40-50 tables, filling the entire upstairs floor. An impressive feast, and they're very accommodating to the Asian Women's Resource Center's semi-formal event every year. They kept the food coming, saved what was left over from each platter onto the next platters, so we didn't feel hurried but also didn't have to wait for the next course. My favorites were the prawns with candied walnuts (and I rarely order prawns!) and the spinach. They even let us take home leftovers, rare for a banquet-style meal.
author: Laurel L.

description:
4 stars is for the wedding banquet I had here over a year ago.  If you're planning a chinese wedding banquet, this is a good place to have it.  Ask for Wing, he's one of the restaurant manager.  He was extremely helpful.  He gave us a lot of free stuff too!  He didn't even try to push us to pick the most expensive banquet menu, instead, he tried to work with us on picking the one that met our needs.  I like how there's just one banquet area upstairs....because a lot of chinese restaurants try to have more than one wedding banquet in one night and it's kind of tacky and confusing for the guests.  As for the food...I think most banquet food taste alike.  The food at the banquet was good, not great, but not bad.  Also, they have a big dance floor with a disco ball!  Wing was great, he even helped out at the banquet!  

I would not come here for dinner or lunch but I would definitely recommend this place if you're planning a chinese wedding banquet!
author: Katniss B.

description: My cousin had her wedding banquet reception here.  While we were sitting there all of a sudden a rat, not a mouse, came running in the middle of the dance floor and he just froze there.  A waiter saw it and came running with one of the dinner napkins and just grabbed it with his hand!! I didn't eat afterwards.
author: Kymberli C.

description: This place was horrible.  Went in because of banners outside that claim they were top 100 Chinese restaurants in US, what a total lie.  Started with the dim sum combo platter which wasn't too bad but not even close to what I've had elsewhere.  They claim their seafood is what they are popular for so we ordered the sea bass and the honey walnut prawns off the chef's special menu and both were awful, we couldn't even eat it.  The sea bass tasted like it was rotten and the spicy seasoning was basically pepper and rock salt and something that was so funky we tasted it for the rest of the day even though we each only had 1 bite.  The prawns had some kind of thick sauce that stuck to the prawns like glue and was so sweet it was intolerable.  I asked for a glass of water when we sat down and it never came.  The prices were high and cost us $60 for one of the worst meals I've ever had.  We watched the people around us that ordered lomein and Szechuan beef, more usual American-Chinese dishes and their reactions were similar to ours.  Avoid this place at all costs.  Too many other great places to eat in Chinatown.
author: Mary K.

description: This is by far my favorite Chinese food restaurant in the city.  I live nearby and get take-out all the time.  The food is always hot and the produce they use is always fresh.  The first time I went there, I was absolutely baffled at how fresh the chicken fried rice was.  Typically, when you order fried rice, you almost always expect it to be dry from probably sitting around for a while, but their fried rice is always moist and has an amazing flavor to it.  The sweet and sour pork is great and even though spring rolls are hard to screw up, they are always delicious.  I am absolutely perplexed by some of the poor reviews.  I wouldn't exactly call myself a "chinese food connoisseur," but can certainly appreciate food that is always tasty and fresh.  I have been there many times and Far East Cafe has never let me down.
author: Lauren W.

description: Not a big chinese food fan. That said, I love this place. The manager, Wing, should do stand-up comedy on the side. There's also something to be said about eating in one of the oldest establishments in San Francisco. Treat yourself and a group of people to a booth, but make sure you call ahead to reserve it.
author: Babs P.

description:
This is a fantastic place to take out of town visitors who want to go to Chinatown.  It's smack in the middle of Grant and the decor is phenomenal . . . classic vintage Chinatown.  My midwest relatives are always impressed.  

The food is not as bad as some reviewers claim, but it certainly isn't fantastic.  Criticizing the food is like giving a bad review to the sushi at a sushi boat restaurant . . . eating here is not really about the food, it's more about a novelty experience.  

When ordering, stick with the simple stuff, don't expect too much, have a nice cup of tea and soak in the ambiance.
author: amy b.

description: I've been coming here since I was a kid. Every time my family visited SF we always made time for dinner here. It's a nice hole in the wall chinese restaurant with awesome private booths. I like the fookin rice, yes...people at the table were drunk when they ordered it and made many jokes, but it's awesome rice in a light gravy sauce with veggies and shrimp, pork, and beef. Great if you're going there in a group...plenty of food to go around.
author: Melanie B.

description:
I would NEVER GO BACK to FAR EAST CAFE again! THIS IS THE WORST RESTAURANT that we have ever had a meal in.  We would never set foot in this place again.  The food we ordered was served ICE cold.  Yes this is not a joke, ICE COLD.  The beef with broccoli was cold like it just came out of the refrigerator.  When we were finally able to get the attention of a waiter, he took the food and stuck the dish in a microwave oven.  I could see all this occurring as the large fish tanks provided a perfect reflection of the entrance to the kitchen where upon going to use the restroom I did in fact confirm a little gray microwave just as I had seen.
The waiter was cold and rude and never once did they check in to see how we liked the meal.  BUT for the larger groups of people of (7 or more people) they were being catered to like a normal restaurant should.  So clearly this is place that should go out of business as the FAR EAST CAFE owned by the HNH Corporation really sucks!  How can you take the food and microwave it and serve it back to the guests?
I would NEVER GO BACK to FAR EAST CAFE again!!!
author: R. B.

description: Far East Cafe is the venue of choice for organizations and companies that need good banquet food at an affordable price, with an upstairs event dining area with quite a few amenities. (No, I don't work for them..)
author: Keith K.

description: Ehhh, we were greeted quite nicely and they aren't cheap and not uberly expensive. However, our server was slow and rude. I escaped to the bathroom and my friend ordered for me and when he asked what was included in the Combination Noodles (Pan Fried H.K. style add a $1), he rudely responded: SCALLOPS, CALAMARI, BOK CHOY, SHRIMP, & CHICKEN. We also had to ask for water which didn't come until after we were done with our meal. Comes with hot tea. The noodles itself were good but not worth the price and not big enough to fill up two people. Search elsewhere, I'm sure there are better places out there.
author: Nadine B.

description:
it looked cool.

the food was okay. nothing really special. the tea was really good. the hot and sour soup was really sour. the dim sum was okay. and my tofu with vegetables was okay... like i said, nothing special.

the customer service was really good though.
author: A. M.

description:
i only attend big parties at this restaurant. the 2nd floor of the restaurant is great for big parties. there's even a dance floor. you can also sing K  and have a poteum.

i haven't tried their food downstairs (the stuff off the menu). but the special dishes that i've had are good. too bad you can only eat this kinda food during wedding parties, big family parties or special occassions.

oh yeah, they speak english there too!

personal fave: great for parties of 100+
author: Mei N.

description: I loved the food, and I love the fact that a lot of events held by non-profs end up coming here!! Sweet!
author: Michael C.

description: Food is good and the beef use stir-fry is unbelievably tender.  Otherwise, nothing is particularly memorable.
author: Jerry C.

description: A pretty gringo place for a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. The food was good, and it was pretty cheap, nothing to write home about however.
author: Daniel K.

description: Food was good but the portions were very small for the price we paid. The "privacy booth" is good for a party less than five adults and two kids, otherwise space is very limited.
author: Selina L.

description: This is a good restaurant. Highly recommended.  It is better to go with someone who knows what to order and understands authentic Chinese food.  Don't order the typical American-style Chinese food  like sweet and sour .., chow men, fried rice, Kung Pao ..
author: Ken V.

description: Came here for my agency Christmas party.. it was surprising that the place is actually pretty big for a "cafe". I thought it was going to be small, but it was okay to accommodate 200 something people and probably could fit more. The food is just okay for me. It's so greasy although I like their sweet and sour ribs. The place has a private/ VIP room on the second floor in the back, which looks pretty cozy. It's definitely can accommodate lots of people, but the food could be better!
author: Daisy S.

description: Stopped in and had a couple of ice cold beers and a few snacks. Salt and pepper shrimp were yummy as were the chicken wings. Both were generous portions and very reasonably priced. We were sorry to hear that they would be closed to the general public in the upcoming days of our stay due to several large parties. Service was outstanding, very attentive and our host gave us interesting insights into Chinese culture. .
author: Kris M.

description: In the past, this was one of my fave raves for the giant Chinese chandeliers, wooden "booths" that gave great privacy to any party and fun for kids. But no more - the food was terrible and the service worse today. We ordered mu shu chicken but could not find ONE piece of chicken in it; the pancakes were dry and almost inedible. The two other dishes were also extremely light on the protein and high on the filler, and neither one was even as good as you might expect from a cheap franchise place on Powell or worse. So disappointed in the whole experience.
author: Paige W.

description: The food was good. I had the dimsum and the Schezuan prawns. I wish the prawns were on the bigger size and fresh not frozen. Prices are very reasonable. Good selection. The food is good. Not memorable but good. The server was somehow not interested in giving suggestions...that's a shame. Overall, I would not return based on all the other choices in the area..
author: Chris A.

description: i've had better chinese food. the entrees werent horrible, but im not asking the cook to bury me in the beef chow fun so i can eat my way out of it in order to survive.  the cook was really stingy with the prawns for our prawn and honey walnut plate and a lot of the food was on the salty side. the highlight of the night was the dungeness crab in spicy salt. the dish would have been much better if it were soft shell crabs instead. cracking crab legs while drunk and hungry was one of the hardest things to do!
author: marlene m.

description: I loved the rat story.  Listen, if you are a tourist it can't get much better than this restaurant for authentic San Francisco Chinatown culture.  Don't go there to eat strictly speaking, but if you do, you'll be fine.  Go there and sit in one of the booths, get a Gin'nTonic and feel like you are back in time and that an earthquake may happen any moment.  Seriously a great place to impress a first date.  There are some ceiling lights that are classic, they must have been there since like 1849.  Don't go there trying to be a foodie or get all worked up over the fact that they are actually suppose to be a restaurant, that's beside the point really.  My family gave my son a Red Egg Party there, and it was the bomb.  True the food sucks, get over it, you can get better food anywhere practically, but why do you think they stay in business? because the place is awesomely Chinatown that's why. OH, and here's some advice from someone who knows the game.  If you act all picky and fussy and don't look happy, you are going to get treated like the turp you are for being out on the town and whining.  They don't need your stupid business they are an icon and are probably richer than you.
author: Sarah H.

description: Ok, I take out-of-towners here for the Barbary Coast Chinese effect 'cause it looks the way an exotic Chinese restaurant ought to--imagine shang hai-ing going on in the basement, opium dens somewhere in the upper back rooms, beautiful prostitutes....  Ok, none of that actually happens anymore but if it did, this is the place that has the right look for it.  Ask for a booth so you can close the curtains (there are little buttons inside but I don't know if they actually work or not).  Food isn't anything to write home about and I wouldn't recommend going just for the food, but the wonton chicken soup is pretty good and I guess everything else I've eaten here was passable if unmemorable.  I've been 5 or more times but can't remember any of the food we've ordered (except the wonton soup).  It's right in Chinatown so parking would be a problem but we always take public transit and walk the few blocks up to Ctown.
author: Kai T.
